quoteText:
Now, do you think we re enjoying ourselves
enormously?
subQuotationList: ['Now, do you think we re enjoying ourselves\nenormously?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: Katharine as she shook hands with him asked him
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue', 'Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman']]]

quoteText: Mr. Denham, mother,
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Denham, mother,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText:
Now, what would you do if you were married to an engineer, and had to
live in Manchester, Mr. Denham?
subQuotationList: ['Now, what would you do if you were married to an engineer, and had to\nlive in Manchester, Mr. Denham?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']
referringExpression: Mrs Hilbery deftly joined the severed parts by leaning towards him and remarking

quoteText:
Surely she could learn Persian, Is there no retired schoolmaster or man of letters in Manchester with
whom she could read Persian?
subQuotationList: ['Surely she could learn Persian,', 'Is there no retired schoolmaster or man of letters in Manchester with\nwhom she could read Persian?']
speaker: A Thin, Elderly Gentleman
referringExpression: broke in a thin elderly gentleman

quoteText: A cousin of ours has married and gone to live in Manchester,
subQuotationList: ['A cousin of ours has married and gone to live in Manchester,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText: Have you ever been to Manchester?
subQuotationList: ['Have you ever been to Manchester?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Never,
subQuotationList: ['Never,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Why do you object to it, then?
subQuotationList: ['Why do you object to it, then?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I should think there would be no one to talk to in Manchester,
subQuotationList: ['I should think there would be no one to talk to in Manchester,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
In spite of a slight tendency to exaggeration, Katharine decidedly
hits the mark,
subQuotationList: ['In spite of a slight tendency to exaggeration, Katharine decidedly\nhits the mark,']
speaker: Mr. Fortescue
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery']

quoteText:
Oh, Mr. Fortescue, I had
just written to say how I envied her! I was thinking of the big gardens
and the dear old ladies in mittens, who read nothing but the and snuff the candles. Have they _all_ disappeared? I told
her she would find the nice things of London without the horrid streets
that depress one so.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, Mr. Fortescue,', 'I had
just written to say how I envied her! I was thinking of the big gardens
and the dear old ladies in mittens, who read nothing but the', 'and snuff the candles. Have they _all_ disappeared? I told
her she would find the nice things of London without the horrid streets
that depress one so.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText: There is the University,
subQuotationList: ['There is the University,']
speaker: A Thin, Elderly Gentleman

quoteText:
I know there are moors there, because I read about them in a book the
other day,
subQuotationList: ['I know there are moors there, because I read about them in a book the\nother day,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText: I am grieved and amazed at the ignorance of my family,
subQuotationList: ['I am grieved and amazed at the ignorance of my family,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery
addressees: ['A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText: Would it be the Battle of Trafalgar or the Spanish Armada, Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['Would it be the Battle of Trafalgar or the Spanish Armada, Katharine?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText: Trafalgar, mother.
subQuotationList: ['Trafalgar, mother.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText:
Trafalgar, of course! How stupid of me! Another cup of tea, with a
thin slice of lemon in it, and then, dear Mr. Fortescue, please explain
my absurd little puzzle. One can t help believing gentlemen with Roman
noses, even if one meets them in omnibuses.
subQuotationList:
['Trafalgar, of course! How stupid of me! Another cup of tea, with a
thin slice of lemon in it, and then, dear Mr. Fortescue, please explain
my absurd little puzzle. One can t help believing gentlemen with Roman
noses, even if one meets them in omnibuses.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

quoteText:
D you know, Mr. Denham, you remind me so much of dear Mr.
Ruskin.... Is it his tie, Katharine, or his hair, or the way he sits in
his chair? Do tell me, Mr. Denham, are you an admirer of Ruskin? Some
one, the other day, said to me,  Oh, no, we don t read Ruskin, Mrs.
Hilbery.  What _do_ you read, I wonder? for you can t spend all your
time going up in aeroplanes and burrowing into the bowels of the
earth.
subQuotationList:
['D you know, Mr. Denham, you remind me so much of dear Mr.
Ruskin.... Is it his tie, Katharine, or his hair, or the way he sits in
his chair? Do tell me, Mr. Denham, are you an admirer of Ruskin? Some
one, the other day, said to me,  Oh, no, we don t read Ruskin, Mrs.
Hilbery.  What _do_ you read, I wonder? for you can t spend all your
time going up in aeroplanes and burrowing into the bowels of the
earth.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Mrs. Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
I m sure Mr. Denham would like to see our things, Katharine. I m sure
he s not like that dreadful young man, Mr. Ponting, who told me that he
considered it our duty to live exclusively in the present. After all,
what IS the present? Half of it s the past, and the better half, too, I
should say,
subQuotationList:
['I m sure Mr. Denham would like to see our things, Katharine. I m sure
he s not like that dreadful young man, Mr. Ponting, who told me that he
considered it our duty to live exclusively in the present. After all,
what IS the present? Half of it s the past, and the better half, too, I
should say,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']
referringExpression: Mrs Hilbery seemed possessed by a brilliant idea and exclaimed

quoteText: Perhaps you would like to see the pictures,
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps you would like to see the pictures,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']
referringExpression: Katharine rose at the same moment and saying

quoteText: This is his writing-table. He used this pen,
subQuotationList: ['This is his writing-table. He used this pen,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I think my grandfather must have been at least twice as large as any
one is nowadays. This, is the original manuscript of the  Ode to Winter.  The early
poems are far less corrected than the later. Would you like to look at
it?
subQuotationList:
['I think my grandfather must have been at least twice as large as any
one is nowadays. This,', 'is the original manuscript of the  Ode to Winter.  The early
poems are far less corrected than the later. Would you like to look at
it?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
This is a copy of the first edition of the poems, which contains several poems that have not been
reprinted, as well as corrections.
subQuotationList: ['This is a copy of the first edition of the poems,', 'which contains several poems that have not been\nreprinted, as well as corrections.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
That lady in blue is my great-grandmother, by Millington. Here is my
uncle s walking-stick he was Sir Richard Warburton, you know, and rode
with Havelock to the Relief of Lucknow. And then, let me see oh, that s
the original Alardyce, 1697, the founder of the family fortunes, with
his wife. Some one gave us this bowl the other day because it has their
crest and initials. We think it must have been given them to celebrate
their silver wedding-day.
subQuotationList:
['That lady in blue is my great-grandmother, by Millington. Here is my
uncle s walking-stick he was Sir Richard Warburton, you know, and rode
with Havelock to the Relief of Lucknow. And then, let me see oh, that s
the original Alardyce, 1697, the founder of the family fortunes, with
his wife. Some one gave us this bowl the other day because it has their
crest and initials. We think it must have been given them to celebrate
their silver wedding-day.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: She paused for a minute and then went on
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Richard Warburton'], ['Sir Richard Warburton'], ['Sir Richard Warburton'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']]]

quoteText: You must be very proud of your family, Miss Hilbery.
subQuotationList: ['You must be very proud of your family, Miss Hilbery.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: he laid down the manuscript and said

quoteText:
Yes, I am, Do you think there s
anything wrong in that?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I am,', 'Do you think there s\nanything wrong in that?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Wrong? How should it be wrong? It must be a bore, though, showing your
things to visitors,
subQuotationList: ['Wrong? How should it be wrong? It must be a bore, though, showing your\nthings to visitors,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Not if the visitors like them.
subQuotationList: ['Not if the visitors like them.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Isn t it difficult to live up to your ancestors?
subQuotationList: ['Isn t it difficult to live up to your ancestors?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I dare say I shouldn t try to write poetry,
subQuotationList: ['I dare say I shouldn t try to write poetry,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No. And that s what I should hate. I couldn t bear my grandfather to
cut me out. And, after all, it s not your grandfather only.
You re cut out all the way round. I suppose you come of one of the most
distinguished families in England. There are the Warburtons and the
Mannings and you re related to the Otways, aren t you? I read it all in
some magazine,
subQuotationList:
['No. And that s what I should hate. I couldn t bear my grandfather to
cut me out. And, after all,', 'it s not your grandfather only.
You re cut out all the way round. I suppose you come of one of the most
distinguished families in England. There are the Warburtons and the
Mannings and you re related to the Otways, aren t you? I read it all in
some magazine,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: The Otways are my cousins,
subQuotationList: ['The Otways are my cousins,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Well,
subQuotationList: ['Well,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Well, I don t see that you ve proved anything.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'I don t see that you ve proved anything.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Well,
subQuotationList: ['Well,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But aren t you proud of your family?
subQuotationList: ['But aren t you proud of your family?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No, We ve never done anything to be proud of unless you
count paying one s bills a matter for pride.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'We ve never done anything to be proud of unless you\ncount paying one s bills a matter for pride.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: That sounds rather dull,
subQuotationList: ['That sounds rather dull,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You would think us horribly dull,
subQuotationList: ['You would think us horribly dull,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Yes, I might find you dull, but I don t think I should find you
ridiculous,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I might find you dull, but I don t think I should find you\nridiculous,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No because we re not in the least ridiculous. We re a respectable
middle-class family, living at Highgate.
subQuotationList: ['No because we re not in the least ridiculous. We re a respectable\nmiddle-class family, living at Highgate.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']]]

quoteText: We don t live at Highgate, but we re middle class too, I suppose.
subQuotationList: ['We don t live at Highgate, but we re middle class too, I suppose.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: That belonged to Clive, so we say,
subQuotationList: ['That belonged to Clive, so we say,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Is it a lie?
subQuotationList: ['Is it a lie?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: It s a family tradition. I don t know that we can prove it.
subQuotationList: ['It s a family tradition. I don t know that we can prove it.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You see, we don t have traditions in our family,
subQuotationList: ['You see, we don t have traditions in our family,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You sound very dull,
subQuotationList: ['You sound very dull,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Merely middle class,
subQuotationList: ['Merely middle class,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You pay your bills, and you speak the truth. I don t see why you
should despise us.
subQuotationList: ['You pay your bills, and you speak the truth. I don t see why you\nshould despise us.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I shouldn t like to be you; that s all I said,
subQuotationList: ['I shouldn t like to be you; that s all I said,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: No, but one never would like to be any one else.
subQuotationList: ['No, but one never would like to be any one else.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I should. I should like to be lots of other people.
subQuotationList: ['I should. I should like to be lots of other people.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Then why not us?
subQuotationList: ['Then why not us?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You ll never know anything at first hand, It s all been done for you. You ll never know the pleasure of buying
things after saving up for them, or reading books for the first time,
or making discoveries.
subQuotationList: ['You ll never know anything at first hand,', 'It s all been done for you. You ll never know the pleasure of buying\nthings after saving up for them, or reading books for the first time,\nor making discoveries.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Go on,
subQuotationList: ['Go on,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Of course, I don t know how you spend your time, but I suppose you have to show people round. You are
writing a life of your grandfather, aren t you? And this kind of
thing must take up a lot of time.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, I don t know how you spend your time,', 'but I suppose you have to show people round. You are\nwriting a life of your grandfather, aren t you? And this kind of\nthing', 'must take up a lot of time.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], []]

quoteText:
You ve got it very nearly right, but I only help my
mother. I don t write myself.
subQuotationList: ['You ve got it very nearly right,', 'but I only help my\nmother. I don t write myself.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Do you do anything yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Do you do anything yourself?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
What do you mean? I don t leave the house at ten and come
back at six.
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?', 'I don t leave the house at ten and come\nback at six.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I don t mean that.
subQuotationList: ['I don t mean that.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Nobody ever does do anything worth doing nowadays, You
see we don t even
print as well as they did, and as for poets or painters or
novelists there are none; so, at any rate, I m not singular.
subQuotationList:
['Nobody ever does do anything worth doing nowadays,', 'You
see', 'we don t even
print as well as they did, and as for poets or painters or
novelists there are none; so, at any rate, I m not singular.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No, we haven t any great men, I m very glad that we
haven t. I hate great men. The worship of greatness in the nineteenth
century seems to me to explain the worthlessness of that generation.
subQuotationList: ['No, we haven t any great men,', 'I m very glad that we\nhaven t. I hate great men. The worship of greatness in the nineteenth\ncentury seems to me to explain the worthlessness of that generation.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Well, how do you like our things, Mr. Denham?
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'how do you like our things, Mr. Denham?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
There are some books that _live_, They are young with us,
and they grow old with us. Are you fond of poetry, Mr. Denham? But what
an absurd question to ask! The truth is, dear Mr. Fortescue has almost
tired me out. He is so eloquent and so witty, so searching and so
profound that, after half an hour or so, I feel inclined to turn out
all the lights. But perhaps he d be more wonderful than ever in the
dark. What d you think, Katharine? Shall we give a little party in
complete darkness? There d have to be bright rooms for the bores....
subQuotationList:
['There are some books that _live_,', 'They are young with us,
and they grow old with us. Are you fond of poetry, Mr. Denham? But what
an absurd question to ask! The truth is, dear Mr. Fortescue has almost
tired me out. He is so eloquent and so witty, so searching and so
profound that, after half an hour or so, I feel inclined to turn out
all the lights. But perhaps he d be more wonderful than ever in the
dark. What d you think, Katharine? Shall we give a little party in
complete darkness? There d have to be bright rooms for the bores....']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Mr. Fortescue'], ['Mr. Fortescue'], ['Mr. Fortescue'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
But we ve any number of things to show you! Books, pictures, china, manuscripts, and the
very chair that Mary Queen of Scots sat in when she heard of Darnley s
murder. I must lie down for a little, and Katharine must change her
dress (though she s wearing a very pretty one), but if you don t mind
being left alone, supper will be at eight. I dare say you ll write a
poem of your own while you re waiting. Ah, how I love the firelight!
Doesn t our room look charming?
subQuotationList:
['But we ve any number of things to show you!', 'Books, pictures, china, manuscripts, and the
very chair that Mary Queen of Scots sat in when she heard of Darnley s
murder. I must lie down for a little, and Katharine must change her
dress (though she s wearing a very pretty one), but if you don t mind
being left alone, supper will be at eight. I dare say you ll write a
poem of your own while you re waiting. Ah, how I love the firelight!
Doesn t our room look charming?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText:
Dear things! Dear chairs and tables! How like old
friends they are faithful, silent friends. Which reminds me, Katharine,
little Mr. Anning is coming to-night, and Tite Street, and Cadogan
Square.... Do remember to get that drawing of your great-uncle glazed.
Aunt Millicent remarked it last time she was here, and I know how it
would hurt me to see _my_ father in a broken glass.
subQuotationList:
['Dear things!', 'Dear chairs and tables! How like old
friends they are faithful, silent friends. Which reminds me, Katharine,
little Mr. Anning is coming to-night, and Tite Street, and Cadogan
Square.... Do remember to get that drawing of your great-uncle glazed.
Aunt Millicent remarked it last time she was here, and I know how it
would hurt me to see _my_ father in a broken glass.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
She ll do.... Yes, Katharine Hilbery ll do.... I ll take Katharine
Hilbery.
subQuotationList: ['She ll do.... Yes, Katharine Hilbery ll do.... I ll take Katharine\nHilbery.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Mother says, aren t you coming down, Ralph? Uncle Joseph
subQuotationList: ['Mother says, aren t you coming down, Ralph? Uncle Joseph']
speaker: A Small Girl
referringExpression: a small girl popped her head in to say

quoteText: They re to bring my dinner up here,
subQuotationList: ['They re to bring my dinner up here,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Ralph!
subQuotationList: ['Ralph!']
speaker: A Voice From Within

quoteText: Ralph?
subQuotationList: ['Ralph?']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: Joan?
subQuotationList: ['Joan?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I was coming up, but I saw your notice.
subQuotationList: ['I was coming up, but I saw your notice.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: Well, come along in, then.
subQuotationList: ['Well, come along in, then.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
It s about Charles and Uncle John s offer.... Mother s been talking to
me. She says she can t afford to pay for him after this term. She says
she ll have to ask for an overdraft as it is.
subQuotationList: ['It s about Charles and Uncle John s offer.... Mother s been talking to\nme. She says she can t afford to pay for him after this term. She says\nshe ll have to ask for an overdraft as it is.']
speaker: Joan
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charles'], ['Uncle John'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Charles'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Mrs. Denham']]]

quoteText: That s simply not true,
subQuotationList: ['That s simply not true,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: No. I thought not. But she won t believe me when I say it.
subQuotationList: ['No. I thought not. But she won t believe me when I say it.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: I m not interrupting?
subQuotationList: ['I m not interrupting?']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: She doesn t understand that one s got to take risks,
subQuotationList: ['She doesn t understand that one s got to take risks,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I believe mother would take risks if she knew that Charles was the
sort of boy to profit by it.
subQuotationList: ['I believe mother would take risks if she knew that Charles was the\nsort of boy to profit by it.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: He s got brains, hasn t he?
subQuotationList: ['He s got brains, hasn t he?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
In some ways he s fearfully backward, though, compared with what you
were at his age. And he s difficult at home, too. He makes Molly slave
for him.
subQuotationList: ['In some ways he s fearfully backward, though, compared with what you\nwere at his age. And he s difficult at home, too. He makes Molly slave\nfor him.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: she,
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: It s pretty hard lines to stick a boy into an office at seventeen!
subQuotationList: ['It s pretty hard lines to stick a boy into an office at seventeen!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Nobody _wants_ to stick him into an office,
subQuotationList: ['Nobody _wants_ to stick him into an office,']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
The truth is, that I ought to have accepted
Uncle John s offer. I should have been making six hundred a year by
this time.
subQuotationList: ['The truth is,', 'that I ought to have accepted\nUncle John s offer. I should have been making six hundred a year by\nthis time.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I don t think that for a moment, The question, to my mind, is, whether we couldn t cut
down our expenses in some way.
subQuotationList: ['I don t think that for a moment,', 'The question, to my mind, is, whether we couldn t cut\ndown our expenses in some way.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: A smaller house?
subQuotationList: ['A smaller house?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Fewer servants, perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Fewer servants, perhaps.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: It s out of the question.
subQuotationList: ['It s out of the question.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: If mother won t run risks
subQuotationList: ['If mother won t run risks']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You really can t expect her to sell out again.
subQuotationList: ['You really can t expect her to sell out again.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
She ought to look upon it as an investment; but if she won t, we must
find some other way, that s all.
subQuotationList: ['She ought to look upon it as an investment; but if she won t, we must\nfind some other way, that s all.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I think you d be foolish to risk your money on poor old Charles, Fond as I am of him, he doesn t seem to me exactly
brilliant.... Besides, why should you be sacrificed?
subQuotationList: ['I think you d be foolish to risk your money on poor old Charles,', 'Fond as I am of him, he doesn t seem to me exactly\nbrilliant.... Besides, why should you be sacrificed?']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
My dear Joan, don t you see that we ve all got to be sacrificed?
What s the use of denying it? What s the use of struggling against it?
So it always has been, so it always will be. We ve got no money and we
never shall have any money. We shall just turn round in the mill every
day of our lives until we drop and die, worn out, as most people do,
when one comes to think of it.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Joan,', 'don t you see that we ve all got to be sacrificed?
What s the use of denying it? What s the use of struggling against it?
So it always has been, so it always will be. We ve got no money and we
never shall have any money. We shall just turn round in the mill every
day of our lives until we drop and die, worn out, as most people do,
when one comes to think of it.']

quoteText: Aren t you happy, Ralph?

speaker: Joan

quoteText:
No. Are you? Perhaps I m as happy as most people, though. God knows
whether I m happy or not. What is happiness?
subQuotationList: ['No. Are you? Perhaps I m as happy as most people, though. God knows\nwhether I m happy or not. What is happiness?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Happiness,
subQuotationList: ['Happiness,']

quoteText: Hilda was here to-day, She brought Bobbie he s a fine boy now.
subQuotationList: ['Hilda was here to-day,', 'She brought Bobbie he s a fine boy now.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
Shall you talk to mother? Because, you see, the
thing s got to be settled, one way or another. Charles must write to
Uncle John if he s going there.
subQuotationList: ['Shall you talk to mother?', 'Because, you see, the\nthing s got to be settled, one way or another. Charles must write to\nUncle John if he s going there.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
I suppose it doesn t much matter either way, He s
doomed to misery in the long run.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose it doesn t much matter either way,', 'He s\ndoomed to misery in the long run.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You know you re talking nonsense, It doesn t hurt any one
to have to earn their own living. I m very glad I have to earn mine.
subQuotationList: ['You know you re talking nonsense,', 'It doesn t hurt any one\nto have to earn their own living. I m very glad I have to earn mine.']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
Isn t that only because you ve forgotten how to enjoy yourself? You
never have time for anything decent
subQuotationList: ['Isn t that only because you ve forgotten how to enjoy yourself? You\nnever have time for anything decent']

quoteText: As for instance?
subQuotationList: ['As for instance?']

quoteText:
Well, going for walks, or music, or books, or seeing interesting

do.
subQuotationList: ['Well, going for walks, or music, or books, or seeing interesting\npeople. You never do anything that s really worth doing any more than I\ndo.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I always think you could make this room much nicer, if you liked,
subQuotationList: ['I always think you could make this room much nicer, if you liked,']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
What does it matter what sort of room I have when I m forced to spend

subQuotationList: ['What does it matter what sort of room I have when I m forced to spend\nall the best years of my life drawing up deeds in an office?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You said two days ago that you found the law so interesting.

quoteText: So it is if one could afford to know anything about it.
subQuotationList: ['So it is if one could afford to know anything about it.']

quoteText:
That s Herbert only just going to bed now, And then he won t get up in
the morning.

speaker: Joan

quoteText: D you ever pay calls now?
subQuotationList: ['D you ever pay calls now?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I don t often have the time. Why do you ask?
subQuotationList: ['I don t often have the time. Why do you ask?']
speaker: Joan

quoteText: It might be a good thing, to get to know new people, that s all.
subQuotationList: ['It might be a good thing, to get to know new people, that s all.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Poor Ralph! You think your
sister s getting very old and very dull that s it, isn t it?
subQuotationList: ['Poor Ralph!', 'You think your\nsister s getting very old and very dull that s it, isn t it?']
speaker: Joan

quoteText:
I don t think anything of the kind, But you lead a dog s life, Joan. When you re not working in an office,
you re worrying over the rest of us. And I m not much good to you, I m
afraid.

quoteText:
Well done, Katharine! What a wonderful head for business you ve got!
Now I shall keep this before me, and every day I shall make a little
mark in my pocketbook, and on the last day of all let me think, what
shall we do to celebrate the last day of all? If it weren t the winter
we could take a jaunt to Italy. They say Switzerland s very lovely in
the snow, except for the cold. But, as you say, the great thing is to
finish the book. Now let me see

your wicked old
Uncle Judge Peter, who used to be heard delivering sentence of death in

William Rodney, upon the Elizabethan use of metaphor. I expect a good
solid paper, with plenty of quotations from the classics.
subQuotationList: ['William Rodney, upon the Elizabethan use of metaphor. I expect a good\nsolid paper, with plenty of quotations from the classics.']

I suppose you are the only woman in London who darns her own

quoteText:
I m only one of a great many thousands really, though I

And now that you re here I don t think myself remarkable at all. How

You ve done much more than I ve done.
subQuotationList:

Emerson? You don t mean to say you

 combination,  as you call it, in the houses of the clergy. The only

But, in spite of what you say, I do admire her, I ve only

 personality.

I didn t mean to abuse her. I only felt that she wasn t very

quoteText:
That was a very interesting paper, Will
you lend me the manuscript to read in peace?
subQuotationList: ['That was a very interesting paper,', 'Will\nyou lend me the manuscript to read in peace?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Do you say that merely to disguise the fact of my ridiculous failure?

quoteText:
He says he doesn t mind what we think of him, He says

very pleased with myself.

plain.

quoteText:
I suppose you re one of the people who think we should all have
professions,

quoteText: Oh dear no,

always be able to say that you ve done something, whereas, in a crowd
like this, I feel rather melancholy.

want to assert myself, and it s difficult, if one hasn t a profession.

give there s no use in my giving. Trust me, Katharine, I won t speak of it again. But in the presence of beauty look
at the iridescence round the moon! one feels one feels Perhaps if you
married me I m half a poet, you see, and I can t pretend not to feel
what I do feel. If I could write ah, that would be another matter. I
shouldn t bother you to marry me then, Katharine.

at the iridescence round the moon! one feels one feels Perhaps if you

quoteText: But for me I suppose you would recommend marriage?
subQuotationList: ['But for me I suppose you would recommend marriage?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Certainly I should. Not for you only, but for all women. Why, you re
nothing at all without it; you re only half alive; using only half your
faculties; you must feel that for yourself. That is why
subQuotationList: ['Certainly I should. Not for you only, but for all women. Why, you re\nnothing at all without it; you re only half alive; using only half your\nfaculties; you must feel that for yourself. That is why']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I ve been told a great many unpleasant things about myself to-night, Mr. Denham seems to think
it his mission to lecture me, though I hardly know him. By the way,
William, you know him; tell me, what is he like?

quoteText: We may lecture you till we re blue in the face

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Yes but what s he like?
subQuotationList: ['Yes but what s he like?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
And we write sonnets to your eyebrows, you cruel practical creature.
Denham? A good fellow, I
should think. He cares, naturally, for the right sort of things, I
expect. But you mustn t marry him, though. He scolded you, did he what
did he say?

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText:
What happens with Mr. Denham is this: He comes to tea. I do all I can
to put him at his ease. He merely sits and scowls at me. Then I show
him our manuscripts. At this he becomes really angry, and tells me I ve
no business to call myself a middle-class woman. So we part in a huff;
and next time we meet, which was to-night, he walks straight up to me,
and says,  Go to the Devil!  That s the sort of behavior my mother
complains of. I want to know, what does it mean?
subQuotationList:
['What happens with Mr. Denham is this: He comes to tea. I do all I can
to put him at his ease. He merely sits and scowls at me. Then I show
him our manuscripts. At this he becomes really angry, and tells me I ve

and next time we meet, which was to-night, he walks straight up to me,
and says,  Go to the Devil!  That s the sort of behavior my mother

quoteText: It means, I should say, that he finds you chilly and unsympathetic.
subQuotationList: ['It means, I should say, that he finds you chilly and unsympathetic.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: It s time I jumped into a cab and hid myself in my own house,
subQuotationList: ['It s time I jumped into a cab and hid myself in my own house,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Would your mother object to my being seen with you? No one could
possibly recognize us, could they?
subQuotationList: ['Would your mother object to my being seen with you? No one could\npossibly recognize us, could they?']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
You may laugh, Katharine, but I can tell you that if any of your
friends saw us together at this time of night they would talk about it,
and I should find that very disagreeable. But why do you laugh?
subQuotationList: ['You may laugh, Katharine, but I can tell you that if any of your\nfriends saw us together at this time of night they would talk about it,\nand I should find that very disagreeable. But why do you laugh?']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
I don t know. Because you re such a queer mixture, I think. You re
half poet and half old maid.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know. Because you re such a queer mixture, I think. You re\nhalf poet and half old maid.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I know I always seem to you highly ridiculous. But I can t help having
inherited certain traditions and trying to put them into practice.
subQuotationList: ['I know I always seem to you highly ridiculous. But I can t help having\ninherited certain traditions and trying to put them into practice.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Nonsense, William. You may come of the oldest family in Devonshire,
but that s no reason why you should mind being seen alone with me on
the Embankment.
subQuotationList: ['Nonsense, William. You may come of the oldest family in Devonshire,\nbut that s no reason why you should mind being seen alone with me on\nthe Embankment.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I m ten years older than you are, Katharine, and I know more of the
world than you do.
subQuotationList: ['I m ten years older than you are, Katharine, and I know more of the\nworld than you do.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Very well. Leave me and go home.
subQuotationList: ['Very well. Leave me and go home.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Don t call that cab for me, William. I shall walk.
subQuotationList: ['Don t call that cab for me, William. I shall walk.']

referringExpression: Katharine saw it too and exclaimed

quoteText:
Nonsense, Katharine; you ll do nothing of the kind. It s nearly twelve
o clock, and we ve walked too far as it is.
subQuotationList: ['Nonsense, Katharine; you ll do nothing of the kind. It s nearly twelve\no clock, and we ve walked too far as it is.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Now, William, if people see me racing along the Embankment
like this they _will_ talk. You had far better say good-night, if you
don t want people to talk.
subQuotationList: ['Now, William,', 'if people see me racing along the Embankment\nlike this they _will_ talk. You had far better say good-night, if you\ndon t want people to talk.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Don t let the man see us struggling, for God s sake!
subQuotationList: ['Don t let the man see us struggling, for God s sake!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: There s more of the old maid in you than the poet,
subQuotationList: ['There s more of the old maid in you than the poet,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Of all the unreasonable, inconsiderate creatures I ve ever known,
she s the worst! Heaven forbid that I should ever make a fool of myself
with her again. Why, I d sooner marry the daughter of my landlady than
Katharine Hilbery! She d leave me not a moment s peace and she d never
understand me never, never, never!
subQuotationList:

quoteText: Ha!
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
You do well, Denham, to have nothing to do
with young women. I offer you my experience if one trusts them one
invariably has cause to repent. Not that I have any reason at this
moment, to complain of them. It s a subject that
crops up now and again for no particular reason. Miss Datchet, I dare
say, is one of the exceptions. Do you like Miss Datchet?
subQuotationList:
['You do well, Denham,', 'to have nothing to do
with young women. I offer you my experience if one trusts them one

quoteText: Yes, I like Mary; I don t see how one could help liking her,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I like Mary; I don t see how one could help liking her,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Ah, Denham, you re so different from me. You never give yourself away.
I watched you this evening with Katharine Hilbery. My instinct is to
trust the person I m talking to. That s why I m always being taken in,
I suppose.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, Denham, you re so different from me. You never give yourself away.

quoteText:
Katharine Hilbery, No,
Denham, I have no illusions about that young woman. I think I made that
plain to her to-night. But don t run away with a false impression,
subQuotationList: ['Katharine Hilbery,', 'No,\nDenham, I have no illusions about that young woman. I think I made that\nplain to her to-night. But don t run away with a false impression,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
You must not think that I have any bitterness against her far
from it. It s not altogether her fault, poor girl. She lives, you know,
one of those odious, self-centered lives at least, I think them odious
for a woman feeding her wits upon everything, having control of
everything, getting far too much her own way at home spoilt, in a
sense, feeling that every one is at her feet, and so not realizing how
she hurts that is, how rudely she behaves to people who haven t all her
advantages. Still, to do her justice, she s no fool, She has taste. She has
sense. She can understand you when you talk to her. But she s a woman,
and there s an end of it,
subQuotationList:
['You must not think that I have any bitterness against her far
from it. It s not altogether her fault, poor girl. She lives, you know,

speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Oh dear me, no. I should never think of telling Katharine the truth
about herself. That wouldn t do at all. One has to be in an attitude of
adoration in order to get on with Katharine.

quoteText: You re a slave like me, I suppose?

quoteText: A solicitor, yes.
subQuotationList: ['A solicitor, yes.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I sometimes wonder why we don t chuck it. Why don t you emigrate,
Denham? I should have thought that would suit you.
subQuotationList: ['I sometimes wonder why we don t chuck it. Why don t you emigrate,\nDenham? I should have thought that would suit you.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I ve a family.
subQuotationList: ['I ve a family.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I m often on the point of going myself. And then I know I couldn t
live without this
subQuotationList: ['I m often on the point of going myself. And then I know I couldn t\nlive without this']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
There are one or two people I m fond of, and there s a little good
music, and a few pictures, now and then just enough to keep one
dangling about here. Ah, but I couldn t live with savages! Are you fond
of books? Music? Pictures? D you care at all for first editions? I ve
got a few nice things up here, things I pick up cheap, for I can t
afford to give what they ask.
subQuotationList:
['There are one or two people I m fond of, and there s a little good

speaker: William Rodney

Oh dear me, what a waste of time! But it s over now, and so we may
think no more about it.
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear me, what a waste of time! But it s over now, and so we may\nthink no more about it.']
speaker: William Rodney

The Baskerville Congreve, I
couldn t read him in a cheap edition.
subQuotationList: ['The Baskerville Congreve,', 'I\ncouldn t read him in a cheap edition.']

speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
If you mean that I shouldn t do anything good with leisure if I had

whole day to spend as I liked.
subQuotationList: ['If you mean that I shouldn t do anything good with leisure if I had\nit, I dare say you re right. But I should be ten times as happy with my\nwhole day to spend as I liked.']

subQuotationList: ['I doubt that,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I could spend three hours every day reading Shakespeare, And there s music and pictures, let alone the society of the
people one likes.
subQuotationList: ['I could spend three hours every day reading Shakespeare,', 'And there s music and pictures, let alone the society of the\npeople one likes.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: You d be bored to death in a year s time.

Oh, I grant you I should be bored if I did nothing. But I should write
plays.

quoteText: H m!
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I should write plays, I ve written three-quarters of
one already, and I m only waiting for a holiday to finish it. And it s
not bad no, some of it s really rather nice.

Very
few people care for poetry. I dare say it bores you.

quoteText:
I confess I don t know how you manage it, Miss Datchet, I should sleep all the afternoon, I know, if I took a heavy
meal in the middle of the day.

speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
For, the wonderful thing about you is that
you re ready for anything; you re not in the least conventional, like
most clever men.

quoteText:
No. The S.G.S. top
floor.

No, Mr. Clacton, it s not Penningtons.
I should ring them up again double three double eight, Central. Well,
this is a surprise. Come in, You re just in time for tea.

quoteText:
I m sorry, I m sorry, It s my misfortune to be
an enthusiast, My father s daughter
could hardly be anything else. I think I ve been on as many committees
as most people. Waifs and Strays, Rescue Work, Church Work, C. O.
S. local branch besides the usual civic duties which fall to one as a
householder. But I ve given them all up for our work here, and I don t
regret it for a second, This is the root question, I feel;
until women have votes

speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
She s doing more for the cause than any of us. She s giving her
youth for, alas! when I was young there were domestic circumstances
subQuotationList: ['She s doing more for the cause than any of us. She s giving her\nyouth for, alas! when I was young there were domestic circumstances']
speaker: Mrs. Seal
referringExpression: she remarked rather confidentially to Katharine

quoteText:
Yes, I took my little bag into the square, It
was really very sustaining, and the bare boughs against the sky do one
so much _good_. But I shall have to give up going into the square, The injustice of it! Why should I
have a beautiful square all to myself, when poor women who need rest
have nowhere at all to sit? It s dreadful what a tyrant one still
is, in spite of all one s efforts. One tries to lead a decent life, but
one can t. Of course, directly one thinks of it, one sees that _all_
squares should be open to _every one_. Is there any society with that
object, Mr. Clacton? If not, there should be, surely.
subQuotationList:

was really very sustaining, and the bare boughs against the sky do one

have nowhere at all to sit?', 'It s dreadful what a tyrant one still
