speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
A most excellent object, At the same time, one must deplore the ramification of organizations,
Mrs. Seal. So much excellent effort thrown away, not to speak of
pounds, shillings, and pence. Now how many organizations of a
philanthropic nature do you suppose there are in the City of London
itself, Miss Hilbery?
subQuotationList:
['A most excellent object,', 'At the same time, one must deplore the ramification of organizations,
Mrs. Seal. So much excellent effort thrown away, not to speak of
pounds, shillings, and pence. Now how many organizations of a
philanthropic nature do you suppose there are in the City of London
itself, Miss Hilbery?']
speaker: Mr. Clacton

quoteText:
Well, there are more in this house than I d any notion of, On the ground floor you protect natives, on the next you emigrate
women and tell people to eat nuts
subQuotationList: ['Well, there are more in this house than I d any notion of,', 'On the ground floor you protect natives, on the next you emigrate\nwomen and tell people to eat nuts']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Why do you say that  we  do these things? We re not responsible for all the cranks who choose to lodge
in the same house with us.
subQuotationList: ['Why do you say that  we  do these things?', 'We re not responsible for all the cranks who choose to lodge\nin the same house with us.']
speaker: Mary Datchet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Seal', 'Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton']], [['Mrs. Seal', 'Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mrs. Seal', 'Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton']]]

quoteText: You don t belong to our society, then?
subQuotationList: ['You don t belong to our society, then?']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText: No, I m afraid I don t,
subQuotationList: ['No, I m afraid I don t,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But surely,
subQuotationList: ['But surely,']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
Mrs. Seal is an enthusiast in these matters, We have to remind her sometimes that others have a
right to their views even if they differ from our own.... has a
very funny picture this week, about a Suffragist and an agricultural
laborer. Have you seen this week s Miss Datchet?
subQuotationList:
['Mrs. Seal is an enthusiast in these matters,', 'We have to remind her sometimes that others have a
right to their views even if they differ from our own....', 'has a
very funny picture this week, about a Suffragist and an agricultural
laborer. Have you seen this week s', 'Miss Datchet?']
speaker: Mr. Clacton
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Seal']], [['Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mrs. Seal']], [['Mary Datchet']], [['Mary Datchet']]]

quoteText: No.
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
But surely, if you care about the welfare of your sex at all, you must
wish them to have the vote?
subQuotationList: ['But surely, if you care about the welfare of your sex at all, you must\nwish them to have the vote?']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText: I never said I didn t wish them to have the vote,
subQuotationList: ['I never said I didn t wish them to have the vote,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Then why aren t you a member of our society?
subQuotationList: ['Then why aren t you a member of our society?']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
Are you in any way related, I wonder, to the poet Alardyce? His
daughter, I believe, married a Mr. Hilbery.
subQuotationList: ['Are you in any way related, I wonder, to the poet Alardyce? His\ndaughter, I believe, married a Mr. Hilbery.']
speaker: Mr. Clacton
referringExpression: Mr Clacton meanwhile framed a question which after a moment s hesitation he put to Katharine

quoteText: Yes; I m the poet s granddaughter,
subQuotationList: ['Yes; I m the poet s granddaughter,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: The poet s granddaughter!
subQuotationList: ['The poet s granddaughter!']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
Ah, indeed. That interests me very much, I owe a great debt
to your grandfather, Miss Hilbery. At one time I could have repeated
the greater part of him by heart. But one gets out of the way of
reading poetry, unfortunately. You don t remember him, I suppose?
subQuotationList:
['Ah, indeed. That interests me very much,', 'I owe a great debt
to your grandfather, Miss Hilbery. At one time I could have repeated
the greater part of him by heart. But one gets out of the way of
reading poetry, unfortunately. You don t remember him, I suppose?']
speaker: Mr. Clacton

quoteText: The proofs at last!
subQuotationList: ['The proofs at last!']
speaker: Mrs. Seal
referringExpression: Mrs Seal looked up with renewed hope in her eyes and exclaiming

quoteText: Oh, it s only Mr. Denham!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, it s only Mr. Denham!']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText: Katharine has come to see how one runs an office.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine has come to see how one runs an office.']
speaker: Mary Datchet
referringExpression: Mary at once explained the strange fact of her being there by saying

quoteText: I hope Mary hasn t persuaded you that she knows how to run an office?
subQuotationList: ['I hope Mary hasn t persuaded you that she knows how to run an office?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: What, doesn t she?
subQuotationList: ['What, doesn t she?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Now, I know what you re going to say, Mr. Denham! But it was the day
Kit Markham was here, and she upsets one so with her wonderful
vitality, always thinking of something new that we ought to be doing
and aren t and I was conscious at the time that my dates were mixed. It
had nothing to do with Mary at all, I assure you.
subQuotationList:
['Now, I know what you re going to say, Mr. Denham! But it was the day
Kit Markham was here, and she upsets one so with her wonderful
vitality, always thinking of something new that we ought to be doing
and aren t and I was conscious at the time that my dates were mixed. It
had nothing to do with Mary at all, I assure you.']
speaker: Mrs. Seal
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Miss Markham'], ['Miss Markham'], ['Miss Markham'], ['Mrs. Seal', 'Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText:
My dear Sally, don t apologize, Men are such
pedants they don t know what things matter, and what things don t.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Sally, don t apologize,', 'Men are such\npedants they don t know what things matter, and what things don t.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Now, Denham, speak up for our sex,
subQuotationList: ['Now, Denham, speak up for our sex,']
speaker: Mr. Clacton

quoteText:
Doesn t it seem strange to you, Miss Hilbery, that the
French, with all their wealth of illustrious names, have no poet who
can compare with your grandfather? Let me see. There s Chenier and Hugo
and Alfred de Musset wonderful men, but, at the same time, there s a
richness, a freshness about Alardyce
subQuotationList:
['Doesn t it seem strange to you, Miss Hilbery,', 'that the
French, with all their wealth of illustrious names, have no poet who
can compare with your grandfather? Let me see. There s Chenier and Hugo
and Alfred de Musset wonderful men, but, at the same time, there s a
richness, a freshness about Alardyce']
speaker: Mr. Clacton

quoteText:
For if I were to tell you what I know of back-stairs
intrigue, and what can be done by the power of the purse, you wouldn t
credit me, Mr. Denham, you wouldn t, indeed. Which is why I feel that
the only work for my father s daughter for he was one of the pioneers,
Mr. Denham, and on his tombstone I had that verse from the Psalms put,
about the sowers and the seed.... And what wouldn t I give that he
should be alive now, seeing what we re going to see
subQuotationList:
['For if I were to tell you what I know of back-stairs
intrigue, and what can be done by the power of the purse, you wouldn t
credit me, Mr. Denham, you wouldn t, indeed. Which is why I feel that
the only work for my father s daughter for he was one of the pioneers,
Mr. Denham, and on his tombstone I had that verse from the Psalms put,
about the sowers and the seed.... And what wouldn t I give that he
should be alive now, seeing what we re going to see']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
The standard of morality seems to me frightfully low, especially among women
who aren t well educated. They don t see that small things matter, and
that s where the leakage begins, and then we find ourselves in
difficulties I very nearly lost my temper yesterday,
subQuotationList:
['The standard of morality seems to me frightfully low,', 'especially among women
who aren t well educated. They don t see that small things matter, and
that s where the leakage begins, and then we find ourselves in
difficulties I very nearly lost my temper yesterday,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
It makes me very angry when people tell me
lies doesn t it make you angry?
subQuotationList: ['It makes me very angry when people tell me\nlies doesn t it make you angry?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: But considering that every one tells lies,
subQuotationList: ['But considering that every one tells lies,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t think that I tell lies, and I don t think that Ralph tells
lies, do you, Ralph?
subQuotationList: ['I don t think that I tell lies, and I don t think that Ralph tells\nlies, do you, Ralph?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Mary Datchet does that sort of work very well.... She s responsible
for it, I suppose?
subQuotationList: ['Mary Datchet does that sort of work very well.... She s responsible\nfor it, I suppose?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Yes. The others don t help at all.... Has she made a convert of you?
subQuotationList: ['Yes. The others don t help at all.... Has she made a convert of you?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Oh no. That is, I m a convert already.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no. That is, I m a convert already.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But she hasn t persuaded you to work for them?
subQuotationList: ['But she hasn t persuaded you to work for them?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Oh dear no that wouldn t do at all.
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear no that wouldn t do at all.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Suppose we get on to that omnibus?
subQuotationList: ['Suppose we get on to that omnibus?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But which way are you going?
subQuotationList: ['But which way are you going?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I m going to the Temple,
subQuotationList: ['I m going to the Temple,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
This is like Venice, The motor-cars,
I mean, shooting about so quickly, with their lights.
subQuotationList: ['This is like Venice,', 'The motor-cars,\nI mean, shooting about so quickly, with their lights.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I ve never seen Venice, I keep that and some other
things for my old age.
subQuotationList: ['I ve never seen Venice,', 'I keep that and some other\nthings for my old age.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: What are the other things?
subQuotationList: ['What are the other things?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: There s Venice and India and, I think, Dante, too.
subQuotationList: ['There s Venice and India and, I think, Dante, too.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Think of providing for one s old age! And would you refuse to see
Venice if you had the chance?
subQuotationList: ['Think of providing for one s old age! And would you refuse to see\nVenice if you had the chance?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I ve planned out my life in sections ever since I was a child, to make
it last longer. You see, I m always afraid that I m missing something
subQuotationList: ['I ve planned out my life in sections ever since I was a child, to make\nit last longer. You see, I m always afraid that I m missing something']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: And so am I!
subQuotationList: ['And so am I!']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But, after all, why
should you miss anything?
subQuotationList: ['But, after all,', 'why\nshould you miss anything?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Why? Because I m poor, for one thing, You, I
suppose, can have Venice and India and Dante every day of your life.
subQuotationList: ['Why? Because I m poor, for one thing,', 'You, I\nsuppose, can have Venice and India and Dante every day of your life.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
But to know that one might have things doesn t alter the fact that one
hasn t got them, How could I go to
India, for example? Besides,
subQuotationList: ['But to know that one might have things doesn t alter the fact that one\nhasn t got them,', 'How could I go to\nIndia, for example? Besides,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I have a message to give your father, Perhaps you would
give it him, or I could come
subQuotationList: ['I have a message to give your father,', 'Perhaps you would\ngive it him, or I could come']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Yes, do come,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, do come,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Still, I don t see why you shouldn t go to India,
subQuotationList: ['Still, I don t see why you shouldn t go to India,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: And little Augustus Pelham said to me,
subQuotationList: ['And little Augustus Pelham said to me,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: and I said to him,
subQuotationList: ['and I said to him,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Such a feeble little
joke, wasn t it, but down it went into his notebook all the same."
subQuotationList: ['Such a feeble little\njoke, wasn t it, but down it went into his notebook all the same."']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Let us congratulate ourselves that we shall be in the grave before
that work is published,
subQuotationList: ['Let us congratulate ourselves that we shall be in the grave before\nthat work is published,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
The only excuse for you, Katharine, is that dinner is still later than
you are,
subQuotationList: ['The only excuse for you, Katharine, is that dinner is still later than\nyou are,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t mind her being late when the result is so charming, Still, I don t know that
I _like_ your being out so late, Katharine, You took a
cab, I hope?
subQuotationList: ['I don t mind her being late when the result is so charming,', 'Still, I don t know that\nI _like_ your being out so late, Katharine,', 'You took a\ncab, I hope?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
That s more cheerful, D you know, Katharine, that
ridiculous goose came to tea with me? Oh, how I wanted you! He tried to
make epigrams all the time, and I got so nervous, expecting them, you
know, that I spilt the tea and he made an epigram about that!
subQuotationList:
['That s more cheerful,', 'D you know, Katharine, that
ridiculous goose came to tea with me? Oh, how I wanted you! He tried to
make epigrams all the time, and I got so nervous, expecting them, you
know, that I spilt the tea and he made an epigram about that!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Augustus Pelham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Augustus Pelham'], ['Augustus Pelham']]]

quoteText: Which ridiculous goose?
subQuotationList: ['Which ridiculous goose?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Only one of my geese, happily, makes epigrams Augustus Pelham, of
course,
subQuotationList: ['Only one of my geese, happily, makes epigrams Augustus Pelham, of\ncourse,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: I m not sorry that I was out,
subQuotationList: ['I m not sorry that I was out,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Poor Augustus! But we re all too hard on
him. Remember how devoted he is to his tiresome old mother.
subQuotationList: ['Poor Augustus!', 'But we re all too hard on\nhim. Remember how devoted he is to his tiresome old mother.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Augustus Pelham']], [['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Augustus Pelham'], ['Augustus Pelham'], ['Augustus Pelham']]]

quoteText:
That s only because she is his mother. Any one connected with
himself
subQuotationList: ['That s only because she is his mother. Any one connected with\nhimself']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No, no, Katharine that s too bad. That s what s the word I mean,
Trevor, something long and Latin the sort of word you and Katharine
know
subQuotationList: ['No, no, Katharine that s too bad. That s what s the word I mean,\nTrevor, something long and Latin the sort of word you and Katharine\nknow']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: cynical.
subQuotationList: ['cynical.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Well, that ll do. I don t believe in sending girls to college, but I
should teach them that sort of thing. It makes one feel so dignified,
bringing out these little allusions, and passing on gracefully to the
next topic. But I don t know what s come over me I actually had to ask
Augustus the name of the lady Hamlet was in love with, as you were out,
Katharine, and Heaven knows what he mayn t put down about me in his
diary.
subQuotationList:
['Well, that ll do. I don t believe in sending girls to college, but I
should teach them that sort of thing. It makes one feel so dignified,
bringing out these little allusions, and passing on gracefully to the
next topic. But I don t know what s come over me I actually had to ask
Augustus the name of the lady Hamlet was in love with, as you were out,
Katharine, and Heaven knows what he mayn t put down about me in his
diary.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: I wish,
subQuotationList: ['I wish,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: What is it you wish?
subQuotationList: ['What is it you wish?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
I wish mother wasn t famous. I was out at tea, and they would talk to
me about poetry.
subQuotationList: ['I wish mother wasn t famous. I was out at tea, and they would talk to\nme about poetry.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Thinking you must be poetical, I see and aren t you?
subQuotationList: ['Thinking you must be poetical, I see and aren t you?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Who s been talking to you about poetry, Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['Who s been talking to you about poetry, Katharine?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
They have an office at the top of one of the old houses in Russell
Square. I never saw such queer-looking people. And the man discovered I
was related to the poet, and talked to me about poetry. Even Mary
Datchet seems different in that atmosphere.
subQuotationList:
['They have an office at the top of one of the old houses in Russell
Square. I never saw such queer-looking people. And the man discovered I
was related to the poet, and talked to me about poetry. Even Mary
Datchet seems different in that atmosphere.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Yes, the office atmosphere is very bad for the soul,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, the office atmosphere is very bad for the soul,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t remember any offices in Russell Square in the old days, when
Mamma lived there, and I can t fancy turning one
of those noble great rooms into a stuffy little Suffrage office. Still,
if the clerks read poetry there must be something nice about them.
subQuotationList:
['I don t remember any offices in Russell Square in the old days, when
Mamma lived there,', 'and I can t fancy turning one
of those noble great rooms into a stuffy little Suffrage office. Still,
if the clerks read poetry there must be something nice about them.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: No, because they don t read it as we read it,
subQuotationList: ['No, because they don t read it as we read it,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Seal', 'Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
But it s nice to think of them reading your grandfather, and not
filling up those dreadful little forms all day long,
subQuotationList: ['But it s nice to think of them reading your grandfather, and not\nfilling up those dreadful little forms all day long,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
At any rate, they haven t made a convert of Katharine, which was what
I was afraid of,
subQuotationList: ['At any rate, they haven t made a convert of Katharine, which was what\nI was afraid of,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Oh no, I wouldn t work with them for
anything.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no,', 'I wouldn t work with them for\nanything.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
It s curious, how
the sight of one s fellow-enthusiasts always chokes one off. They show
up the faults of one s cause so much more plainly than one s
antagonists. One can be enthusiastic in one s study, but directly one
comes into touch with the people who agree with one, all the glamor
goes. So I ve always found,
subQuotationList:
['It s curious,', 'how
the sight of one s fellow-enthusiasts always chokes one off. They show
up the faults of one s cause so much more plainly than one s
antagonists. One can be enthusiastic in one s study, but directly one
comes into touch with the people who agree with one, all the glamor
goes. So I ve always found,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Oh, Katharine, how you ve made me think of Mamma and
the old days in Russell Square! I can see the chandeliers, and the
green silk of the piano, and Mamma sitting in her cashmere shawl by the
window, singing till the little ragamuffin boys outside stopped to
listen. Papa sent me in with a bunch of violets while he waited round
the corner. It must have been a summer evening. That was before things
were hopeless....
subQuotationList:
['Oh, Katharine,', 'how you ve made me think of Mamma and
the old days in Russell Square! I can see the chandeliers, and the
green silk of the piano, and Mamma sitting in her cashmere shawl by the
window, singing till the little ragamuffin boys outside stopped to
listen. Papa sent me in with a bunch of violets while he waited round
the corner. It must have been a summer evening. That was before things
were hopeless....']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
If they d lived now, I feel it wouldn t have
happened. People aren t so set upon tragedy as they were then. If my
father had been able to go round the world, or if she d had a rest
cure, everything would have come right. But what could I do? And then
they had bad friends, both of them, who made mischief. Ah, Katharine,
when you marry, be quite, quite sure that you love your husband!
subQuotationList:
['If they d lived now,', 'I feel it wouldn t have
happened. People aren t so set upon tragedy as they were then. If my
father had been able to go round the world, or if she d had a rest
cure, everything would have come right. But what could I do? And then
they had bad friends, both of them, who made mischief. Ah, Katharine,
when you marry, be quite, quite sure that you love your husband!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Richard Alardyce']], [['Richard Alardyce'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
Now this is what
Mary Datchet and Mr. Denham don t understand. This is the sort of
position I m always getting into. How simple it must be to live as they
do!
subQuotationList:
['Now this is what
Mary Datchet and Mr. Denham don t understand. This is the sort of
position I m always getting into. How simple it must be to live as they
do!']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But, Katharine, though, Heaven knows, I don t want to see you
married, surely if ever a man loved a woman, William loves you. And
it s a nice, rich-sounding name too Katharine Rodney, which,
unfortunately, doesn t mean that he s got any money, because he
hasn t.
subQuotationList:
['But, Katharine,', 'though, Heaven knows, I don t want to see you
married, surely if ever a man loved a woman, William loves you. And
it s a nice, rich-sounding name too Katharine Rodney, which,
unfortunately, doesn t mean that he s got any money, because he
hasn t.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney']]]

quoteText:
It s very dull that you can only marry one husband, certainly, I always wish that you could marry everybody who
wants to marry you. Perhaps they ll come to that in time, but meanwhile
I confess that dear William
subQuotationList: ['It s very dull that you can only marry one husband, certainly,', 'I always wish that you could marry everybody who\nwants to marry you. Perhaps they ll come to that in time, but meanwhile\nI confess that dear William']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: Please, Katharine, read us something _real_.
subQuotationList: ['Please, Katharine, read us something _real_.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: What would Ralph Denham say to this?
subQuotationList: ['What would Ralph Denham say to this?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: What would Mary Datchet and Ralph Denham say?
subQuotationList: ['What would Mary Datchet and Ralph Denham say?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I ve had a letter from Aunt Celia about Cyril, father.... It seems to
be true about his marriage. What are we to do?
subQuotationList: ['I ve had a letter from Aunt Celia about Cyril, father.... It seems to\nbe true about his marriage. What are we to do?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Cyril seems to have been behaving in a very foolish manner,
subQuotationList: ['Cyril seems to have been behaving in a very foolish manner,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: He s about done for himself, I should say,
subQuotationList: ['He s about done for himself, I should say,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Humph!
subQuotationList: ['Humph!']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Mother knows nothing about it, Will you tell
her?
subQuotationList: ['Mother knows nothing about it,', 'Will you tell\nher?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I shall tell your mother. But I shall tell her that there is nothing
whatever for us to do.
subQuotationList: ['I shall tell your mother. But I shall tell her that there is nothing\nwhatever for us to do.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: But the marriage?
subQuotationList: ['But the marriage?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: What in the name of conscience did he do it for?
subQuotationList: ['What in the name of conscience did he do it for?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Well, if the younger generation want to carry on its life on those
lines, it s none of our affair,
subQuotationList: ['Well, if the younger generation want to carry on its life on those\nlines, it s none of our affair,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: But isn t it our affair, perhaps, to make them get married?
subQuotationList: ['But isn t it our affair, perhaps, to make them get married?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Why the dickens should they apply to me?
subQuotationList: ['Why the dickens should they apply to me?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Only as the head of the family
subQuotationList: ['Only as the head of the family']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But I m not the head of the family. Alfred s the head of the family.
Let them apply to Alfred,
subQuotationList: ['But I m not the head of the family. Alfred s the head of the family.\nLet them apply to Alfred,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: I think, perhaps, the best thing would be for me to go and see them,
subQuotationList: ['I think, perhaps, the best thing would be for me to go and see them,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I won t have you going anywhere near them, Indeed, I don t understand why
they ve dragged you into the business at all I don t see that it s got
anything to do with you.
subQuotationList: ['I won t have you going anywhere near them,', 'Indeed, I don t understand why\nthey ve dragged you into the business at all I don t see that it s got\nanything to do with you.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: I ve always been friends with Cyril,
subQuotationList: ['I ve always been friends with Cyril,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But did he ever tell you anything about this?
subQuotationList: ['But did he ever tell you anything about this?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
As to your mother, you had better tell
her the facts. She d better know the facts before every one begins to
talk about it, though why Aunt Celia thinks it necessary to come, I m
sure I don t know. And the less talk there is the better.
subQuotationList:
['As to your mother,', 'you had better tell
her the facts. She d better know the facts before every one begins to
talk about it, though why Aunt Celia thinks it necessary to come, I m
sure I don t know. And the less talk there is the better.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Have you told mother?
subQuotationList: ['Have you told mother?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: My dear child, it went out of my head.
subQuotationList: ['My dear child, it went out of my head.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
I ll send a note
round from the office.... I m late this morning, and I ve any amount of
proofs to get through.
subQuotationList: ['I ll send a note\nround from the office.... I m late this morning, and I ve any amount of\nproofs to get through.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
That wouldn t do at all, She must be
told you or I must tell her. We ought to have told her at first.
subQuotationList: ['That wouldn t do at all,', 'She must be\ntold you or I must tell her. We ought to have told her at first.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
Katharine, I ve just made out such
a queer, strange thing about your grandfather. I m three years and six
months older than he was when he died. I couldn t very well have been
his mother, but I might have been his elder sister, and that seems to
me such a pleasant fancy. I m going to start quite fresh this morning,
and get a lot done.
subQuotationList:
['Katharine,', 'I ve just made out such
a queer, strange thing about your grandfather. I m three years and six
months older than he was when he died. I couldn t very well have been
his mother, but I might have been his elder sister, and that seems to
me such a pleasant fancy. I m going to start quite fresh this morning,
and get a lot done.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
I really believe I m bewitched! I only want three sentences, you see,
something quite straightforward and commonplace, and I can t find  em.
subQuotationList: ['I really believe I m bewitched! I only want three sentences, you see,\nsomething quite straightforward and commonplace, and I can t find  em.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
referringExpression: Mrs Hilbery turned abruptly and exclaimed

quoteText:
Besides, I
don t believe this ll do. Did your grandfather ever visit the Hebrides,
Katharine? My mind got running on the Hebrides, and I couldn t help writing a
little description of them. Perhaps it would do at the beginning of a
chapter. Chapters often begin quite differently from the way they go
on, you know.
subQuotationList:
['Besides,', 'I
don t believe this ll do. Did your grandfather ever visit the Hebrides,
Katharine?', 'My mind got running on the Hebrides, and I couldn t help writing a
little description of them. Perhaps it would do at the beginning of a
chapter. Chapters often begin quite differently from the way they go
on, you know.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
It s very beautiful, but, you see, mother, we ought to
go from point to point
subQuotationList: ['It s very beautiful,', 'but, you see, mother, we ought to\ngo from point to point']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Oh, I know, And that s just what I can t do.
Things keep coming into my head. It isn t that I don t know everything
and feel everything (who did know him, if I didn t?), but I can t put
it down, you see. There s a kind of blind spot, there. And when I can t sleep o  nights, I fancy I shall die
without having done it.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, I know,', 'And that s just what I can t do.
Things keep coming into my head. It isn t that I don t know everything
and feel everything (who did know him, if I didn t?), but I can t put
it down, you see. There s a kind of blind spot,', 'there. And when I can t sleep o  nights, I fancy I shall die
without having done it.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Surely, Katharine, the men were far handsomer in those
days than they are now, in spite of their odious whiskers? Look at old
John Graham, in his white waistcoat look at Uncle Harley. That s Peter
the manservant, I suppose. Uncle John brought him back from India.
subQuotationList:
['Surely, Katharine,', 'the men were far handsomer in those
days than they are now, in spite of their odious whiskers? Look at old
John Graham, in his white waistcoat look at Uncle Harley. That s Peter
the manservant, I suppose. Uncle John brought him back from India.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
What is nobler, than to be
a woman to whom every one turns, in sorrow or difficulty? How have the
young women of your generation improved upon that, Katharine? I can see
them now, sweeping over the lawns at Melbury House, in their flounces
and furbelows, so calm and stately and imperial (and the monkey and the
little black dwarf following behind), as if nothing mattered in the
world but to be beautiful and kind. But they did more than we do, I
sometimes think. They WERE, and that s better than doing. They seem to
me like ships, like majestic ships, holding on their way, not shoving
or pushing, not fretted by little things, as we are, but taking their
way, like ships with white sails.
subQuotationList:
['What is nobler,', 'than to be
a woman to whom every one turns, in sorrow or difficulty? How have the
young women of your generation improved upon that, Katharine? I can see
them now, sweeping over the lawns at Melbury House, in their flounces
and furbelows, so calm and stately and imperial (and the monkey and the
little black dwarf following behind), as if nothing mattered in the
world but to be beautiful and kind. But they did more than we do, I
sometimes think. They WERE, and that s better than doing. They seem to
me like ships, like majestic ships, holding on their way, not shoving
or pushing, not fretted by little things, as we are, but taking their
way, like ships with white sails.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
That s Janie Mannering, I must have told
you how she found her cook drunk under the kitchen table when the
Empress was coming to dinner, and tucked up her velvet sleeves (she
always dressed like an Empress herself), cooked the whole meal, and
appeared in the drawing-room as if she d been sleeping on a bank of
roses all day. She could do anything with her hands they all could make
a cottage or embroider a petticoat.
subQuotationList:
['That s Janie Mannering,', 'I must have told
you how she found her cook drunk under the kitchen table when the
Empress was coming to dinner, and tucked up her velvet sleeves (she
always dressed like an Empress herself), cooked the whole meal, and
appeared in the drawing-room as if she d been sleeping on a bank of
roses all day. She could do anything with her hands they all could make
a cottage or embroider a petticoat.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
And that s Queenie Colquhoun, who
took her coffin out with her to Jamaica, packed with lovely shawls and
bonnets, because you couldn t get coffins in Jamaica, and she had a
horror of dying there (as she did), and being devoured by the white
ants. And there s Sabine, the loveliest of them all; ah! it was like a
star rising when she came into the room. And that s Miriam, in her
coachman s cloak, with all the little capes on, and she wore great
top-boots underneath. You young people may say you re unconventional,
but you re nothing compared with her.
subQuotationList:
['And that s Queenie Colquhoun,', 'who
took her coffin out with her to Jamaica, packed with lovely shawls and
bonnets, because you couldn t get coffins in Jamaica, and she had a
horror of dying there (as she did), and being devoured by the white
ants. And there s Sabine, the loveliest of them all; ah! it was like a
star rising when she came into the room. And that s Miriam, in her
coachman s cloak, with all the little capes on, and she wore great
top-boots underneath. You young people may say you re unconventional,
but you re nothing compared with her.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Ah, you wretch! what a wicked old despot you
were, in your day! How we all bowed down before you!  Maggie,  she used
to say,  if it hadn t been for me, where would you be now?  And it was
true; she brought them together, you know. She said to my father,
 Marry her,  and he did; and she said to poor little Clara,  Fall down
and worship him,  and she did; but she got up again, of course. What
else could one expect? She was a mere child eighteen and half dead with
fright, too. But that old tyrant never repented. She used to say that
she had given them three perfect months, and no one had a right to
more; and I sometimes think, Katharine, that s true, you know. It s
more than most of us have, only we have to pretend, which was a thing
neither of them could ever do. I fancy, that
there was a kind of sincerity in those days between men and women
which, with all your outspokenness, you haven t got.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, you wretch!', 'what a wicked old despot you
were, in your day! How we all bowed down before you!  Maggie,  she used
to say,  if it hadn t been for me, where would you be now?  And it was
true; she brought them together, you know. She said to my father,
 Marry her,  and he did; and she said to poor little Clara,  Fall down
and worship him,  and she did; but she got up again, of course. What
else could one expect? She was a mere child eighteen and half dead with
fright, too. But that old tyrant never repented. She used to say that
she had given them three perfect months, and no one had a right to
more; and I sometimes think, Katharine, that s true, you know. It s
more than most of us have, only we have to pretend, which was a thing
neither of them could ever do. I fancy,', 'that
there was a kind of sincerity in those days between men and women
which, with all your outspokenness, you haven t got.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
They must have been good friends at heart, because she
used to sing his songs. Ah, how did it go?
subQuotationList: ['They must have been good friends at heart,', 'because she\nused to sing his songs. Ah, how did it go?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
It s the vitality of them! That s what we haven t got! We re virtuous, we re earnest,
we go to meetings, we pay the poor their wages, but we don t live as
they lived. As often as not, my father wasn t in bed three nights out
of the seven, but always fresh as paint in the morning. I hear him now,
come singing up the stairs to the nursery, and tossing the loaf for
breakfast on his sword-stick, and then off we went for a day s
pleasuring Richmond, Hampton Court, the Surrey Hills. Why shouldn t we
go, Katharine? It s going to be a fine day.
subQuotationList:
['It s the vitality of them!', 'That s what we haven t got! We re virtuous, we re earnest,
we go to meetings, we pay the poor their wages, but we don t live as
they lived. As often as not, my father wasn t in bed three nights out
of the seven, but always fresh as paint in the morning. I hear him now,
come singing up the stairs to the nursery, and tossing the loaf for
breakfast on his sword-stick, and then off we went for a day s
pleasuring Richmond, Hampton Court, the Surrey Hills. Why shouldn t we
go, Katharine? It s going to be a fine day.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Aunt
Celia!
subQuotationList: ['Aunt\nCelia!']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I think Aunt Celia has come to talk about Cyril, mother, Aunt Celia has discovered that Cyril is married. He
has a wife and children.
subQuotationList: ['I think Aunt Celia has come to talk about Cyril, mother,', 'Aunt Celia has discovered that Cyril is married. He\nhas a wife and children.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No, he is _not_ married, He has two children, and another
on the way.
subQuotationList: ['No, he is _not_ married,', 'He has two children, and another\non the way.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
referringExpression: Mrs Milvain interposed in low tones addressing herself to Mrs Hilbery

quoteText: We thought it better to wait until it was proved before we told you,
subQuotationList: ['We thought it better to wait until it was proved before we told you,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But I met Cyril only a fortnight ago at the National Gallery! I don t believe a word of it,
subQuotationList: ['But I met Cyril only a fortnight ago at the National Gallery!', 'I don t believe a word of it,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
I didn t _wish_ to believe it, Maggie, For a long
time I _couldn t_ believe it. But now I ve seen, and I _have_ to
believe it.
subQuotationList: ['I didn t _wish_ to believe it, Maggie,', 'For a long\ntime I _couldn t_ believe it. But now I ve seen, and I _have_ to\nbelieve it.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: Katharine, does your father know of this?
subQuotationList: ['Katharine,', 'does your father know of this?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Cyril married! And never telling us a word,
though we ve had him in our house since he was a child noble William s
son! I can t believe my ears!
subQuotationList: ['Cyril married!', 'And never telling us a word,\nthough we ve had him in our house since he was a child noble William s\nson! I can t believe my ears!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cyril']], [['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Cyril'], ['Cyril'], ['William Rodney']]]

quoteText:
I have suspected for some time that he was not happy. There were new
lines on his face. So I went to his rooms, when I knew he was engaged
at the poor men s college. He lectures there Roman law, you know, or it
may be Greek. The landlady said Mr. Alardyce only slept there about
once a fortnight now. He looked so ill, she said. She had seen him with
a young person. I suspected something directly. I went to his room, and
there was an envelope on the mantelpiece, and a letter with an address
in Seton Street, off the Kennington Road.
subQuotationList:
['I have suspected for some time that he was not happy. There were new
lines on his face. So I went to his rooms, when I knew he was engaged
at the poor men s college. He lectures there Roman law, you know, or it
may be Greek. The landlady said Mr. Alardyce only slept there about
once a fortnight now. He looked so ill, she said. She had seen him with
a young person. I suspected something directly. I went to his room, and
there was an envelope on the mantelpiece, and a letter with an address
in Seton Street, off the Kennington Road.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
I went to Seton Street, A very low
place lodging-houses, you know, with canaries in the window. Number
seven just like all the others. I rang, I knocked; no one came. I went
down the area. I am certain I saw some one inside children a cradle.
But no reply no reply.
subQuotationList:
['I went to Seton Street,', 'A very low
place lodging-houses, you know, with canaries in the window. Number
seven just like all the others. I rang, I knocked; no one came. I went
down the area. I am certain I saw some one inside children a cradle.
But no reply no reply.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
I stood in the street, in case I could catch a sight of
one of them. It seemed a very long time. There were rough men singing
in the public-house round the corner. At last the door opened, and some
one it must have been the woman herself came right past me. There was
only the pillar-box between us.
subQuotationList:
['I stood in the street,', 'in case I could catch a sight of
one of them. It seemed a very long time. There were rough men singing
in the public-house round the corner. At last the door opened, and some
one it must have been the woman herself came right past me. There was
only the pillar-box between us.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: And what did she look like?
subQuotationList: ['And what did she look like?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: One could see how the poor boy had been deluded,
subQuotationList: ['One could see how the poor boy had been deluded,']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: Poor thing!
subQuotationList: ['Poor thing!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: Poor Cyril!
subQuotationList: ['Poor Cyril!']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
But they ve got nothing to live upon, If
he d come to us like a man, and said,  I ve been a
fool,  one would have pitied him; one would have tried to help him.
There s nothing so disgraceful after all But he s been going about all
these years, pretending, letting one take it for granted, that he was
single. And the poor deserted little wife
subQuotationList:
['But they ve got nothing to live upon,', 'If
he d come to us like a man,', 'and said,  I ve been a
fool,  one would have pitied him; one would have tried to help him.
There s nothing so disgraceful after all But he s been going about all
these years, pretending, letting one take it for granted, that he was
single. And the poor deserted little wife']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: She is _not_ his wife,
subQuotationList: ['She is _not_ his wife,']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: I ve never heard anything so detestable!
subQuotationList: ['I ve never heard anything so detestable!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: We must realize Cyril s point of view first,
subQuotationList: ['We must realize Cyril s point of view first,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
This unhappy business, If the
train had not gone out of the station just as I arrived, I should have
been with you before. Celia has doubtless told you. You will agree with
me, Maggie. He must be made to marry her at once for the sake of the
children
subQuotationList:
['This unhappy business,', 'If the
train had not gone out of the station just as I arrived, I should have
been with you before. Celia has doubtless told you. You will agree with
me, Maggie. He must be made to marry her at once for the sake of the
children']
speaker: Cousin Caroline

quoteText: But does he refuse to marry her?
subQuotationList: ['But does he refuse to marry her?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
He has written an absurd perverted letter, all quotations, He thinks he s doing a very fine thing, where we only
see the folly of it.... The girl s every bit as infatuated as he is for
which I blame him.
subQuotationList: ['He has written an absurd perverted letter, all quotations,', 'He thinks he s doing a very fine thing, where we only\nsee the folly of it.... The girl s every bit as infatuated as he is for\nwhich I blame him.']
speaker: Cousin Caroline

quoteText: She entangled him,
subQuotationList: ['She entangled him,']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
It s no use going into the rights and wrongs of the affair now,
Celia, The
mischief s done, and very ugly mischief too. Are we to allow the third
child to be born out of wedlock? (I am sorry to have to say these
things before you, Katharine.) He will bear your name, Maggie your
father s name, remember.
subQuotationList:
['It s no use going into the rights and wrongs of the affair now,
Celia,', 'The
mischief s done, and very ugly mischief too. Are we to allow the third
child to be born out of wedlock? (I am sorry to have to say these
things before you, Katharine.) He will bear your name, Maggie your
father s name, remember.']
speaker: Cousin Caroline
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Milvain']], [['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Milvain', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cyril'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery']]]

quoteText: But let us hope it will be a girl,
subQuotationList: ['But let us hope it will be a girl,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: It s detestable quite detestable!
subQuotationList: ['It s detestable quite detestable!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Nowadays, people don t think so
badly of these things as they used to do, It will be
horribly uncomfortable for them sometimes, but if they are brave,
clever children, as they will be, I dare say it ll make remarkable
people of them in the end. Robert Browning used to say that every great
man has Jewish blood in him, and we must try to look at it in that
light. And, after all, Cyril has acted on principle. One may disagree
with his principle, but, at least, one can respect it like the French
Revolution, or Cromwell cutting the King s head off. Some of the most
terrible things in history have been done on principle,
subQuotationList:
['Nowadays, people don t think so
badly of these things as they used to do,', 'It will be
horribly uncomfortable for them sometimes, but if they are brave,
clever children, as they will be, I dare say it ll make remarkable
people of them in the end. Robert Browning used to say that every great
man has Jewish blood in him, and we must try to look at it in that
light. And, after all, Cyril has acted on principle. One may disagree
with his principle, but, at least, one can respect it like the French
Revolution, or Cromwell cutting the King s head off. Some of the most
terrible things in history have been done on principle,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: I m afraid I take a very different view of principle,
subQuotationList: ['I m afraid I take a very different view of principle,']
speaker: Cousin Caroline

quoteText: Principle! I will go to-morrow and see him,
subQuotationList: ['Principle!', 'I will go to-morrow and see him,']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
But why should you take these disagreeable things upon yourself,
Celia?
subQuotationList: ['But why should you take these disagreeable things upon yourself,\nCelia?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
It s life that matters, nothing
but life the process of discovering the everlasting and perpetual
process, not the discovery itself at all.
subQuotationList: ['It s life that matters, nothing\nbut life the process of discovering the everlasting and perpetual\nprocess, not the discovery itself at all.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: She did not see him and went on repeating to herself

quoteText:
Now, I m not going
to let these silly ideas come into my head....
subQuotationList: ['Now,', 'I m not going\nto let these silly ideas come into my head....']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Don t you think Mr.
Asquith deserves to be hanged?
subQuotationList: ['Don t you think Mr.\nAsquith deserves to be hanged?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
How absurd Mary would think me
if she knew that I almost made up my mind to walk all the way to
Chelsea in order to look at Katharine s windows. She wouldn t
understand it, but I like her very much as she is. Here, is where we differ from women; they have
no sense of romance.
subQuotationList:
['How absurd Mary would think me
if she knew that I almost made up my mind to walk all the way to
Chelsea in order to look at Katharine s windows. She wouldn t
understand it, but I like her very much as she is.', 'Here,', 'is where we differ from women; they have
no sense of romance.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Well, Mary, why don t you say something amusing?
subQuotationList: ['Well, Mary,', 'why don t you say something amusing?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Because I ve got nothing amusing to say, I suppose.
subQuotationList: ['Because I ve got nothing amusing to say, I suppose.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You work too hard. I don t mean your health, I mean that you seem to me to be getting wrapped up in
your work.
subQuotationList: ['You work too hard. I don t mean your health,', 'I mean that you seem to me to be getting wrapped up in\nyour work.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: Ralph thought for a moment and then remarked

quoteText: And is that a bad thing?
subQuotationList: ['And is that a bad thing?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: I think it is,
subQuotationList: ['I think it is,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But only a week ago you were saying the opposite.
subQuotationList: ['But only a week ago you were saying the opposite.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You don t read enough, Mary, You ought to read more
poetry.
subQuotationList: ['You don t read enough, Mary,', 'You ought to read more\npoetry.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I m behaving
exactly as I said I wouldn t behave,
subQuotationList: ['I m behaving\nexactly as I said I wouldn t behave,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Tell me what I ought to read, then.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me what I ought to read, then.']
speaker: Mary Datchet
referringExpression: she relaxed all her muscles and said

quoteText: You live with your inferiors,
subQuotationList: ['You live with your inferiors,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
And you get into a groove because, on the whole,
it s rather a pleasant groove. And you tend to forget what you re there
for. You ve the feminine habit of making much of details. You don t see
when things matter and when they don t. And that s what s the ruin of
all these organizations. That s why the Suffragists have never done
anything all these years. What s the point of drawing-room meetings and
bazaars? You want to have ideas, Mary; get hold of something big; never
mind making mistakes, but don t niggle. Why don t you throw it all up
for a year, and travel? see something of the world. Don t be content to
live with half a dozen people in a backwater all your life. But you
won t,
subQuotationList:
['And you get into a groove because, on the whole,
it s rather a pleasant groove. And you tend to forget what you re there
for. You ve the feminine habit of making much of details. You don t see

won t,']
speaker: Ralph Denham
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet']]]

quoteText:
I ve rather come to that way of thinking myself about myself, I mean, I should like to go
somewhere far away.
subQuotationList: ['I ve rather come to that way of thinking myself about myself, I mean,', 'I should like to go\nsomewhere far away.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
But look here, Mary, you haven t been taking this seriously, have
you?
subQuotationList: ['But look here, Mary, you haven t been taking this seriously, have\nyou?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You won t go away, will you? Oh no, don t go away.
subQuotationList: ['You won t go away, will you?', 'Oh no, don t go away.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I don t know exactly what I mean to do,
subQuotationList: ['I don t know exactly what I mean to do,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
It s life that matters, nothing but life the process of discovering,
the everlasting and perpetual process, not the discovery itself at all.
subQuotationList: ['It s life that matters, nothing but life the process of discovering,\nthe everlasting and perpetual process,', 'not the discovery itself at all.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Well, William, I m afraid I m late.
subQuotationList: ['Well, William,', 'I m afraid I m late.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
My oysters! I had a basket, and I ve left it
somewhere. Uncle Dudley dines with us to-night. What in the world have
I done with them?
subQuotationList: ['My oysters! I had a basket,', 'and I ve left it\nsomewhere. Uncle Dudley dines with us to-night. What in the world have\nI done with them?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Oysters, oysters your basket of
oysters!
subQuotationList: ['Oysters, oysters your basket of\noysters!']
speaker: William Rodney
referringExpression: William rose also and stood in front of the fire muttering

quoteText:
I had them, in the Strand; I sat on a seat. Well,
never mind, I
dare say some old creature is enjoying them by this time.
subQuotationList: ['I had them,', 'in the Strand; I sat on a seat. Well,\nnever mind,', 'I\ndare say some old creature is enjoying them by this time.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I should have thought that you never forgot anything,
subQuotationList: ['I should have thought that you never forgot anything,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: That s part of the myth about me, I know,
subQuotationList: ['That s part of the myth about me, I know,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
And I wonder, what the truth
about you is? But I know this sort of thing doesn t interest you,
subQuotationList: ['And I wonder,', 'what the truth\nabout you is? But I know this sort of thing doesn t interest you,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: No; it doesn t interest me very much,
subQuotationList: ['No; it doesn t interest me very much,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: What shall we talk about then?
subQuotationList: ['What shall we talk about then?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
However we start, we end by talking about the same thing about poetry,
I mean. I wonder if you realize, William, that I ve never read even
Shakespeare? It s rather wonderful how I ve kept it up all these
years.
subQuotationList:
['However we start, we end by talking about the same thing about poetry,
I mean. I wonder if you realize, William, that I ve never read even
Shakespeare? It s rather wonderful how I ve kept it up all these
years.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You ve kept it up for ten years very beautifully, as far as I m
concerned,
subQuotationList: ['You ve kept it up for ten years very beautifully, as far as I m\nconcerned,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Ten years? So long as that?
subQuotationList: ['Ten years? So long as that?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And I don t think it s always bored you,
subQuotationList: ['And I don t think it s always bored you,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
You may say you don t read books, but, all the same,
you know about them. Besides, who wants you to be learned? Leave that
to the poor devils who ve got nothing better to do. You you ahem!
subQuotationList: ['You may say you don t read books,', 'but, all the same,\nyou know about them. Besides, who wants you to be learned? Leave that\nto the poor devils who ve got nothing better to do. You you ahem!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Well, then, why don t you read me something before I go?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, why don t you read me something before I go?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Katharine, you ve only just come! Let me see now, what have I got to
show you?
subQuotationList: ['Katharine, you ve only just come! Let me see now, what have I got to\nshow you?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I believe you only ask me to read out of kindness, Let s find something else to talk about. Who have you been seeing?
subQuotationList: ['I believe you only ask me to read out of kindness,', 'Let s find something else to talk about. Who have you been seeing?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I don t generally ask things out of kindness, however, if you don t want to read, you needn t.
subQuotationList: ['I don t generally ask things out of kindness,', 'however, if you don t want to read, you needn t.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
One can trust you, certainly, to say unpleasant things, Ahem! The Princess is lost in the wood, and she hears the
sound of a horn. (This would all be very pretty on the stage, but I
can t get the effect here.) Anyhow, Sylvano enters, accompanied by the
rest of the gentlemen of Gratian s court. I begin where he
soliloquizes.
subQuotationList:
['One can trust you, certainly, to say unpleasant things,', 'Ahem! The Princess is lost in the wood, and she hears the
sound of a horn. (This would all be very pretty on the stage, but I
can t get the effect here.) Anyhow, Sylvano enters, accompanied by the
rest of the gentlemen of Gratian s court. I begin where he

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
That seems to me extremely well written, William; although, of course,
I don t know enough to criticize in detail.
subQuotationList: ['That seems to me extremely well written, William; although, of course,\nI don t know enough to criticize in detail.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But it s the skill that strikes you not the emotion?
subQuotationList: ['But it s the skill that strikes you not the emotion?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: In a fragment like that, of course, the skill strikes one most.
subQuotationList: ['In a fragment like that, of course, the skill strikes one most.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But perhaps have you time to listen to one more short piece? the scene
between the lovers? There s some real feeling in that, I think. Denham
agrees that it s the best thing I ve done.
subQuotationList: ['But perhaps have you time to listen to one more short piece? the scene\nbetween the lovers? There s some real feeling in that, I think. Denham\nagrees that it s the best thing I ve done.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: You ve read it to Ralph Denham? He s a better judge than I am. What did he say?
subQuotationList: ['You ve read it to Ralph Denham?', 'He s a better judge than I am. What did he say?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
My dear Katharine, I don t ask you for criticism,
as I should ask a scholar. I dare say there are only five men in
England whose opinion of my work matters a straw to me. But I trust you
where feeling is concerned. I had you in my mind often when I was
writing those scenes. I kept asking myself,  Now is this the sort of
thing Katharine would like?  I always think of you when I m writing,
Katharine, even when it s the sort of thing you wouldn t know about.
And I d rather yes, I really believe I d rather you thought well of my
writing than any one in the world.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Katharine,', 'I don t ask you for criticism,
as I should ask a scholar. I dare say there are only five men in
England whose opinion of my work matters a straw to me. But I trust you
where feeling is concerned. I had you in my mind often when I was
writing those scenes. I kept asking myself,  Now is this the sort of

Katharine, even when it s the sort of thing you wouldn t know about.
And I d rather yes, I really believe I d rather you thought well of my
writing than any one in the world.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: You think too much of me altogether, William,
subQuotationList: ['You think too much of me altogether, William,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No, Katharine, I don t, It does me good to think of you.
subQuotationList: ['No, Katharine, I don t,', 'It does me good to think of you.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: William,
subQuotationList: ['William,']

quoteText: William, if you still want me to marry you, I will.
subQuotationList: ['William,', 'if you still want me to marry you, I will.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Is Mr. Hilbery at home, or Mrs. Hilbery?
subQuotationList: ['Is Mr. Hilbery at home, or Mrs. Hilbery?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: No, sir. But Miss Hilbery is at home,
subQuotationList: ['No, sir. But Miss Hilbery is at home,']
speaker: Parlor-Maid

quoteText:
My father is out, But if you can wait, I expect him
soon.
subQuotationList: ['My father is out,', 'But if you can wait, I expect him\nsoon.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Is that one of the moderns whom you despise?
subQuotationList: ['Is that one of the moderns whom you despise?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Yes, I think even you would despise him.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I think even you would despise him.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Even I? Why even I?
subQuotationList: ['Even I?', 'Why even I?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You said you liked modern things; I said I hated them.
subQuotationList: ['You said you liked modern things; I said I hated them.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Or did I confess that I hated all books? I forget
subQuotationList: ['Or did I confess that I hated all books?', 'I forget']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Do you hate all books?
subQuotationList: ['Do you hate all books?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
It would be absurd to say that I hate all books when I ve only read
ten, perhaps; but   Here she pulled herself up short.
subQuotationList: ['It would be absurd to say that I hate all books when I ve only read\nten, perhaps; but   Here she pulled herself up short.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Yes, I do hate books, Why do you want to be for ever
talking about your feelings? That s what I can t make out. And poetry s
all about feelings novels are all about feelings.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I do hate books,', 'Why do you want to be for ever\ntalking about your feelings? That s what I can t make out. And poetry s\nall about feelings novels are all about feelings.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
My mother wants me to tell you, that she hopes you have
begun your poem. She says every one ought to write poetry.... All my
relations write poetry, I can t bear to think of it
sometimes because, of course, it s none of it any good. But then one
needn t read it
subQuotationList:
['My mother wants me to tell you,', 'that she hopes you have
begun your poem. She says every one ought to write poetry.... All my
relations write poetry,', 'I can t bear to think of it
sometimes because, of course, it s none of it any good. But then one
needn t read it']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You don t encourage me to write a poem,
subQuotationList: ['You don t encourage me to write a poem,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But you re not a poet, too, are you?
subQuotationList: ['But you re not a poet, too, are you?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Should I tell you if I were?
subQuotationList: ['Should I tell you if I were?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Yes. Because I think you speak the truth,
subQuotationList: ['Yes. Because I think you speak the truth,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Are you a poet?
subQuotationList: ['Are you a poet?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No. I haven t written any poetry for years, But all the
same, I don t agree with you. I think it s the only thing worth doing.
subQuotationList: ['No. I haven t written any poetry for years,', 'But all the\nsame, I don t agree with you. I think it s the only thing worth doing.']

quoteText: Why do you say that?
subQuotationList: ['Why do you say that?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Because,
I suppose, it keeps an ideal alive which might die otherwise.
subQuotationList: ['Because,\nI suppose, it keeps an ideal alive which might die otherwise.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I don t know that there s much sense in having ideals,
subQuotationList: ['I don t know that there s much sense in having ideals,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But you have them, Why do we call them
ideals? It s a stupid word. Dreams, I mean
subQuotationList: ['But you have them,', 'Why do we call them\nideals? It s a stupid word. Dreams, I mean']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Dreams, I mean,
subQuotationList: ['Dreams, I mean,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: My aunts!
subQuotationList: ['My aunts!']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I come from Woking, Mr. Popham. You may well ask me, why Woking? and
to that I answer, for perhaps the hundredth time, because of the
sunsets. We went there for the sunsets, but that was five-and-twenty
years ago. Where are the sunsets now? Alas! There is no sunset now
nearer than the South Coast.
subQuotationList:
['I come from Woking, Mr. Popham. You may well ask me, why Woking? and
to that I answer, for perhaps the hundredth time, because of the
sunsets. We went there for the sunsets, but that was five-and-twenty
years ago. Where are the sunsets now? Alas! There is no sunset now
nearer than the South Coast.']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
Where are the sunsets now? Do you find sunsets now,
Mr. Popham?
subQuotationList: ['Where are the sunsets now?', 'Do you find sunsets now,\nMr. Popham?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText: I live at Highgate,
subQuotationList: ['I live at Highgate,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
At Highgate? Yes, Highgate has its charms; your Uncle John lived at
Highgate,
subQuotationList: ['At Highgate? Yes, Highgate has its charms; your Uncle John lived at\nHighgate,']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
I dare say there are very pretty lanes in
Highgate. I can recollect walking with your mother, Katharine, through
lanes blossoming with wild hawthorn. But where is the hawthorn now? You
remember that exquisite description in De Quincey, Mr. Popham? but I
forget, you, in your generation, with all your activity and
enlightenment, at which I can only marvel do not read De Quincey. You have your Belloc,
your Chesterton, your Bernard Shaw why should you read De Quincey?
subQuotationList:
['I dare say there are very pretty lanes in
Highgate. I can recollect walking with your mother, Katharine, through
lanes blossoming with wild hawthorn. But where is the hawthorn now? You
remember that exquisite description in De Quincey, Mr. Popham? but I
forget, you, in your generation, with all your activity and
enlightenment, at which I can only marvel', 'do not read De Quincey. You have your Belloc,
your Chesterton, your Bernard Shaw why should you read De Quincey?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
But I do read De Quincey, more than Belloc and
Chesterton, anyhow.
subQuotationList: ['But I do read De Quincey,', 'more than Belloc and\nChesterton, anyhow.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Indeed! You are, then, a  rara avis  in your generation. I am
delighted to meet anyone who reads De Quincey.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed!', 'You are, then, a  rara avis  in your generation. I am\ndelighted to meet anyone who reads De Quincey.']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
Does your friend
_write?_
subQuotationList: ['Does your friend\n_write?_']
speaker: Aunt Millicent
referringExpression: she hollowed her hand into a screen and leaning towards Katharine inquired

quoteText: Mr. Denham, writes for the Review. He is a lawyer.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Denham,', 'writes for the Review. He is a lawyer.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
The clean-shaven lips, showing the expression of the mouth! I
recognize them at once. I always feel at home with lawyers, Mr.
Denham
subQuotationList: ['The clean-shaven lips, showing the expression of the mouth! I\nrecognize them at once. I always feel at home with lawyers, Mr.\nDenham']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText: They used to come about so much in the old days,
subQuotationList: ['They used to come about so much in the old days,']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
You say you live at Highgate, I wonder whether you
happen to know if there is an old house called Tempest Lodge still in
existence an old white house in a garden?
subQuotationList: ['You say you live at Highgate,', 'I wonder whether you\nhappen to know if there is an old house called Tempest Lodge still in\nexistence an old white house in a garden?']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
Ah, no; it must have been pulled down by this time, with all the other
old houses. There were such pretty lanes in those days. That was how
your uncle met your Aunt Emily, you know, They walked home through the lanes.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, no; it must have been pulled down by this time, with all the other\nold houses. There were such pretty lanes in those days. That was how\nyour uncle met your Aunt Emily, you know,', 'They walked home through the lanes.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: A sprig of May in her bonnet,
subQuotationList: ['A sprig of May in her bonnet,']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
And next Sunday he had violets in his buttonhole. And that was how we
guessed.
subQuotationList: ['And next Sunday he had violets in his buttonhole. And that was how we\nguessed.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: Uncle John yes,  poor John,  you always called him. Why was that?
subQuotationList: ['Uncle John yes,  poor John,  you always called him. Why was that?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
That was what his father, old Sir Richard, always called him. Poor
John, or the fool of the family,
subQuotationList: ['That was what his father, old Sir Richard, always called him. Poor\nJohn, or the fool of the family,']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
referringExpression: Mrs Milvain hastened to inform them

quoteText:
The other boys were so brilliant, and he could never pass his
examinations, so they sent him to India a long voyage in those days,
poor fellow. You had your own room, you know, and you did it up. But he
will get his knighthood and a pension, I believe, only it is not England.
subQuotationList:
['The other boys were so brilliant, and he could never pass his
examinations, so they sent him to India a long voyage in those days,
poor fellow. You had your own room, you know, and you did it up. But he
will get his knighthood and a pension, I believe,', 'only it is not England.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Uncle John'], ['Uncle John'], ['Uncle John'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Uncle John'], ['Uncle John']], []]

quoteText:
No, it is not England. In those days we
thought an Indian Judgeship about equal to a county-court judgeship at
home. His Honor a pretty title, but still, not at the top of the tree.
However, if you have a wife and seven children, and
people nowadays very quickly forget your father s name well, you have
to take what you can get,
subQuotationList:
['No,', 'it is not England. In those days we
thought an Indian Judgeship about equal to a county-court judgeship at
home. His Honor a pretty title, but still, not at the top of the tree.
However,', 'if you have a wife and seven children, and
people nowadays very quickly forget your father s name well, you have
to take what you can get,']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
And I fancy, that John would have done more if it hadn t been for
his wife, your Aunt Emily. She was a very good woman, devoted to him,
of course, but she was not ambitious for him, and if a wife isn t
ambitious for her husband, especially in a profession like the law,
clients soon get to know of it. In our young days, Mr. Denham, we used
to say that we knew which of our friends would become judges, by
looking at the girls they married. And so it was, and so, I fancy, it
always will be. I don t think, that any man is really happy unless he succeeds in his
profession.
subQuotationList:
['And I fancy,', 'that John would have done more if it hadn t been for
his wife, your Aunt Emily. She was a very good woman, devoted to him,
of course, but she was not ambitious for him, and if a wife isn t
ambitious for her husband, especially in a profession like the law,
clients soon get to know of it. In our young days, Mr. Denham, we used
to say that we knew which of our friends would become judges, by
looking at the girls they married. And so it was, and so, I fancy, it
always will be. I don t think,', 'that any man is really happy unless he succeeds in his
profession.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
