quoteText:
No, men are not the same as women. I fancy Alfred Tennyson spoke the
truth about that as about many other things. How I wish he d lived to
write  The Prince  a sequel to  The Princess ! I confess I m almost
tired of Princesses. We want some one to show us what a good man can
be. We have Laura and Beatrice, Antigone and Cordelia, but we have no
heroic man. How do you, as a poet, account for that, Mr. Denham?
subQuotationList:
['No, men are not the same as women. I fancy Alfred Tennyson spoke the
truth about that as about many other things. How I wish he d lived to
write  The Prince  a sequel to  The Princess ! I confess I m almost
tired of Princesses. We want some one to show us what a good man can
be. We have Laura and Beatrice, Antigone and Cordelia, but we have no
heroic man. How do you, as a poet, account for that, Mr. Denham?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent
referringExpression: Mrs Cosham approved of this sentiment with more ponderous sagacity from her side of the teatable in the first place by swaying her head and in the second by remarking

quoteText: I m not a poet, I m only a solicitor.
subQuotationList: ['I m not a poet,', 'I m only a solicitor.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But you write, too?
subQuotationList: ['But you write, too?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText: In my spare time,
subQuotationList: ['In my spare time,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
In your spare time! That is a proof of devotion,
indeed.
subQuotationList: ['In your spare time!', 'That is a proof of devotion,\nindeed.']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
Um um Pendennis Warrington I could never forgive Laura, for not marrying George, in spite of
everything. George Eliot did the very same thing; and Lewes was a
little frog-faced man, with the manner of a dancing master. But
Warrington, now, had everything in his favor; intellect, passion,
romance, distinction, and the connection was a mere piece of
undergraduate folly. Arthur, I confess, has always seemed to me a bit
of a fop; I can t imagine how Laura married him. But you say you re a
solicitor, Mr. Denham. Now there are one or two things I should like to
ask you about Shakespeare They say,
nowadays, that Shakespeare was a lawyer. They say, that accounts for
his knowledge of human nature. There s a fine example for you, Mr.
Denham. Study your clients, young man, and the world will be the richer
one of these days, I have no doubt. Tell me, how do we come out of it,
now; better or worse than you expected?
subQuotationList:
['Um um Pendennis Warrington I could never forgive Laura,', 'for not marrying George, in spite of
everything. George Eliot did the very same thing; and Lewes was a
little frog-faced man, with the manner of a dancing master. But
Warrington, now, had everything in his favor; intellect, passion,
romance, distinction, and the connection was a mere piece of
undergraduate folly. Arthur, I confess, has always seemed to me a bit
of a fop; I can t imagine how Laura married him. But you say you re a
solicitor, Mr. Denham. Now there are one or two things I should like to
ask you about Shakespeare', 'They say,
nowadays, that Shakespeare was a lawyer. They say, that accounts for
his knowledge of human nature. There s a fine example for you, Mr.
Denham. Study your clients, young man, and the world will be the richer
one of these days, I have no doubt. Tell me, how do we come out of it,
now; better or worse than you expected?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText:
Worse, Mrs. Cosham, a good deal worse. I m afraid the ordinary man is
a bit of a rascal
subQuotationList: ['Worse, Mrs. Cosham, a good deal worse. I m afraid the ordinary man is\na bit of a rascal']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: And the ordinary woman?
subQuotationList: ['And the ordinary woman?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText: No, I don t like the ordinary woman either
subQuotationList: ['No, I don t like the ordinary woman either']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Ah, dear me, I ve no doubt that s very true, very true. Swift would have agreed with you, anyhow
subQuotationList: ['Ah, dear me, I ve no doubt that s very true, very true.', 'Swift would have agreed with you, anyhow']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText: Charles Lavington, you remember, was a solicitor, But you wouldn t remember him, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['Charles Lavington, you remember, was a solicitor,', 'But you wouldn t remember him, Katharine.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
Mr. Lavington? Oh, yes, I do, The summer we had a house near Tenby.
I remember the field and the pond with the tadpoles, and making
haystacks with Mr. Lavington.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Lavington? Oh, yes, I do,', 'The summer we had a house near Tenby.\nI remember the field and the pond with the tadpoles, and making\nhaystacks with Mr. Lavington.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
She is right. There _was_ a pond with tadpoles, Millais made studies of it for  Ophelia.  Some say that
is the best picture he ever painted
subQuotationList: ['She is right. There _was_ a pond with tadpoles,', 'Millais made studies of it for  Ophelia.  Some say that\nis the best picture he ever painted']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
And I remember the dog chained up in the yard, and the dead snakes
hanging in the toolhouse.
subQuotationList: ['And I remember the dog chained up in the yard, and the dead snakes\nhanging in the toolhouse.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
It was at Tenby that you were chased by the bull, But that you couldn t remember, though it s true you were a
wonderful child. Such eyes she had, Mr. Denham! I used to say to her
father,  She s watching us, and summing us all up in her little mind. 
And they had a nurse in those days, who was a good woman, but engaged to
a sailor. When she ought to have been attending to the baby, her eyes
were on the sea. And Mrs. Hilbery allowed this girl Susan her name
was to have him to stay in the village. They abused her goodness, I m
sorry to say, and while they walked in the lanes, they stood the
perambulator alone in a field where there was a bull. The animal became
enraged by the red blanket in the perambulator, and Heaven knows what
might have happened if a gentleman had not been walking by in the nick
of time, and rescued Katharine in his arms!
subQuotationList:
['It was at Tenby that you were chased by the bull,', 'But that you couldn t remember, though it s true you were a
wonderful child. Such eyes she had, Mr. Denham! I used to say to her
father,  She s watching us, and summing us all up in her little mind. 
And they had a nurse in those days,', 'who was a good woman, but engaged to
a sailor. When she ought to have been attending to the baby, her eyes
were on the sea. And Mrs. Hilbery allowed this girl Susan her name
was to have him to stay in the village. They abused her goodness, I m
sorry to say, and while they walked in the lanes, they stood the
perambulator alone in a field where there was a bull. The animal became
enraged by the red blanket in the perambulator, and Heaven knows what
might have happened if a gentleman had not been walking by in the nick
of time, and rescued Katharine in his arms!']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: I think the bull was only a cow, Aunt Celia,
subQuotationList: ['I think the bull was only a cow, Aunt Celia,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
My darling, it was a great red Devonshire bull, and not long after it
gored a man to death and had to be destroyed. And your mother forgave
Susan a thing I could never have done.
subQuotationList: ['My darling, it was a great red Devonshire bull, and not long after it\ngored a man to death and had to be destroyed. And your mother forgave\nSusan a thing I could never have done.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText:
Maggie s sympathies were entirely with Susan and the sailor, I am
sure,
subQuotationList: ['Maggie s sympathies were entirely with Susan and the sailor, I am\nsure,']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
My sister-in-law, has laid her burdens upon Providence at every crisis in her
life, and Providence, I must confess, has responded nobly, so far
subQuotationList: ['My sister-in-law,', 'has laid her burdens upon Providence at every crisis in her\nlife, and Providence, I must confess, has responded nobly, so far']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText:
Yes, My mother s bulls always turn into
cows at the critical moment.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'My mother s bulls always turn into\ncows at the critical moment.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Well, I m glad you have some one to protect you
from bulls now.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'I m glad you have some one to protect you\nfrom bulls now.']
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

quoteText: I can t imagine William protecting any one from bulls,
subQuotationList: ['I can t imagine William protecting any one from bulls,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I like rubies,
subQuotationList: ['I like rubies,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And have you settled upon a house yet, Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['And have you settled upon a house yet, Katharine?']
speaker: Aunt Millicent
referringExpression: Mrs Cosham had time to look over his shoulder and ask her niece

quoteText: Yes, it s a difficult passage.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, it s a difficult passage.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: He looked up at once and said

quoteText:
Katharine s engaged to William Rodney, a very old friend of ours. He has a wonderful knowledge of
literature, too wonderful. You
should meet each other.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine s engaged to William Rodney,', 'a very old friend of ours. He has a wonderful knowledge of\nliterature, too wonderful.', 'You\nshould meet each other.']
speaker: Aunt Millicent

quoteText: My father will be back, Won t you sit down?
subQuotationList: ['My father will be back,', 'Won t you sit down?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I must congratulate you, It was news to me.
subQuotationList: ['I must congratulate you,', 'It was news to me.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: My engagement? Yes, I am going to marry William Rodney.
subQuotationList: ['My engagement?', 'Yes, I am going to marry William Rodney.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Well, I must go,
subQuotationList: ['Well, I must go,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You will come again, I hope. We always seem to be
interrupted.
subQuotationList: ['You will come again, I hope. We always seem', 'to be\ninterrupted.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: She seemed about to say something then changed her mind and said

quoteText: In what can one trust, then?
subQuotationList: ['In what can one trust, then?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
In what can one trust? Not in men and women. Not in one s dreams about
them. There s nothing nothing, nothing left at all.
subQuotationList: ['In what can one trust? Not in men and women. Not in one s dreams about\nthem. There s nothing nothing, nothing left at all.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Gracious, Mary! How you startled me!
subQuotationList: ['Gracious, Mary!', 'How you startled me!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Yes. You looked as if you were walking in your sleep, Are
you arranging some terrible love affair? Have you got to reconcile a
desperate couple?
subQuotationList: ['Yes. You looked as if you were walking in your sleep,', 'Are\nyou arranging some terrible love affair? Have you got to reconcile a\ndesperate couple?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I wasn t thinking about my work, And,
besides, that sort of thing s not in my line,
subQuotationList: ['I wasn t thinking about my work,', 'And,\nbesides, that sort of thing s not in my line,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I ve never seen sparrows so tame,
subQuotationList: ['I ve never seen sparrows so tame,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
No, The sparrows in Hyde Park aren t as tame as this. If
we keep perfectly still, I ll get one to settle on my arm.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'The sparrows in Hyde Park aren t as tame as this. If\nwe keep perfectly still, I ll get one to settle on my arm.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Done! That s what always happens just as I ve almost got him, Here s your sixpence, Mary. But you ve only got it thanks to that
brute of a boy. They oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops here
subQuotationList: ['Done!', 'That s what always happens just as I ve almost got him,', 'Here s your sixpence, Mary. But you ve only got it thanks to that\nbrute of a boy. They oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops here']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops! My dear Ralph, what nonsense!
subQuotationList: ['Oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops! My dear Ralph, what nonsense!']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You always say that, and it isn t nonsense. What s
the point of having a garden if one can t watch birds in it? The street
does all right for hoops. And if children can t be trusted in the
streets, their mothers should keep them at home.
subQuotationList:
['You always say that,', 'and it isn t nonsense. What s
the point of having a garden if one can t watch birds in it? The street
does all right for hoops. And if children can t be trusted in the
streets, their mothers should keep them at home.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Ah, well, London s a fine place to live in. I believe I
could sit and watch people all day long. I like my
fellow-creatures....
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well,', 'London s a fine place to live in. I believe I\ncould sit and watch people all day long. I like my\nfellow-creatures....']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Yes, I think so, when you come to know them,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I think so, when you come to know them,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
That s just when I don t like them, Still, I don t see
why you shouldn t cherish that illusion, if it pleases you.
subQuotationList: ['That s just when I don t like them,', 'Still, I don t see\nwhy you shouldn t cherish that illusion, if it pleases you.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Wake up, Ralph! You re half asleep! What have you been doing with yourself? Moping? Working?
Despising the world, as usual?
subQuotationList: ['Wake up, Ralph! You re half asleep!', 'What have you been doing with yourself? Moping? Working?\nDespising the world, as usual?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: It s a bit of a pose, isn t it?
subQuotationList: ['It s a bit of a pose, isn t it?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Not more than most things,
subQuotationList: ['Not more than most things,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Well, I ve a great deal to say to you, but I must go
on we have a committee.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'I ve a great deal to say to you, but I must go\non we have a committee.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You don t look happy, Ralph, Is it
anything, or is it nothing?
subQuotationList: ['You don t look happy, Ralph,', 'Is it\nanything, or is it nothing?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I ve been bothered, Partly by work, and partly by
family troubles. Charles has been behaving like a fool. He wants to go
out to Canada as a farmer
subQuotationList: ['I ve been bothered,', 'Partly by work, and partly by\nfamily troubles. Charles has been behaving like a fool. He wants to go\nout to Canada as a farmer']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Well, there s something to be said for that,
subQuotationList: ['Well, there s something to be said for that,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
What d you want to sit on a committee for? It s waste of
your time, Mary.
subQuotationList: ['What d you want to sit on a committee for?', 'It s waste of\nyour time, Mary.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I agree with you that a country walk would benefit the world more, Look here, why don t you come to us at
Christmas? It s almost the best time of year.
subQuotationList: ['I agree with you that a country walk would benefit the world more,', 'Look here,', 'why don t you come to us at\nChristmas? It s almost the best time of year.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Come to you at Disham?
subQuotationList: ['Come to you at Disham?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Yes. We won t interfere with you. But you can tell me later,
subQuotationList: ['Yes. We won t interfere with you. But you can tell me later,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
If I can t face a walk in a field alone with Ralph, I d better buy a cat and live in a lodging at Ealing, like Sally
Seal and he won t come. Or did he mean that he _would_ come?
subQuotationList: ['If I can t face a walk in a field alone with Ralph,', 'I d better buy a cat and live in a lodging at Ealing, like Sally\nSeal and he won t come. Or did he mean that he _would_ come?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Miss Markham has already arrived, and this is her dog.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Markham has already arrived,', 'and this is her dog.']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText: A very fine dog, too,
subQuotationList: ['A very fine dog, too,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Yes. A magnificent fellow, A kind of St. Bernard,
she tells me so like Kit to have a St. Bernard. And you guard your
mistress well, don t you, Sailor? You see that wicked men don t break
into her larder when she s out at _her_ work helping poor souls who
have lost their way.... But we re late we must begin!
subQuotationList:
['Yes. A magnificent fellow,', 'A kind of St. Bernard,
she tells me so like Kit to have a St. Bernard. And you guard your
mistress well, don t you, Sailor? You see that wicked men don t break
into her larder when she s out at _her_ work helping poor souls who
have lost their way.... But we re late we must begin!']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText: I fancy, ladies and gentlemen, that we are ready to commence.
subQuotationList: ['I fancy, ladies and gentlemen, that we are ready to commence.']
speaker: Mr. Clacton
referringExpression: he gave a little laugh and observed to the assembly

quoteText: My friends think all this kind of thing useless.
subQuotationList: ['My friends think all this kind of thing useless.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Oh, they re that sort, are they?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, they re that sort, are they?']
speaker: Miss Markham

quoteText: What do I matter compared with the cause?
subQuotationList: ['What do I matter compared with the cause?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Action! everywhere! at
once!
subQuotationList: ['Action! everywhere! at\nonce!']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
If I liked I could make you go in there or stop
short; I could make you walk in single file or in double file; I could
do what I liked with you.
subQuotationList: ['If I liked I could make you go in there or stop\nshort; I could make you walk in single file or in double file; I could\ndo what I liked with you.']
speaker: Mary Datchet
referringExpression: Mary looked at the little figures and thought

quoteText: Oughtn t you to put something round your shoulders, Sally? Well, did you enjoy yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Oughtn t you to put something round your shoulders, Sally?', 'Well, did you enjoy yourself?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Ah, if only one could get every one of those people into
this room, and make them understand for five minutes! But they _must_
see the truth some day.... If only one could _make_ them see it....
subQuotationList: ['Ah, if only one could get every one of those people into\nthis room, and make them understand for five minutes! But they _must_\nsee the truth some day.... If only one could _make_ them see it....']
speaker: Mrs. Seal
referringExpression: Mrs Seal drew a deep breath restrained herself and then burst out

quoteText:
Let s have our tea, It was a good meeting didn t you think so,
Sally?
subQuotationList: ['Let s have our tea,', 'It was a good meeting didn t you think so,\nSally?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
But we go at such a snail s pace, You can afford to laugh, but I can t. I m fifty-five, and I dare say I shall be in my grave by
the time we get it if we ever do.
subQuotationList: ['But we go at such a snail s pace,', 'You can afford to laugh,', 'but I can t. I m fifty-five, and I dare say I shall be in my grave by\nthe time we get it if we ever do.']
speaker: Mrs. Seal
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton', 'Mary Datchet', 'Miss Markham']], [['Mary Datchet']], [['Mary Datchet', 'Miss Markham', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Miss Markham', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton']]]

quoteText: Oh, no, you won t be in your grave,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no, you won t be in your grave,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
It ll be such a great day, A great day, not only for us, but for civilization. That s what I
feel, you know, about these meetings. Each one of them is a step
onwards in the great march humanity, you know. We do want the people
after us to have a better time of it and so many don t see it. I wonder
how it is that they don t see it?
subQuotationList:
['It ll be such a great day,', 'A great day, not only for us, but for civilization. That s what I
feel, you know, about these meetings. Each one of them is a step
onwards in the great march humanity, you know. We do want the people
after us to have a better time of it and so many don t see it. I wonder
how it is that they don t see it?']
speaker: Mrs. Seal

quoteText:
You mustn t wear yourself out, Sally, if you want to see the great
day,
subQuotationList: ['You mustn t wear yourself out, Sally, if you want to see the great\nday,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
My dear child, what else is my old body good for? Shouldn t
I be proud to give everything I have to the cause? for I m not an
intelligence like you. There were domestic circumstances I d like to
tell you one of these days so I say foolish things. I lose my head, you
know. You don t. Mr. Clacton doesn t. It s a great mistake, to lose
one s head. But my heart s in the right place. And I m so glad Kit has
a big dog, for I didn t think her looking well.
subQuotationList:
['My dear child, what else is my old body good for?', 'Shouldn t
I be proud to give everything I have to the cause? for I m not an
intelligence like you. There were domestic circumstances I d like to
tell you one of these days so I say foolish things. I lose my head, you
know. You don t. Mr. Clacton doesn t. It s a great mistake, to lose
one s head. But my heart s in the right place. And I m so glad Kit has
a big dog, for I didn t think her looking well.']
speaker: Mrs. Seal
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Datchet']], [['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mr. Clacton'], ['Miss Markham'], ['Miss Markham']]]

quoteText: We were passing and saw a light in your window, so we came up,
subQuotationList: ['We were passing and saw a light in your window, so we came up,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: We have been to see some pictures,
subQuotationList: ['We have been to see some pictures,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Oh, dear, this room reminds me of one of the worst
hours in my existence when I read a paper, and you all sat round and
jeered at me. Katharine was the worst. I could feel her gloating over
every mistake I made. Miss Datchet was kind. Miss Datchet just made it
possible for me to get through, I remember.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, dear,', 'this room reminds me of one of the worst
hours in my existence when I read a paper, and you all sat round and
jeered at me. Katharine was the worst. I could feel her gloating over
every mistake I made. Miss Datchet was kind. Miss Datchet just made it
possible for me to get through, I remember.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: We have been seeing old masters at the Grafton Gallery,
subQuotationList: ['We have been seeing old masters at the Grafton Gallery,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Would you believe it, Miss Datchet, Katharine
doesn t like Titian. She doesn t like apricots, she doesn t like
peaches, she doesn t like green peas. She likes the Elgin marbles, and
gray days without any sun. She s a typical example of the cold northern
nature. I come from Devonshire
subQuotationList:
['Would you believe it, Miss Datchet,', 'Katharine
doesn t like Titian. She doesn t like apricots, she doesn t like
peaches, she doesn t like green peas. She likes the Elgin marbles, and
gray days without any sun. She s a typical example of the cold northern
nature. I come from Devonshire']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
Perhaps, Mary, you wouldn t mind giving us
some tea? We did try to get some, but the shop was so crowded, and in
the next one there was a band playing; and most of the pictures, at any
rate, were very dull, whatever you may say, William.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps, Mary,', 'you wouldn t mind giving us
some tea? We did try to get some, but the shop was so crowded, and in
the next one there was a band playing; and most of the pictures, at any
rate, were very dull, whatever you may say, William.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: What in the world are they after?
subQuotationList: ['What in the world are they after?']
speaker: Mary Datchet
referringExpression: she asked of her own reflection

quoteText:
William, thinks that perhaps you don t know. We are going
to be married.
subQuotationList: ['William,', 'thinks that perhaps you don t know. We are going\nto be married.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Let me see, one puts hot water into the cups first,
doesn t one? You have some dodge of your own, haven t you, William,
about making tea?
subQuotationList: ['Let me see,', 'one puts hot water into the cups first,\ndoesn t one? You have some dodge of your own, haven t you, William,\nabout making tea?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Your tea, William,
subQuotationList: ['Your tea, William,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I wonder how you find the time to know all about pictures as well as
books?
subQuotationList: ['I wonder how you find the time to know all about pictures as well as\nbooks?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
How do I find the time? Why, I always travel with a notebook. And I
ask my way to the picture gallery the very first thing in the morning.
And then I meet men, and talk to them. There s a man in my office who
knows all about the Flemish school. I was telling Miss Datchet about
the Flemish school. I picked up a lot of it from him it s a way men
have Gibbons, his name is. You must meet him. We ll ask him to lunch.
And this not caring about art, it s
one of Katharine s poses, Miss Datchet. Did you know she posed? She
pretends that she s never read Shakespeare. And why should she read
Shakespeare, since she IS Shakespeare Rosalind, you know, She knows enough enough for all decent purposes. What do you women
want with learning, when you have so much else everything, I should
say everything. Leave us something, eh, Katharine?
subQuotationList:
['How do I find the time?', 'Why, I always travel with a notebook. And I
ask my way to the picture gallery the very first thing in the morning.
And then I meet men, and talk to them. There s a man in my office who
knows all about the Flemish school. I was telling Miss Datchet about
the Flemish school. I picked up a lot of it from him it s a way men
have Gibbons, his name is. You must meet him. We ll ask him to lunch.
And this not caring about art,', 'it s
one of Katharine s poses, Miss Datchet. Did you know she posed? She
pretends that she s never read Shakespeare. And why should she read
Shakespeare, since she IS Shakespeare Rosalind, you know,', 'She knows enough enough for all decent purposes. What do you women
want with learning, when you have so much else everything, I should
say everything. Leave us something, eh, Katharine?']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mary Datchet'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mary Datchet']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: Leave you something? I was thinking we must be going
subQuotationList: ['Leave you something?', 'I was thinking we must be going']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Is it to-night that Lady Ferrilby dines with us? No, we mustn t be
late, D you know the Ferrilbys, Miss Datchet?
They own Trantem Abbey, And if Katharine makes herself very charming to-night,
perhaps ll lend it to us for the honeymoon.

quoteText:
I agree that may be a reason. Otherwise she s a dull woman, At least, I
find it difficult to talk to her.
subQuotationList: ['I agree that may be a reason. Otherwise she s a dull woman,', 'At least,', 'I\nfind it difficult to talk to her.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Because you expect every one else to take all the trouble. I ve seen
her sit silent a whole evening, Don t you find that, too? Sometimes when
we re alone, I ve counted the time on my watch the time between one remark and
the next. And once I counted ten minutes and twenty seconds, and then,
if you ll believe me, she only said  Um!
subQuotationList:

her sit silent a whole evening,', 'Don t you find that, too? Sometimes when

quoteText:
I m sure I m sorry, I know it s a bad habit,
but then, you see, at home
subQuotationList: ['I m sure I m sorry,', 'I know it s a bad habit,\nbut then, you see, at home']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

referringExpression: She soon found it and said

quoteText:
But that s absurd, There are five spare rooms, even when the boys are
here. Besides, he wouldn t get a room in the village. And he oughtn t
to work if he s overworked.

subQuotationList: ['If Ralph were here, he d find this very dull,']

quoteText:
Where does this fellow come from? One of Elizabeth s roses I hope you

her leave, and quite right, too.

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']

quoteText: The garden s looking very nice, father.

speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Yes, yes, yes,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, yes,']
speaker: Mr. Datchet

quoteText:
The traffic s very much increased, you know. More rolling-stock needed
already. Forty trucks went down yesterday by the 12.15 counted them
myself. They ve taken off the 9.3, and given us an 8.30 instead suits
the business men, you know. You came by the old 3.10 yesterday, I
suppose?
subQuotationList:

quoteText: Yes,

quoteText: You ll find somebody to direct you at Lincoln,
subQuotationList: ['You ll find somebody to direct you at Lincoln,']

quoteText: I ve got to walk over from Disham,
subQuotationList: ['I ve got to walk over from Disham,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Well, Ralph, this is better than Lincoln s Inn Fields,
isn t it? Look, there s a bird for you! Oh, you ve brought glasses,
have you? Edward and Christopher mean to make you shoot. Can you shoot?
I shouldn t think so
subQuotationList:

Look here, you must explain, Who are these young men?
Where am I staying?
subQuotationList: ['Look here, you must explain,', 'Who are these young men?\nWhere am I staying?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You are staying with us, of course, Of course,
you re staying with us you don t mind coming, do you?
subQuotationList: ['You are staying with us, of course,', 'Of course,\nyou re staying with us you don t mind coming, do you?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

If I had, I shouldn t have come, This is the sort of country I thought you d live in, Mary, Real country.
No gentlemen s seats.
subQuotationList: ['If I had, I shouldn t have come,', 'This is the sort of country I thought you d live in, Mary,', 'Real country.\nNo gentlemen s seats.']

subQuotationList: ['Now we have to find our way through a hedge,', 'It s quite right that they should poach,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I wonder whether it was Alfred Duggins or Sid
Rankin? How can one expect them not to, when they only make fifteen
shillings a week? Fifteen shillings a week, I
could live on fifteen shillings a week easily.
subQuotationList:
['I wonder whether it was Alfred Duggins or Sid
Rankin? How can one expect them not to, when they only make fifteen
shillings a week? Fifteen shillings a week,', 'I
could live on fifteen shillings a week easily.']

quoteText: Could you?
subQuotationList: ['Could you?']

quoteText: I don t believe you could,
subQuotationList: ['I don t believe you could,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Oh yes. They have a cottage thrown in, and a garden where one can grow
vegetables. It wouldn t be half bad,
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes. They have a cottage thrown in, and a garden where one can grow\nvegetables. It wouldn t be half bad,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: But you d get tired of it,
subQuotationList: ['But you d get tired of it,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I sometimes think it s the only thing one would never get tired of,
subQuotationList: ['I sometimes think it s the only thing one would never get tired of,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
But wouldn t it be on the main road, or next door to a woman with six
squalling children, who d always be hanging her washing out to dry
across your garden?
subQuotationList: ['But wouldn t it be on the main road, or next door to a woman with six\nsqualling children, who d always be hanging her washing out to dry\nacross your garden?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: The cottage I m thinking of stands by itself in a little orchard.
subQuotationList: ['The cottage I m thinking of stands by itself in a little orchard.']

quoteText: And what about the Suffrage?
subQuotationList: ['And what about the Suffrage?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Oh, there are other things in the world besides the Suffrage,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, there are other things in the world besides the Suffrage,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: D you know the points of the compass?
subQuotationList: ['D you know the points of the compass?']

quoteText:
Well, of course, What d you take me for? a Cockney like
you?
subQuotationList: ['Well, of course,', 'What d you take me for? a Cockney like\nyou?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
It s my native land, this, I could smell my way about it

subQuotationList: ['It s my native land, this,', 'I could smell my way about it\nblindfold.', 'That s Christopher, come in already, and gone to feed his chickens,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You came by the 3.10, Mr. Denham? They treat us very well,
on the whole. Considering the increase of traffic, they treat us very
well indeed. I have the curiosity sometimes to count the trucks on the
goods  trains, and they re well over fifty well over fifty, at this
season of the year.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
It s got the old rests by the side of the fireplace, where the men
hung their guns, Show Mr. Denham the steps,
Christopher.... When the Ecclesiastical Commissioners were here two
years ago they said this was the most interesting part of the house.
These narrow bricks prove that it is five hundred years old five
hundred years, I think they may have said six.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: Don t you care about shooting?

subQuotationList: ['You wouldn t have much chance in London, I suppose,', 'But won t you find it rather dull just watching us?']

quoteText: I shall watch birds,
subQuotationList: ['I shall watch birds,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I can show you the place for watching birds, if that s
what you like doing. I know a fellow who comes down from London about
this time every year to watch them. It s a great place for the wild
geese and the ducks. I ve heard this man say that it s one of the best
places for birds in the country.
subQuotationList:
['I can show you the place for watching birds,', 'if that s

speaker: Christopher

quoteText: It s not Piper, it s Pitch,
subQuotationList: ['It s not Piper, it s Pitch,']
speaker: Edward

quoteText: All the same, I shall have to get up,
subQuotationList: ['All the same, I shall have to get up,']
speaker: Christopher

quoteText: Do come in and shut the door!
subQuotationList: ['Do come in and shut the door!']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: We shall have a fine day to-morrow,
subQuotationList: ['We shall have a fine day to-morrow,']
speaker: Christopher

quoteText: I should like Mary to stroke my head like that,
subQuotationList: ['I should like Mary to stroke my head like that,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
To begin with, I m very fond of William. You can t deny that. I know
him better than any one, almost. But why I m marrying him is, partly, I
admit I m being quite honest with you, and you mustn t tell any
one partly because I want to get married. I want to have a house of my
own. It isn t possible at home. It s all very well for you, Henry; you
can go your own way. I have to be there always. Besides, you know what
our house is. You wouldn t be happy either, if you didn t do something.
It isn t that I haven t the time at home it s the atmosphere.
subQuotationList:
['To begin with, I m very fond of William. You can t deny that. I know
him better than any one, almost. But why I m marrying him is, partly, I
admit I m being quite honest with you, and you mustn t tell any
one partly because I want to get married. I want to have a house of my
own. It isn t possible at home. It s all very well for you, Henry; you
can go your own way. I have to be there always. Besides, you know what
our house is. You wouldn t be happy either, if you didn t do something.
It isn t that I haven t the time at home it s the atmosphere.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: she did begin a little speech to him

quoteText:
I should like, to study mathematics to
know about the stars.
subQuotationList: ['I should like,', 'to study mathematics to\nknow about the stars.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t care much whether I ever get to know anything but I want to
work out something in figures something that hasn t got to do with
human beings. I don t want people particularly. In some ways, Henry,
I m a humbug I mean, I m not what you all take me for. I m not
domestic, or very practical or sensible, really. And if I could
calculate things, and use a telescope, and have to work out figures,
and know to a fraction where I was wrong, I should be perfectly happy,
and I believe I should give William all he wants.
subQuotationList:
['I don t care much whether I ever get to know anything but I want to
work out something in figures something that hasn t got to do with
human beings. I don t want people particularly. In some ways, Henry,
I m a humbug I mean, I m not what you all take me for. I m not
domestic, or very practical or sensible, really. And if I could
calculate things, and use a telescope, and have to work out figures,
and know to a fraction where I was wrong, I should be perfectly happy,
and I believe I should give William all he wants.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

subQuotationList: ['You have fled, too, then?']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
Fled? From whom d you mean? Oh, the family party. Yes, it
was hot down there, so I went into the garden.
subQuotationList: ['Fled?', 'From whom d you mean? Oh, the family party. Yes, it\nwas hot down there, so I went into the garden.']

subQuotationList: ['Thank you, Henry,', 'I m not disturbing you?']

quoteText:
I m not here. I m at Bungay, I m giving a music lesson
to Harold and Julia. That was why I had to leave the table with the
ladies I m spending the night there, and I shan t be back till late on
Christmas Eve.
subQuotationList:

to Harold and Julia. That was why I had to leave the table with the

I think these
parties are a great mistake,

quoteText: Oh, horrible!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, horrible!']

quoteText: It s very interesting,
subQuotationList: ['It s very interesting,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Perhaps marriage will make you more human.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps marriage will make you more human.']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
When you consider things like the stars, our affairs don t seem to
matter very much, do they?
subQuotationList: ['When you consider things like the stars, our affairs don t seem to\nmatter very much, do they?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I don t think I ever do consider things like the stars,
subQuotationList: ['I don t think I ever do consider things like the stars,']

quoteText: I m not sure that that s not the explanation, though,
subQuotationList: ['I m not sure that that s not the explanation, though,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: That certainly seems to explain some of your actions,
subQuotationList: ['That certainly seems to explain some of your actions,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: One thing s about as good as another, and one s got to do something,
subQuotationList: ['One thing s about as good as another, and one s got to do something,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Well, if you believe that your life must be simple, Henry.
subQuotationList: ['Well, if you believe that your life must be simple, Henry.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But I don t believe it,
subQuotationList: ['But I don t believe it,']

quoteText: No more do I,
subQuotationList: ['No more do I,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
What about the stars? I understand that you
rule your life by the stars?

quoteText:
But do you always understand why you do everything? Ought one to
understand? People like my mother understand, Now I
must go down to them, I suppose, and see what s happening.
subQuotationList: ['But do you always understand why you do everything? Ought one to\nunderstand? People like my mother understand,', 'Now I\nmust go down to them, I suppose, and see what s happening.']

subQuotationList: ['What could be happening?']

quoteText: Oh, they may want to settle something,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, they may want to settle something,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And then there s William,
subQuotationList: ['And then there s William,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Do they know what coals are made of, Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Do they know what coals are made of, Henry?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Mares  tails, I believe,
subQuotationList: ['Mares  tails, I believe,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Have you ever been down a coal-mine?
subQuotationList: ['Have you ever been down a coal-mine?']

Don t let s talk about coal-mines, Katharine, We shall
probably never see each other again. When you re married

subQuotationList: ['Things aren t easy, anyhow,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

subQuotationList: ['Promise me, Katharine, that if I can ever help you, you will let me.']

quoteText: Yes, I promise that,

quoteText: That s where you ve been all the time,

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: My dear Katharine, you left the drawing-room over an hour ago.

quoteText:
They don t like it, It isn t kind to old people to leave

subQuotationList: ['They don t like it,', 'It isn t kind to old people to leave\nthem alone although I ve no doubt it s much more amusing to sit up here\nand talk to Henry.']

Yes. But we were talking about much more interesting things before
that,

quoteText: I can quite understand that,

quoteText: Of course it was dull,
subQuotationList: ['Of course it was dull,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Well, you stay and talk to Henry, and I ll go down,

quoteText: I shall come down with you,
subQuotationList: ['I shall come down with you,']

quoteText: Oh no, You stay here and talk to Henry.

speaker: Henry Otway

It s useless for you to come. I shall go to bed in ten minutes. Good
night.

quoteText:
You ve several big estates round here, Otway, Any good
hunting? Let me see, what pack would it be? Who s your great man?
subQuotationList: ['You ve several big estates round here, Otway,', 'Any good\nhunting? Let me see, what pack would it be? Who s your great man?']

quoteText:
Sir William Budge, the sugar king, has the biggest estate. He bought
out poor Stanham, who went bankrupt.
subQuotationList: ['Sir William Budge, the sugar king, has the biggest estate. He bought\nout poor Stanham, who went bankrupt.']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Which Stanham would that be? Verney or Alfred?

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Alfred.... I don t hunt myself. You re a great huntsman, aren t you?
You have a great reputation as a horseman, anyhow,
subQuotationList: ['Alfred.... I don t hunt myself. You re a great huntsman, aren t you?\nYou have a great reputation as a horseman, anyhow,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
Oh, I love riding, Could I get a horse down here?
Stupid of me! I forgot to bring any clothes. I can t imagine, though,
who told you I was anything of a rider?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I love riding,', 'Could I get a horse down here?\nStupid of me! I forgot to bring any clothes. I can t imagine, though,\nwho told you I was anything of a rider?']

quoteText:
I don t care much for shooting, but one has to do
it, unless one wants to be altogether out of things. I dare say there s
some very pretty country round here. I stayed once at Bolham Hall.
Young Cranthorpe was up with you, wasn t he? He married old Lord
Bolham s daughter. Very nice people in their way.
subQuotationList:
['I don t care much for shooting,', 'but one has to do
it, unless one wants to be altogether out of things. I dare say there s
some very pretty country round here. I stayed once at Bolham Hall.
Young Cranthorpe was up with you, wasn t he? He married old Lord
Bolham s daughter. Very nice people in their way.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I don t mix in that society,
subQuotationList: ['I don t mix in that society,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
Oh, but you should, It s well worth staying there,
anyhow, once a year. They make one very comfortable, and the women are
ravishing.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, but you should,', 'It s well worth staying there,\nanyhow, once a year. They make one very comfortable, and the women are\nravishing.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
The women? What could any
woman see in you?
subQuotationList: ['The women?', 'What could any\nwoman see in you?']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
I don t think I should get on in that society, I don t
think I should know what to say to Lady Rose if I met her.
subQuotationList: ['I don t think I should get on in that society,', 'I don t\nthink I should know what to say to Lady Rose if I met her.']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
I don t find any difficulty, You talk to them about
their children, if they have any, or their accomplishments painting,
gardening, poetry they re so delightfully sympathetic. Seriously, you
know I think a woman s opinion of one s poetry is always worth having.
Don t ask them for their reasons. Just ask them for their feelings.
Katharine, for example
subQuotationList:
['I don t find any difficulty,', 'You talk to them about
their children, if they have any, or their accomplishments painting,
gardening, poetry they re so delightfully sympathetic. Seriously, you
know I think a woman s opinion of one s poetry is always worth having.
Don t ask them for their reasons. Just ask them for their feelings.
Katharine, for example']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Katharine, Katharine is very unlike most women.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine,', 'Katharine is very unlike most women.']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Quite, She is
subQuotationList: ['Quite,', 'She is']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: She s looking very well,
subQuotationList: ['She s looking very well,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: But, as a family, you re given to moods, eh?
subQuotationList: ['But, as a family, you re given to moods, eh?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Not Katharine,
subQuotationList: ['Not Katharine,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Not Katharine,
subQuotationList: ['Not Katharine,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
No, perhaps you re right. But her engagement has changed her.
Naturally, one would expect that to be so.
subQuotationList: ['No, perhaps you re right. But her engagement has changed her.\nNaturally,', 'one would expect that to be so.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Katharine has had a difficult life, in some ways, I
expect that marriage will be good for her. She has great powers.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine has had a difficult life, in some ways,', 'I\nexpect that marriage will be good for her. She has great powers.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Great,
subQuotationList: ['Great,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Yes but now what direction d you think they take?
subQuotationList: ['Yes but now what direction d you think they take?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I don t know,
subQuotationList: ['I don t know,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
D you think children a household that sort of thing d you think
that ll satisfy her? Mind, I m out all day.
subQuotationList: ['D you think children a household that sort of thing d you think\nthat ll satisfy her? Mind, I m out all day.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: She would certainly be very competent,
subQuotationList: ['She would certainly be very competent,']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
Oh, she s wonderfully competent, But I get absorbed in
my poetry. Well, Katharine hasn t got that. She admires my poetry, you
know, but that wouldn t be enough for her?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, she s wonderfully competent,', 'But I get absorbed in\nmy poetry. Well, Katharine hasn t got that. She admires my poetry, you\nknow, but that wouldn t be enough for her?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: No,
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText:
I think you re right, Katharine hasn t found herself yet. Life
isn t altogether real to her yet I sometimes think
subQuotationList: ['I think you re right,', 'Katharine hasn t found herself yet. Life\nisn t altogether real to her yet I sometimes think']
speaker: Henry Otway

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: That is what I
subQuotationList: ['That is what I']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I wish you could help her to take an interest in something that other
people are interested in, Katharine, It s all Henry s doing, you know, giving up
her parties and taking to these nasty insects. It doesn t follow that
if a man can do a thing a woman may too.
subQuotationList:
['I wish you could help her to take an interest in something that other
people are interested in, Katharine,', 'It s all Henry s doing, you know, giving up
her parties and taking to these nasty insects. It doesn t follow that
if a man can do a thing a woman may too.']
speaker: Lady Otway
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Henry Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway']]]

quoteText:
It s so very pleasant, to knit while one s talking.
And now, my dear Katharine, tell me about your plans.
subQuotationList: ['It s so very pleasant,', 'to knit while one s talking.\nAnd now, my dear Katharine, tell me about your plans.']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: What a perfect daughter, or daughter-in-law!
subQuotationList: ['What a perfect daughter, or daughter-in-law!']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText:
Yes, Katharine is like
the girls of my youth. We took the serious things of life seriously.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'Katharine is like\nthe girls of my youth. We took the serious things of life seriously.']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText:
I never _shall_ know my way about this house! I m on
my way to the library, and I don t want to interrupt. You and Katharine
were having a little chat?
subQuotationList: ['I never _shall_ know my way about this house!', 'I m on\nmy way to the library, and I don t want to interrupt. You and Katharine\nwere having a little chat?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
I was telling Katharine a few little commonplaces about marriage, Are none of my children looking after you,
Maggie?
subQuotationList: ['I was telling Katharine a few little commonplaces about marriage,', 'Are none of my children looking after you,\nMaggie?']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText:
Marriage, I always say marriage is a school. And you don t
get the prizes unless you go to school. Charlotte has won all the
prizes,
subQuotationList: ['Marriage,', 'I always say marriage is a school. And you don t\nget the prizes unless you go to school. Charlotte has won all the\nprizes,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Aunt Charlotte was saying that it s no good being married unless you
submit to your husband,
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Charlotte was saying that it s no good being married unless you\nsubmit to your husband,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Well, I really don t advise a woman who wants to have things her own
way to get married,
subQuotationList: ['Well, I really don t advise a woman who wants to have things her own\nway to get married,']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: What a shame it was!
subQuotationList: ['What a shame it was!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
But, Charlotte, it
would have been much worse if Frank had disgraced himself in any way.
And it isn t what our husbands GET, but what they _are_. I used to
dream of white horses and palanquins, too; but still, I like the
ink-pots best. And who knows? your father may be made a baronet to-morrow.
subQuotationList:
['But, Charlotte, it
would have been much worse if Frank had disgraced himself in any way.
And it isn t what our husbands GET, but what they _are_. I used to
dream of white horses and palanquins, too; but still, I like the
ink-pots best. And who knows?', 'your father may be made a baronet to-morrow.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
But if you can give way to your husband, a
happy marriage is the happiest thing in the world.
subQuotationList: ['But if you can give way to your husband,', 'a\nhappy marriage is the happiest thing in the world.']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: Yes, but
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'but']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: We ve all had perfect husbands,
subQuotationList: ['We ve all had perfect husbands,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Not that I think a bad temper is
really a fault in a man. I don t mean a bad temper, I
should say a quick, impatient temper. Most, in fact _all_ great men
have had bad tempers except your grandfather, Katharine,
subQuotationList:
['Not that I think a bad temper is
really a fault in a man. I don t mean a bad temper,', 'I
should say a quick, impatient temper. Most, in fact _all_ great men
have had bad tempers except your grandfather, Katharine,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
But in the ordinary marriage, is it necessary to give way to one s
husband?
subQuotationList: ['But in the ordinary marriage, is it necessary to give way to one s\nhusband?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I should say yes, certainly,
subQuotationList: ['I should say yes, certainly,']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: Then one ought to make up one s mind to that before one is married,
subQuotationList: ['Then one ought to make up one s mind to that before one is married,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Do look at that lovely little blue bird!
subQuotationList: ['Do look at that lovely little blue bird!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Most women know by instinct whether they can give it or not, And if
not well then, my advice would be don t marry.
subQuotationList: ['Most women know by instinct whether they can give it or not,', 'And if\nnot well then, my advice would be don t marry.']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: Oh, but marriage is the happiest life for a woman,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, but marriage is the happiest life for a woman,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: It s the most _interesting_ life,
subQuotationList: ['It s the most _interesting_ life,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Why don t we all live in the country? I m sure one would think such
beautiful things if one lived in the country. No horrid slum houses to
depress one, no trams or motor-cars; and the people all looking so
plump and cheerful. Isn t there some little cottage near you,
Charlotte, which would do for us, with a spare room, perhaps, in case
we asked a friend down? And we should save so much money that we should
be able to travel
subQuotationList:
['Why don t we all live in the country?', 'I m sure one would think such
beautiful things if one lived in the country. No horrid slum houses to
depress one, no trams or motor-cars; and the people all looking so
plump and cheerful. Isn t there some little cottage near you,
Charlotte, which would do for us, with a spare room, perhaps, in case

speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']], [['Lady Otway'], ['Lady Otway'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery']]]

quoteText: Yes. You would find it very nice for a week or two, no doubt,
subQuotationList: ['Yes. You would find it very nice for a week or two, no doubt,']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: But what hour would you like the carriage this morning?
subQuotationList: ['But what hour would you like the carriage this morning?']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText:
Katharine shall decide, And I was just going to tell you,
Katharine, how, when I woke this morning, everything seemed so clear in
my head that if I d had a pencil I believe I could have written quite a
long chapter. When we re out on our drive I shall find us a house. A
few trees round it, and a little garden, a pond with a Chinese duck, a
study for your father, a study for me, and a sitting room for
Katharine, because then she ll be a married lady.
subQuotationList:
['Katharine shall decide,', 'And I was just going to tell you,
Katharine, how, when I woke this morning, everything seemed so clear in
my head that if I d had a pencil I believe I could have written quite a
long chapter. When we re out on our drive I shall find us a house. A
few trees round it, and a little garden, a pond with a Chinese duck, a

Katharine, because then she ll be a married lady.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: Let me look at your engagement-ring, Aunt Charlotte,
subQuotationList: ['Let me look at your engagement-ring, Aunt Charlotte,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
That poor old ring was a sad disappointment to me when I first had
it, I d set my heart on a diamond ring, but I never
liked to tell Frank, naturally. He bought it at Simla.
subQuotationList: ['That poor old ring was a sad disappointment to me when I first had\nit,', 'I d set my heart on a diamond ring, but I never\nliked to tell Frank, naturally. He bought it at Simla.']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText: Why didn t Andrews tell me himself?
subQuotationList: ['Why didn t Andrews tell me himself?']
speaker: Lady Otway

quoteText:
Do you know, Mary, I ve made up my
mind.
subQuotationList: ['Do you know, Mary,', 'I ve made up my\nmind.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I ve made up my mind to chuck my work and live down here. I want you
to tell me about that cottage you spoke of. However, I suppose there ll
be no difficulty about getting a cottage, will there?
subQuotationList: ['I ve made up my mind to chuck my work and live down here. I want you\nto tell me about that cottage you spoke of. However, I suppose there ll\nbe no difficulty about getting a cottage, will there?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I can t stand the office any longer, I don t know what
my family will say; but I m sure I m right. Don t you think so?
subQuotationList: ['I can t stand the office any longer,', 'I don t know what\nmy family will say; but I m sure I m right. Don t you think so?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Live down here by yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Live down here by yourself?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Some old woman would do for me, I suppose,
subQuotationList: ['Some old woman would do for me, I suppose,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I m sick of
the whole thing,
subQuotationList: ['I m sick of\nthe whole thing,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I tell you, Mary, it s utter destruction, working away, day after day,
at stuff that doesn t matter a damn to any one. I ve stood eight years
of it, and I m not going to stand it any longer. I suppose this all
seems to you mad, though?
subQuotationList:
['I tell you, Mary, it s utter destruction, working away, day after day,
at stuff that doesn t matter a damn to any one. I ve stood eight years
of it, and I m not going to stand it any longer. I suppose this all
seems to you mad, though?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: No. I thought you weren t happy,
subQuotationList: ['No. I thought you weren t happy,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Why did you think that?
subQuotationList: ['Why did you think that?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Don t you remember that morning in Lincoln s Inn Fields?
subQuotationList: ['Don t you remember that morning in Lincoln s Inn Fields?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You re right, Mary, though I
don t know how you guessed it.
subQuotationList: ['You re right, Mary,', 'though I\ndon t know how you guessed it.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I was unhappy very unhappy,
subQuotationList: ['I was unhappy very unhappy,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Unhappiness is a state of mind, by which I mean that it is
not necessarily the result of any particular cause.
subQuotationList: ['Unhappiness is a state of mind,', 'by which I mean that it is\nnot necessarily the result of any particular cause.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I began to find my life unsatisfactory, It seemed
to me meaningless.
subQuotationList: ['I began to find my life unsatisfactory,', 'It seemed\nto me meaningless.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
All this money-making and working ten hours a day in an office, what s
it FOR? When one s a boy, you see, one s head is so full of dreams that
it doesn t seem to matter what one does. And if you re ambitious,
you re all right; you ve got a reason for going on. Now my reasons
ceased to satisfy me. Perhaps I never had any. That s very likely now I
come to think of it. (What reason is there for anything, though?)
Still, it s impossible, after a certain age, to take oneself in
satisfactorily. And I know what carried me on
subQuotationList:
['All this money-making and working ten hours a day in an office, what s
it FOR? When one s a boy, you see, one s head is so full of dreams that
it doesn t seem to matter what one does. And if you re ambitious,
you re all right; you ve got a reason for going on. Now my reasons
ceased to satisfy me. Perhaps I never had any. That s very likely now I
come to think of it. (What reason is there for anything, though?)
Still, it s impossible, after a certain age, to take oneself in
satisfactorily. And I know what carried me on']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I wanted to be the savior of my family and all that
kind of thing. I wanted them to get on in the world. That was a lie, of
course a kind of self-glorification, too. Like most people, I suppose,
I ve lived almost entirely among delusions, and now I m at the awkward
stage of finding it out. I want another delusion to go on with. That s
what my unhappiness amounts to, Mary.
subQuotationList:
['I wanted to be the savior of my family and all that
kind of thing. I wanted them to get on in the world. That was a lie, of
course a kind of self-glorification, too. Like most people, I suppose,
I ve lived almost entirely among delusions, and now I m at the awkward
stage of finding it out. I want another delusion to go on with. That s
what my unhappiness amounts to, Mary.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I don t think it will be difficult to find a cottage,
subQuotationList: ['I don t think it will be difficult to find a cottage,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You ve got a
little money, haven t you? Yes, I don t see why it
shouldn t be a very good plan.
subQuotationList: ['You ve got a\nlittle money, haven t you? Yes,', 'I don t see why it\nshouldn t be a very good plan.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Yes, Ralph, it s time you made a break. I ve come to the same
conclusion myself. Only it won t be a country cottage in my case; it ll
be America. America! That s the place for me! They ll
teach me something about organizing a movement there, and I ll come
back and show you how to do it.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, Ralph, it s time you made a break. I ve come to the same
conclusion myself. Only it won t be a country cottage in my case; it ll
be America. America!', 'That s the place for me! They ll
teach me something about organizing a movement there, and I ll come
back and show you how to do it.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Don t go away, Mary!
subQuotationList: ['Don t go away, Mary!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
That s what you said before, Ralph, You want to go away yourself and you don t want me to go away.
That s not very sensible, is it?
subQuotationList: ['That s what you said before, Ralph,', 'You want to go away yourself and you don t want me to go away.\nThat s not very sensible, is it?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Mary, what a brute I ve been to you!
subQuotationList: ['Mary,', 'what a brute I ve been to you!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Katharine, Katharine,
subQuotationList: ['Katharine, Katharine,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Katharine, Katharine,
subQuotationList: ['Katharine, Katharine,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Now, Mary, what s all this about America?
subQuotationList: ['Now, Mary, what s all this about America?']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: he linked his arm through hers and said

quoteText: You must see that there s water,
subQuotationList: ['You must see that there s water,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
One of the rooms, must be my study, for, you see, Mary, I m
going to write a book.
subQuotationList: ['One of the rooms,', 'must be my study, for, you see, Mary, I m\ngoing to write a book.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: And what s your book to be about?
subQuotationList: ['And what s your book to be about?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Well, Mary?
subQuotationList: ['Well, Mary?']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: he turned just so and said

quoteText: How damnable this all is!
subQuotationList: ['How damnable this all is!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: What are you talking about?
subQuotationList: ['What are you talking about?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Mary, I want to talk to you. Haven t we nearly done? Why
don t they take away these plates?
subQuotationList: ['Mary,', 'I want to talk to you. Haven t we nearly done? Why\ndon t they take away these plates?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: They ll come all in good time,
subQuotationList: ['They ll come all in good time,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: I want to apologize,
subQuotationList: ['I want to apologize,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I think I ve treated you very badly. That is, I ve told you lies. Did
you guess that I was lying to you? Once in Lincoln s Inn Fields and
again to-day on our walk. I am a liar, Mary. Did you know that? Do you
think you do know me?
subQuotationList:
['I think I ve treated you very badly. That is, I ve told you lies. Did
you guess that I was lying to you? Once in Lincoln s Inn Fields and
again to-day on our walk. I am a liar, Mary. Did you know that? Do you
think you do know me?']
speaker: Ralph Denham
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet']]]

quoteText: I think I do,
subQuotationList: ['I think I do,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
It s true I don t want you to go to America, In fact, my feelings towards you seem to be
utterly and damnably bad,
subQuotationList: ['It s true I don t want you to go to America,', 'In fact, my feelings towards you seem to be\nutterly and damnably bad,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
If I weren t a selfish beast I should tell you to have nothing more to
do with me. And yet, Mary, in spite of the fact that I believe what I m
saying, I also believe that it s good we should know each other the
world being what it is, you see
subQuotationList:
['If I weren t a selfish beast I should tell you to have nothing more to
do with me. And yet, Mary, in spite of the fact that I believe what I m
saying, I also believe that it s good we should know each other the
world being what it is, you see']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
for, of course, in an ideal state of
things, in a decent community even, there s no doubt you shouldn t have
anything to do with me seriously, that is.
subQuotationList: ['for, of course, in an ideal state of\nthings, in a decent community even, there s no doubt you shouldn t have\nanything to do with me seriously, that is.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You forget that I m not an ideal character, either,
subQuotationList: ['You forget that I m not an ideal character, either,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I m much more selfish than I let on, and I m worldly a little more
than you think, anyhow. I like bossing things perhaps that s my
greatest fault. I ve none of your passion for
subQuotationList: ['I m much more selfish than I let on, and I m worldly a little more\nthan you think, anyhow. I like bossing things perhaps that s my\ngreatest fault. I ve none of your passion for']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
for the
truth,
subQuotationList: ['for the\ntruth,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: I ve told you I m a liar,
subQuotationList: ['I ve told you I m a liar,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Oh, in little things, I dare say, But not in
real ones, and that s what matters. I dare say I m more truthful than
you are in small ways. But I could never care for any one who was a liar in that way. I love the truth a certain
amount a considerable amount but not in the way you love it.
subQuotationList:

real ones, and that s what matters. I dare say I m more truthful than
you are in small ways. But I could never care', 'for any one who was a liar in that way. I love the truth a certain

quoteText:
Good heavens! She loves me! Why did I
never see it before? She s going to cry; no, but she can t speak.
subQuotationList: ['Good heavens!', 'She loves me! Why did I\nnever see it before? She s going to cry; no, but she can t speak.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: That was Katharine Hilbery.
subQuotationList: ['That was Katharine Hilbery.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: He sat down at once and said

quoteText: Katharine Hilbery? What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['Katharine Hilbery? What do you mean?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Katharine Hilbery, But she s gone now.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine Hilbery,', 'But she s gone now.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Katharine Hilbery! I ve always known it was Katharine Hilbery!
subQuotationList: ['Katharine Hilbery!', 'I ve always known it was Katharine Hilbery!']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I m not mistaken? Surely Mr. Denham? I caught a glimpse of your coat
through the window, and I felt sure that I knew your coat. Have you
seen Katharine or William? I m wandering about Lincoln looking for the
ruins.
subQuotationList:
['I m not mistaken? Surely Mr. Denham? I caught a glimpse of your coat
through the window, and I felt sure that I knew your coat. Have you
seen Katharine or William? I m wandering about Lincoln looking for the
ruins.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
First of all, tell me where I am, The ruins my party is
waiting for me at the ruins. The Roman ruins or Greek, Mr. Denham? Your
town has a great many beautiful things in it, but I wish it hadn t so
many ruins. I never saw such delightful little pots of honey in my
life are they made by your own bees? Please give me one of those little
pots, and tell me how I shall find my way to the ruins.
subQuotationList:
['First of all, tell me where I am,', 'The ruins my party is
waiting for me at the ruins. The Roman ruins or Greek, Mr. Denham? Your
town has a great many beautiful things in it, but I wish it hadn t so
many ruins. I never saw such delightful little pots of honey in my
life are they made by your own bees? Please give me one of those little
pots, and tell me how I shall find my way to the ruins.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: And now,
subQuotationList: ['And now,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Now, please tell me what you re
doing here, Mr. Denham for you _are_ Mr. Denham, aren t you? The brilliant young man who writes for the Review, I mean? Only
yesterday my husband was telling me he thought you one of the cleverest
young men he knew. Certainly, you ve been the messenger of Providence
to me, for unless I d seen you I m sure I should never have found the
ruins at all.
subQuotationList:
['Now,', 'please tell me what you re

yesterday my husband was telling me he thought you one of the cleverest

quoteText:
I ve found something much better than ruins! I ve
found two friends who told me how to find you, which I could never have
done without them. They must come and have tea with us. What a pity
that we ve just had luncheon.
subQuotationList:
['I ve found something much better than ruins!', 'I ve
found two friends who told me how to find you, which I could never have

quoteText:
I never knew you lived here. Why didn t you say so, and we could have
met? And are you staying with Mary? What a pity we didn t meet before.
subQuotationList: ['I never knew you lived here. Why didn t you say so, and we could have\nmet? And are you staying with Mary?', 'What a pity we didn t meet before.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Do you know, I thought I saw you this morning, standing at a window.
But I decided that it couldn t be you. And it must have been you all
the same.
subQuotationList: ['Do you know,', 'I thought I saw you this morning, standing at a window.\nBut I decided that it couldn t be you. And it must have been you all\nthe same.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Yes, I thought I saw you but it wasn t you,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I thought I saw you but it wasn t you,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I expect it was me, I was looking for my mother. It
happens every time we come to Lincoln. In fact, there never was a
family so unable to take care of itself as ours is. Not that it very
much matters, because some one always turns up in the nick of time to
help us out of our scrapes. Once I was left in a field with a bull when
I was a baby but where did we leave the carriage? Down that street or
the next? The next, I think.
subQuotationList:
['I expect it was me,', 'I was looking for my mother. It
happens every time we come to Lincoln. In fact, there never was a
family so unable to take care of itself as ours is. Not that it very

I was a baby but where did we leave the carriage? Down that street or
the next? The next, I think.']

quoteText: But what are you doing here?
subQuotationList: ['But what are you doing here?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I m buying a cottage. I m going to live here as soon as I can find a
cottage, and Mary tells me there ll be no difficulty about that.
subQuotationList: ['I m buying a cottage. I m going to live here as soon as I can find a\ncottage, and Mary tells me there ll be no difficulty about that.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
But, you will
give up the Bar, then?
subQuotationList: ['But,', 'you will\ngive up the Bar, then?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: The solicitor s office? Yes. I m giving that up.
subQuotationList: ['The solicitor s office? Yes. I m giving that up.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But why?
subQuotationList: ['But why?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I think you re
very wise to give it up. You will be much happier.
subQuotationList: ['I think you re\nvery wise to give it up. You will be much happier.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t know what one means by happiness, Why do you think I
shall be happy? I don t expect to be anything of the kind. I expect to
be rather less unhappy. I shall write a book and curse my charwoman if
happiness consists in that. What do you think?
subQuotationList:
['I don t know what one means by happiness,', 'Why do you think I
shall be happy? I don t expect to be anything of the kind. I expect to
be rather less unhappy. I shall write a book and curse my charwoman if
happiness consists in that. What do you think?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Henry is going to drive home with your mother, and I suggest that they
should put us down half-way and let us walk back.
subQuotationList: ['Henry is going to drive home with your mother, and I suggest that they\nshould put us down half-way and let us walk back.']
speaker: William Rodney
referringExpression: Rodney went up to Katharine immediately and said to her

quoteText:
Unfortunately we go in opposite directions, or we might have given you
a lift,
subQuotationList: ['Unfortunately we go in opposite directions, or we might have given you\na lift,']
speaker: William Rodney
