quoteText:
I want to see you. Are you going back to London at once? I will
write.
subQuotationList: ['I want to see you. Are you going back to London at once? I will\nwrite.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: She at once helped her mother into her cloak and said to Mary

quoteText: There s no need for us to race,
subQuotationList: ['There s no need for us to race,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I ve not enjoyed my holiday.
subQuotationList: ['I ve not enjoyed my holiday.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: No?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No. I shall be glad to get back to work again.
subQuotationList: ['No. I shall be glad to get back to work again.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Saturday, Sunday, Monday there are only three days more,
subQuotationList: ['Saturday, Sunday, Monday there are only three days more,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No one enjoys being made a fool of before other people,
subQuotationList: ['No one enjoys being made a fool of before other people,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: That refers to me, I suppose,
subQuotationList: ['That refers to me, I suppose,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Every day since we ve been here you ve done something to make me
appear ridiculous, Of course, so long as it amuses you,
you re welcome; but we have to remember that we are going to spend our
lives together. I asked you, only this morning, for example, to come
out and take a turn with me in the garden. I was waiting for you ten
minutes, and you never came. Every one saw me waiting. The stable-boys
saw me. I was so ashamed that I went in. Then, on the drive you hardly
spoke to me. Henry noticed it. Every one notices it.... You find no
difficulty in talking to Henry, though.
subQuotationList:
['Every day since we ve been here you ve done something to make me
appear ridiculous,', 'Of course, so long as it amuses you,
you re welcome; but we have to remember that we are going to spend our

spoke to me. Henry noticed it. Every one notices it.... You find no
difficulty in talking to Henry, though.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: None of these things seem to me to matter,

speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Very well, then. I may as well hold my tongue,

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
In themselves they don t seem to me to matter; if they hurt you, of
course they matter,
subQuotationList: ['In themselves they don t seem to me to matter; if they hurt you, of\ncourse they matter,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And we might be so happy, Katharine!
subQuotationList: ['And we might be so happy, Katharine!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: As long as you let yourself feel like this we shall never be happy,
subQuotationList: ['As long as you let yourself feel like this we shall never be happy,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: What do I feel about Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['What do I feel about Katharine?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
If she were callous all the time and had only led me on to laugh at me
I couldn t have felt that about her, I m not a fool,
after all. I can t have been utterly mistaken all these years. And yet,
when she speaks to me like that! The truth of it is, that
I ve got such despicable faults that no one could help speaking to me
like that. Katharine is quite right. And yet those are not my serious
feelings, as she knows quite well. How can I change myself? What would
make her care for me?
subQuotationList:
['If she were callous all the time and had only led me on to laugh at me
I couldn t have felt that about her,', 'I m not a fool,

quoteText:
If you have no feeling for me, wouldn t it be kinder to say so to me
in private?
subQuotationList: ['If you have no feeling for me, wouldn t it be kinder to say so to me\nin private?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Oh, William, how you go on about feelings! Isn t it better not to
talk so much, not to be worrying always about small things that don t
really matter?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, William,', 'how you go on about feelings! Isn t it better not to\ntalk so much, not to be worrying always about small things that don t\nreally matter?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
That s the question precisely, I only want you to tell
me that they don t matter. There are times when you seem indifferent to
everything. I m vain, I ve a thousand faults; but you know they re not
everything; you know I care for you.
subQuotationList:
['That s the question precisely,', 'I only want you to tell
me that they don t matter. There are times when you seem indifferent to
everything. I m vain, I ve a thousand faults; but you know they re not
everything; you know I care for you.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: And if I say that I care for you, don t you believe me?
subQuotationList: ['And if I say that I care for you, don t you believe me?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Say it, Katharine! Say it as if you meant it! Make me feel that you
care for me!
subQuotationList: ['Say it, Katharine! Say it as if you meant it! Make me feel that you\ncare for me!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I was wrong to get engaged to you. I shall never make you happy. I
have never loved you.
subQuotationList: ['I was wrong to get engaged to you. I shall never make you happy. I\nhave never loved you.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

subQuotationList: ['You love some one else?']

quoteText: Absolutely no one.
subQuotationList: ['Absolutely no one.']

quoteText: Henry?

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: If I could, I would,
subQuotationList: ['If I could, I would,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Why did you tell me you would marry me, then?
subQuotationList: ['Why did you tell me you would marry me, then?']

quoteText: But you re not a child you re not a woman of moods,
subQuotationList: ['But you re not a child you re not a woman of moods,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: You couldn t have accepted me if you hadn t loved me!
subQuotationList: ['You couldn t have accepted me if you hadn t loved me!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I did say I would marry you, but it was wrong, for I don t love you,
William; you ve noticed it, every one s noticed it; why should we go on
pretending? When I told you I loved you, I was wrong. I said what I
knew to be untrue.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
When did you begin to feel this, Katharine? for it isn t
true to say that you ve always felt it. I admit I was unreasonable the
first night when you found that your clothes had been left behind.
Still, where s the fault in that? I could promise you never to
interfere with your clothes again. I admit I was cross when I found you
upstairs with Henry. Perhaps I showed it too openly. But that s not
unreasonable either when one s engaged. Ask your mother. And now this
terrible thing This decision you say you ve come to have you discussed it
with any one? Your mother, for example, or Henry?

quoteText: Help me to understand you

quoteText:
You don t understand, I mean, my real feelings; how could you? I ve
only now faced them myself. But I haven t got the sort of feeling love,
I mean I don t know what to call it

quoteText:
but, anyhow, without it our marriage would be
a farce
subQuotationList: ['but, anyhow, without it our marriage would be\na farce']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: How a farce?
subQuotationList: ['How a farce?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: But this kind of analysis is disastrous!
subQuotationList: ['But this kind of analysis is disastrous!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I should have done it before,
subQuotationList: ['I should have done it before,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You make yourself think things you don t think, Believe me,
Katharine, before we came here we were perfectly happy. You were full
of plans for our house the chair-covers, don t you remember? like any
other woman who is about to be married. Now, for no reason whatever,
you begin to fret about your feeling and about my feeling, with the
usual result. I assure you, Katharine, I ve been through it all myself.
At one time I was always asking myself absurd questions which came to
nothing either. What you want, if I may say so, is some occupation to
take you out of yourself when this morbid mood comes on. If it hadn t
been for my poetry, I assure you, I should often have been very much in
the same state myself. To let you into a secret, I ve often gone
home from seeing you in such a state of nerves that I had to force
myself to write a page or two before I could get you out of my head.
Ask Denham; he ll tell you how he met me one night; he ll tell you what
a state he found me in.

['You make yourself think things you don t think,', 'Believe me,

of plans for our house the chair-covers, don t you remember? like any

you begin to fret about your feeling and about my feeling, with the

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
A farce, a farce, She
said that our marriage would be a farce,
subQuotationList: ['A farce, a farce,', 'She\nsaid that our marriage would be a farce,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: William, I will marry you. I will try to make you happy.
subQuotationList: ['William,', 'I will marry you. I will try to make you happy.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
What I was going to say when we were interrupted at lunch was that if
you go to America I shall come, too. It can t be harder to earn a
living there than it is here. However, that s not the point. The point
is, Mary, that I want to marry you. Well, what do you say?
subQuotationList:
['What I was going to say when we were interrupted at lunch was that if
you go to America I shall come, too. It can t be harder to earn a
living there than it is here. However, that s not the point. The point

speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: Ralph made her start by saying

You know me by
this time, the good and the bad, You know my tempers.
I ve tried to let you know my faults. Well, what do you say, Mary?
subQuotationList: ['You know me by\nthis time, the good and the bad,', 'You know my tempers.\nI ve tried to let you know my faults. Well, what do you say, Mary?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
In most ways, at least in the important ways, as you said, we know
each other and we think alike. I believe you are the only person in the
world I could live with happily. And if you feel the same about me as
you do, don t you, Mary? we should make each other happy.

quoteText: You couldn t do it?
subQuotationList: ['You couldn t do it?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: No, I couldn t marry you,

for I thought you did.

I don t
believe you, Mary. You re not telling me the truth.

quoteText:

want to marry you.

quoteText:
Haven t I always been thinking of Katharine while I was with Mary? I
might have loved Mary if it hadn t been for that idiocy of mine. She
cared for me once, I m certain of that, but I tormented her so with my
humors that I let my chances slip, and now she won t risk marrying me.
And this is what I ve made of my life nothing, nothing, nothing.

And this is what I ve made of my life nothing, nothing, nothing.']

quoteText:
If you don t want to marry me, there is no need why we should
cease to see each other, is there? Or would you rather that we should
keep apart for the present?
subQuotationList: ['If you don t want to marry me,', 'there is no need why we should\ncease to see each other, is there? Or would you rather that we should\nkeep apart for the present?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Keep apart? I don t know I must think about it.

quoteText:
Tell me one thing, Mary, have I done anything to make
you change your mind about me?

speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:

least.

speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Oh, it has come to this to
this when I could have given him everything!

quoteText: Yes, we can still be friends,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, we can still be friends,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: I shall want your friendship,
subQuotationList: ['I shall want your friendship,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:

shall want your help.
subQuotationList: ['If you find it\npossible, let me see you as often as you can. The oftener the better. I\nshall want your help.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You asked me if I had changed my mind about you, Ralph, I
think there s only one thing. When you asked me to marry you, I don t
think you meant it. That made me angry for the moment. Before, you d
always spoken the truth.

quoteText: I never said I loved you,
subQuotationList: ['I never said I loved you,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: And to me marriage without love doesn t seem worth while,
subQuotationList: ['And to me marriage without love doesn t seem worth while,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Well, Mary, I m not going to press you, I see you don t
want to marry me. But love don t we all talk a great deal of nonsense
about it? What does one mean? I believe I care for you more genuinely
than nine men out of ten care for the women they re in love with. It s
only a story one makes up in one s mind about another person, and one
knows all the time it isn t true. Of course one knows; why, one s
always taking care not to destroy the illusion. One takes care not to
see them too often, or to be alone with them for too long together.
It s a pleasant illusion, but if you re thinking of the risks of
marriage, it seems to me that the risk of marrying a person you re in
love with is something colossal.

understand.

quoteText: I doubt that one human being ever understands another,

quoteText:
Such damned liars as we all are, how can we? But we can try. If you
don t want to marry me, don t; but the position you take up about love,
and not seeing each other isn t that mere sentimentality? You think
I ve behaved very badly, Of
course I behave badly; but you can t judge people by what they do. You
can t go through life measuring right and wrong with a foot-rule.
That s what you re always doing, Mary; that s what you re doing now.

quoteText:
The simple elementary acts of justice, are as far beyond
them as they ever were. We can only look upon ourselves, Mary, as
pioneers in a wilderness. We can only go on patiently putting the truth
before them. It isn t _them_, it s their leaders. It s those gentlemen sitting
in Parliament and drawing four hundred a year of the people s money. If
we had to put our case to the people, we should soon have justice done
to us. I have always believed in the people, and I do so still. But
subQuotationList:

mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mary Datchet', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton']], [['Mary Datchet', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton']]]

quoteText:
We must try to consider ourselves rather in the light of a telephone
exchange for the exchange of ideas, Miss Datchet, We should consider ourselves
the center of an enormous system of wires, connecting us up with every
district of the country. We must have our fingers upon the pulse of the
community; we want to know what people all over England are thinking;
we want to put them in the way of thinking rightly.
subQuotationList:

quoteText:
To last a lifetime? My dear child, it will last all our lifetimes. As
one falls another steps into the breach. My father, in his generation,
a pioneer I, coming after him, do my little best. What, alas! can one
do more? And now it s you young women we look to you the future looks
to you. Ah, my dear, if I d a thousand lives, I d give them all to our
cause. The cause of women, d you say? I say the cause of humanity. And
there are some who don t see it!
There are some who are satisfied to go on, year after year, refusing to
admit the truth. And we who have the vision the kettle boiling over?
No, no, let me see to it we who know the truth,

opinion. The British public likes a pellet of reason in its jam of
eloquence a pill of reason in its pudding of sentiment,

It came over me in the Tube the other day, what is it that makes these people go one way rather than the other?

such thing as affection in itself....

subQuotationList: ['There are so many things that she doesn t understand,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I ve got a piece of news for you, Katharine, I shan t get my holiday in April. We shall have to
put off our marriage.
subQuotationList: ['I ve got a piece of news for you, Katharine,', 'I shan t get my holiday in April. We shall have to\nput off our marriage.']

That won t make any difference, will it? I mean the lease isn t
signed, But why? What has happened?
subQuotationList: ['That won t make any difference, will it? I mean the lease isn t\nsigned,', 'But why? What has happened?']

speaker: Katharine Hilbery

It ll mean, too, I m afraid, that I shan t be as free for a

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Where should I address a letter to Cassandra?
subQuotationList: ['Where should I address a letter to Cassandra?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: We ve struck up a friendship,
subQuotationList: ['We ve struck up a friendship,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: She s at home, I think,
subQuotationList: ['She s at home, I think,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
They keep her too much at home, Why don t you ask her
to stay with you, and let her hear a little good music? I ll just
finish what I was saying, if you don t mind, because I m particularly
anxious that she should hear to-morrow.
subQuotationList:

Style, you know, is what we tend
to neglect

quoteText:
No, I m not going to write any more to-night, I m not in

I m not so sure about that. I should say she has a good deal of

quoteText:
Perhaps, You ve been neglecting my

choose a book.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps,', 'You ve been neglecting my\neducation lately, by the way. I wish you d read something. Let me\nchoose a book.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Swift, Let us have some Swift.
subQuotationList: ['Swift,', 'Let us have some Swift.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I think it s a little odd, don t you? Most people, I mean, would be seriously upset if their
marriage was put off for six months or so. But we aren t; now how do
you account for that?
subQuotationList: ['I think it s a little odd, don t you?', 'Most people, I mean, would be seriously upset if their\nmarriage was put off for six months or so. But we aren t; now how do\nyou account for that?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I attribute it, to
the fact that neither of us is in the least romantic about the other.
That may be partly, no doubt, because we ve known each other so long;
but I m inclined to think there s more in it than that. There s
something temperamental. I think you re a trifle cold, and I suspect
I m a trifle self-absorbed. If that were so it goes a long way to
explaining our odd lack of illusion about each other. I m not saying
that the most satisfactory marriages aren t founded upon this sort of
understanding. But certainly it struck me as odd this morning, when
Wilson told me, how little upset I felt. By the way, you re sure we
haven t committed ourselves to that house?
subQuotationList:
['I attribute it,', 'to
the fact that neither of us is in the least romantic about the other.
That may be partly, no doubt, because we ve known each other so long;
but I m inclined to think there s more in it than that. There s
something temperamental. I think you re a trifle cold, and I suspect
I m a trifle self-absorbed. If that were so it goes a long way to
explaining our odd lack of illusion about each other. I m not saying
that the most satisfactory marriages aren t founded upon this sort of
understanding. But certainly it struck me as odd this morning, when
Wilson told me, how little upset I felt. By the way, you re sure we
haven t committed ourselves to that house?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I ve kept the letters, and I ll go through them to-morrow; but I m
certain we re on the safe side.
subQuotationList: ['I ve kept the letters, and I ll go through them to-morrow; but I m\ncertain we re on the safe side.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Thanks. As to the psychological problem, there s no doubt, I think,
that either of us is capable of feeling what, for reasons of
simplicity, I call romance for a third person at least, I ve little
doubt in my own case.
subQuotationList:
['Thanks. As to the psychological problem,', 'there s no doubt, I think,
that either of us is capable of feeling what, for reasons of

subQuotationList: ['What is this romance?']

quoteText:
Ah, that s the question. I ve never come across a definition that
satisfied me, though there are some very good ones
subQuotationList: ['Ah, that s the question. I ve never come across a definition that\nsatisfied me, though there are some very good ones']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: It s not altogether knowing the other person, perhaps it s ignorance,
subQuotationList: ['It s not altogether knowing the other person, perhaps it s ignorance,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Some authorities say it s a question of distance romance in
literature, that is
subQuotationList: ['Some authorities say it s a question of distance romance in\nliterature, that is']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Possibly, in the case of art. But in the case of people it may be
subQuotationList: ['Possibly, in the case of art. But in the case of people it may be']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Have you no personal experience of it?
subQuotationList: ['Have you no personal experience of it?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I believe it s influenced me enormously, but
in my life there s so little scope for it,
subQuotationList: ['I believe it s influenced me enormously,', 'but\nin my life there s so little scope for it,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But isn t it curious, that you should neither feel
it for me, nor I for you?
subQuotationList: ['But isn t it curious,', 'that you should neither feel\nit for me, nor I for you?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I think you might be very happy with some one you loved in that way,
subQuotationList: ['I think you might be very happy with some one you loved in that way,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You assume that romance survives a closer knowledge of the person one

subQuotationList: ['You assume that romance survives a closer knowledge of the person one\nloves?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I don t see why it shouldn t last with you, I can
imagine a certain sort of person
subQuotationList: ['I don t see why it shouldn t last with you,', 'I can\nimagine a certain sort of person']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
A person, like Cassandra Otway, for instance. Cassandra is the
most interesting of the Otways with the exception of Henry. Even so, I
like Cassandra better. She has more than mere cleverness. She is a
character a person by herself.
subQuotationList:

quoteText: Those dreadful insects!
subQuotationList: ['Those dreadful insects!']

subQuotationList:

that she confined herself to to something else.... But she cares for

Extremely affectionate. She worships Henry. When you think what a

My dear, I feel a thousand things every second. I don t know, I m
sure, what I feel. That afternoon on the heath it was then then

Your ghastly
good sense, as usual, has convinced me for the moment but what the
truth is, Heaven only knows!

quoteText: I believe you re right, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['I believe you re right, Katharine.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Katharine, I worship you,
subQuotationList: ['Katharine, I worship you,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Yes, but you must
open the door.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'but you must\nopen the door.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I d rather live here than anywhere in the whole of London,
subQuotationList: ['I d rather live here than anywhere in the whole of London,']

quoteText: And I ve got nowhere to live
subQuotationList: ['And I ve got nowhere to live']

subQuotationList: ['You could get rooms here, no doubt, if you wanted to,']

But I m just leaving London for good I ve taken that cottage I was

Indeed? that s sad.... You must give me your address. But you won t

quoteText:
Should you mind if we walked a little farther? There s
something I want to say to you.
subQuotationList: ['Should you mind if we walked a little farther?', 'There s\nsomething I want to say to you.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Very well,
subQuotationList: ['Very well,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: It s quieter by the river,
subQuotationList: ['It s quieter by the river,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I
want to ask you merely this,
subQuotationList: ['I\nwant to ask you merely this,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

subQuotationList: ['I ve made you my standard ever since I saw you. I ve dreamt about you;\nI ve thought of nothing but you; you represent to me the only reality\nin the world.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
And now things have come to such a pass that, unless I can speak to
you openly, I believe I shall go mad. I think of you as the most
beautiful, the truest thing in the world,
subQuotationList: ['And now things have come to such a pass that, unless I can speak to\nyou openly, I believe I shall go mad. I think of you as the most\nbeautiful, the truest thing in the world,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

I see you everywhere, in the stars, in the river; to me you re
everything that exists; the reality of everything. Life, I tell you,
would be impossible without you. And now I want
subQuotationList: ['I see you everywhere, in the stars, in the river; to me you re\neverything that exists; the reality of everything. Life, I tell you,\nwould be impossible without you. And now I want']

I don t understand, You re saying things that you don t
mean.

speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I mean every word I say,
subQuotationList: ['I mean every word I say,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

subQuotationList: ['I saw Mary Datchet this afternoon,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No!

quoteText:
I did though. It was the day I saw you at Lincoln, I
had meant to ask her to marry me, and then I looked out of the window
and saw you. After that I didn t want to ask any one to marry me. But I
did it; and she knew I was lying, and refused me. I thought then, and
still think, that she cares for me. I behaved very badly. I don t
defend myself.
subQuotationList:

No, I should hope not. There s no defence that I can

subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I should hope not. There s no defence that I can\nthink of. If any conduct is wrong, that is.']

quoteText:
It seems
to me, that people are bound to
be honest. There s no excuse for such behavior.
subQuotationList: ['It seems\nto me,', 'that people are bound to\nbe honest. There s no excuse for such behavior.']

I am not telling you that I am in love with you. I am not in love with
you.
subQuotationList: ['I am not telling you that I am in love with you. I am not in love with\nyou.']

quoteText: I didn t think that,
subQuotationList: ['I didn t think that,']

quoteText: I have not spoken a word to you that I do not mean,
subQuotationList: ['I have not spoken a word to you that I do not mean,']

subQuotationList: ['Tell me then what it is that you mean,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You say that we ve got to be honest, Very well. I will
try to tell you the facts; but I warn you, you ll think me mad. It s a
fact, though, that since I first saw you four or five months ago I have
made you, in an utterly absurd way, I expect, my ideal. I m almost
ashamed to tell you what lengths I ve gone to. It s become the thing
that matters most in my life. Without knowing
you, except that you re beautiful, and all that, I ve come to believe
that we re in some sort of agreement; that we re after something
together; that we see something.... I ve got into the habit of
imagining you; I m always thinking what you d say or do; I walk along
the street talking to you; I dream of you. It s merely a bad habit, a
schoolboy habit, day-dreaming; it s a common experience; half one s
friends do the same; well, those are the facts.

quoteText: Kew,

quoteText:
My dear, I m not talking about _your_ William, though that s another
reason for liking him. I m talking, I m thinking, I m dreaming of _my_
William William Shakespeare, of course. Isn t it odd, that for all
one can see, that dear old thing in the blue bonnet, crossing the road
with her basket on her arm, has never heard that there was such a
person? Yet it all goes on: lawyers hurrying to their work, cabmen
squabbling for their fares, little boys rolling their hoops, little
girls throwing bread to the gulls, as if there weren t a Shakespeare in
the world. I should like to stand at that crossing all day long and
say:  People, read Shakespeare!
subQuotationList:
['My dear, I m not talking about _your_ William, though that s another
reason for liking him. I m talking, I m thinking, I m dreaming of _my_
William William Shakespeare, of course. Isn t it odd,', 'that for all
one can see, that dear old thing in the blue bonnet, crossing the road
with her basket on her arm, has never heard that there was such a
person? Yet it all goes on: lawyers hurrying to their work, cabmen
squabbling for their fares, little boys rolling their hoops, little
girls throwing bread to the gulls, as if there weren t a Shakespeare in
the world. I should like to stand at that crossing all day long and
say:  People, read Shakespeare!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Katharine! I ve hit upon a brilliant idea! to
lay out, say, a hundred pounds or so on copies of Shakespeare, and give
them to working men. Some of your clever friends who get up meetings
might help us, Katharine. And that might lead to a playhouse, where we
could all take parts. You d be Rosalind but you ve a dash of the old
nurse in you. Your father s Hamlet, come to years of discretion; and
I m well, I m a bit of them all; I m quite a large bit of the fool, but
the fools in Shakespeare say all the clever things. Now who shall
William be? A hero? Hotspur? Henry the Fifth? No, William s got a touch
of Hamlet in him, too. I can fancy that William talks to himself when
he s alone. Ah, Katharine, you must say very beautiful things when
you re together!
subQuotationList:
['Katharine! I ve hit upon a brilliant idea!', 'to
lay out, say, a hundred pounds or so on copies of Shakespeare, and give
them to working men. Some of your clever friends who get up meetings
might help us, Katharine. And that might lead to a playhouse, where we
could all take parts. You d be Rosalind but you ve a dash of the old
nurse in you. Your father s Hamlet, come to years of discretion; and
I m well, I m a bit of them all; I m quite a large bit of the fool, but
the fools in Shakespeare say all the clever things. Now who shall
William be? A hero? Hotspur? Henry the Fifth? No, William s got a touch
of Hamlet in him, too. I can fancy that William talks to himself when
he s alone. Ah, Katharine, you must say very beautiful things when
you re together!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: Oh, we talk a lot of nonsense,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, we talk a lot of nonsense,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: It won t seem to you nonsense in ten years  time,
subQuotationList: ['It won t seem to you nonsense in ten years  time,']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
Believe me, Katharine, you ll look back on these days afterwards;
you ll remember all the silly things you ve said; and you ll find that
your life has been built on them. The best of life is built on what we
say when we re in love. It isn t nonsense, Katharine, it s
the truth, it s the only truth.
subQuotationList:
['Believe me, Katharine, you ll look back on these days afterwards;
you ll remember all the silly things you ve said; and you ll find that
your life has been built on them. The best of life is built on what we
say when we re in love. It isn t nonsense, Katharine,', 'it s
the truth, it s the only truth.']

quoteText:
Ah I half wish I d called you Mary, but it wouldn t have gone with
Hilbery, and it wouldn t have gone with Rodney. Now this isn t the
passage I wanted. (I never can find what I want.) But it s spring; it s
the daffodils; it s the green fields; it s the birds.
subQuotationList:
['Ah I half wish I d called you Mary, but it wouldn t have gone with

friends wants cheering up? Who feels that they ve been forgotten and

was somebody I know

quoteText:
Here, is the original manuscript of the  Ode
to Winter.  The early manuscripts are far less corrected than the later
ones, as you will see directly.... Oh, do take it yourself,
subQuotationList: ['Here,', 'is the original manuscript of the  Ode\nto Winter.  The early manuscripts are far less corrected than the later\nones, as you will see directly.... Oh, do take it yourself,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You are wonderfully like your grandfather, Miss Hilbery, especially about
the eyes. Come, now, I expect she writes poetry herself, doesn t she? Quite one s ideal of
a poet, is it not, Mr. Rodney? I cannot tell you what a privilege I
feel it to be standing just here with the poet s granddaughter. You
must know we think a great deal of your grandfather in America, Miss
Hilbery. We have societies for reading him aloud. What! His very own
slippers!
subQuotationList:
['You are wonderfully like your grandfather, Miss Hilbery,', 'especially about

example if she really cares for that sort of thing.
subQuotationList: ['I see no harm,', 'in helping her with Greek, for\nexample if she really cares for that sort of thing.']

quoteText: There s no reason why she shouldn t care, In fact ah, here it is Obviously she does care.
subQuotationList: ['There s no reason why she shouldn t care,', 'In fact ah, here it is', 'Obviously she does care.']

quoteText:
Well, Greek may be rather a large order. I was thinking chiefly of
English. Her criticisms of my play, though they re too generous,
evidently immature she can t be more than twenty-two, I suppose? they
certainly show the sort of thing one wants: real feeling for poetry,
understanding, not formed, of course, but it s at the root of
everything after all. There d be no harm in lending her books?
subQuotationList:
['Well, Greek may be rather a large order. I was thinking chiefly of
English. Her criticisms of my play, though they re too generous,
evidently immature she can t be more than twenty-two, I suppose? they
certainly show the sort of thing one wants: real feeling for poetry,
understanding, not formed, of course, but it s at the root of
everything after all. There d be no harm in lending her books?']

quoteText: No. Certainly not.
subQuotationList: ['No. Certainly not.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But if it hum led to a correspondence? I mean, Katharine, I take it,
without going into matters which seem to me a little morbid, I mean, you, from your point of view, feel that there s nothing
disagreeable to you in the notion? If so, you ve only to speak, and I
never think of it again.
subQuotationList:

The best of all my treasures, Mr. Pelham! Don t move,

quoteText:
As I told you last night, I think it s your duty, if
there s a chance that you care for Cassandra, to discover what your
feeling is for her now. It s your duty to her, as well as to me. But we
must tell my mother. We can t go on pretending.
subQuotationList:
['As I told you last night,', 'I think it s your duty, if
there s a chance that you care for Cassandra, to discover what your
feeling is for her now. It s your duty to her, as well as to me. But we

quoteText:
But, Katharine, if Cassandra should

quoteText:
I m to give up my freedom for an indefinite time, in
order that William may see Cassandra here at his ease. He s not the
courage to manage it without my help he s too much of a coward to tell
me openly what he wants. He hates the notion of a public breach. He
wants to keep us both.
subQuotationList:
['I m to give up my freedom for an indefinite time,', 'in
order that William may see Cassandra here at his ease. He s not the
courage to manage it without my help he s too much of a coward to tell

speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I leave you, then, to tell your
mother that our engagement is ended by your desire.
subQuotationList: ['I leave you, then,', 'to tell your\nmother that our engagement is ended by your desire.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: You don t trust me?
subQuotationList: ['You don t trust me?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I do, absolutely,
subQuotationList: ['I do, absolutely,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: No. You don t trust me to help you.... I could help you?
subQuotationList: ['No. You don t trust me to help you.... I could help you?']

quoteText: I m hopeless without your help!
subQuotationList: ['I m hopeless without your help!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
It s useless to pretend that I don t understand what you re offering,
Katharine. I admit what you say. Speaking to you perfectly frankly, I
believe at this moment that I do love your cousin; there is a chance
that, with your help, I might but no,
subQuotationList:

believe at this moment that I do love your cousin; there is a chance

quoteText:
it s impossible,
it s wrong I m infinitely to blame for having allowed this situation to
arise.
subQuotationList: ['it s impossible,\nit s wrong I m infinitely to blame for having allowed this situation to\narise.']

quoteText: Sit beside me. Let s consider sensibly

quoteText: Your sense has been our undoing

subQuotationList: ['I accept the responsibility.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Ah, but can I allow that? It would mean for we must
face it, Katharine that we let our engagement stand for the time
nominally; in fact, of course, your freedom would be absolute.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, but can I allow that?', 'It would mean for we must\nface it, Katharine that we let our engagement stand for the time\nnominally; in fact, of course, your freedom would be absolute.']

quoteText: And yours too.
subQuotationList: ['And yours too.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Yes, we should both be free. Let us say that I saw Cassandra once,
twice, perhaps, under these conditions; and then if, as I think
certain, the whole thing proves a dream, we tell your mother instantly.
Why not tell her now, indeed, under pledge of secrecy?
subQuotationList:
['Yes, we should both be free. Let us say that I saw Cassandra once,
twice, perhaps, under these conditions; and then if, as I think
certain, the whole thing proves a dream, we tell your mother instantly.
Why not tell her now, indeed, under pledge of secrecy?']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Rodney', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
Why not? It would be over London in ten minutes, besides, she would
never even remotely understand.
subQuotationList: ['Why not? It would be over London in ten minutes, besides, she would\nnever even remotely understand.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Your father, then? This secrecy is detestable it s dishonorable.
subQuotationList: ['Your father, then? This secrecy is detestable it s dishonorable.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: My father would understand even less than my mother.
subQuotationList: ['My father would understand even less than my mother.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Ah, who could be expected to understand? but it s
from your point of view that we must look at it. It s not only asking
too much, it s putting you into a position a position in which I could
not endure to see my own sister.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, who could be expected to understand?', 'but it s
from your point of view that we must look at it. It s not only asking
too much, it s putting you into a position a position in which I could
not endure to see my own sister.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
We re not brothers and sisters, and if we
can t decide, who can? I m not talking nonsense, I ve
done my best to think this out from every point of view, and I ve come
to the conclusion that there are risks which have to be taken, though I
don t deny that they hurt horribly.
subQuotationList:
['We re not brothers and sisters,', 'and if we
can t decide, who can? I m not talking nonsense,', 'I ve
done my best to think this out from every point of view, and I ve come
to the conclusion that there are risks which have to be taken, though I
don t deny that they hurt horribly.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Katharine, you mind? You ll mind too much.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine, you mind? You ll mind too much.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
No I shan t, I shall mind a good deal, but I m
prepared for that; I shall get through it, because you will help me.
You ll both help me. In fact, we ll help each other. That s a Christian
doctrine, isn t it?
subQuotationList:
['No I shan t,', 'I shall mind a good deal, but I m
prepared for that; I shall get through it, because you will help me.
You ll both help me. In fact, we ll help each other. That s a Christian

speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: We will help each other,

speaker: William Rodney

already gone, far away he thinks of me no more.

quoteText: Yes,

quoteText:

quoteText:
Two rooms are all I should want, one for eating, one for sleeping. Oh, but I should
like another, a large one at the top, and a little garden where one
could grow flowers. A path so down to a river, or up to a wood, and the
sea not very far off, so that one could hear the waves at night. Ships
just vanishing on the horizon Shall you be near the
sea?

quoteText:
Well, now you can. You will work, I suppose, you ll
work all the morning and again after tea and perhaps at night. You
won t have people always coming about you to interrupt.

quoteText: How far can one live alone? Have you tried ever?
subQuotationList: ['How far can one live alone?', 'Have you tried ever?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Once for three weeks,
subQuotationList: ['Once for three weeks,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
My father and mother were in
Italy, and something happened so that I couldn t join them. For three
weeks I lived entirely by myself, and the only person I spoke to was a
stranger in a shop where I lunched a man with a beard. Then I went back
to my room by myself and well, I did what I liked. It doesn t make me
out an amiable character, I m afraid, but I can t endure
living with other people. An occasional man with a beard is
interesting; he s detached; he lets me go my way, and we know we shall
never meet again. Therefore, we are perfectly sincere a thing not
possible with one s friends.
subQuotationList:
['My father and mother were in
Italy, and something happened so that I couldn t join them. For three
weeks I lived entirely by myself, and the only person I spoke to was a
stranger in a shop where I lunched a man with a beard. Then I went back
to my room by myself and well, I did what I liked. It doesn t make me
out an amiable character, I m afraid,', 'but I can t endure
living with other people. An occasional man with a beard is
interesting; he s detached; he lets me go my way, and we know we shall
never meet again. Therefore, we are perfectly sincere a thing not
possible with one s friends.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Nonsense,
subQuotationList: ['Nonsense,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Why  nonsense ?
subQuotationList: ['Why  nonsense ?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Because you don t mean what you say,
subQuotationList: ['Because you don t mean what you say,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You re very positive,
subQuotationList: ['You re very positive,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I don t mean what I say, Well ?
subQuotationList: ['I don t mean what I say,', 'Well ?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I doubt whether you make absolute sincerity your standard in life,
subQuotationList: ['I doubt whether you make absolute sincerity your standard in life,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Absolute sincerity is rather difficult, don t you think?
subQuotationList: ['Absolute sincerity is rather difficult, don t you think?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: There are people one credits even with that,
subQuotationList: ['There are people one credits even with that,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Don t you see that if you have no relations with people it s easier to
be honest with them? That is what I meant. One needn t
cajole them; one s under no obligation to them. Surely you must have
found with your own family that it s impossible to discuss what matters
to you most because you re all herded together, because you re in a
conspiracy, because the position is false
subQuotationList:
['Don t you see that if you have no relations with people it s easier to
be honest with them?', 'That is what I meant. One needn t
cajole them; one s under no obligation to them. Surely you must have
found with your own family that it s impossible to discuss what matters
to you most because you re all herded together, because you re in a
conspiracy, because the position is false']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText:
I m convinced, that there are cases in which perfect
sincerity is possible cases where there s no relationship, though the
people live together, if you like, where each is free, where there s no
obligation upon either side.
subQuotationList:
['I m convinced,', 'that there are cases in which perfect
sincerity is possible cases where there s no relationship, though the
people live together, if you like, where each is free, where there s no
obligation upon either side.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: For a time perhaps,
subQuotationList: ['For a time perhaps,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But
obligations always grow up. There are feelings to be considered. People
aren t simple, and though they may mean to be reasonable, they end in a muddle.
subQuotationList: ['But\nobligations always grow up. There are feelings to be considered. People\naren t simple, and though they may mean to be reasonable, they end', 'in a muddle.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Because, they don t make themselves
understood at the beginning. I could undertake, at this instant, to lay down terms for a friendship which should be
perfectly sincere and perfectly straightforward.
subQuotationList: ['Because,', 'they don t make themselves\nunderstood at the beginning. I could undertake, at this instant,', 'to lay down terms for a friendship which should be\nperfectly sincere and perfectly straightforward.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
In the first place, such a friendship must be unemotional, At least, on both sides it must be understood that
if either chooses to fall in love, he or she does so entirely at his
own risk. Neither is under any obligation to the other. They must be at
liberty to break or to alter at any moment. They must be able to say
whatever they wish to say. All this must be understood.
subQuotationList:
['In the first place, such a friendship must be unemotional,', 'At least, on both sides it must be understood that
if either chooses to fall in love, he or she does so entirely at his
own risk. Neither is under any obligation to the other. They must be at
liberty to break or to alter at any moment. They must be able to say
whatever they wish to say. All this must be understood.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: And they gain something worth having?
subQuotationList: ['And they gain something worth having?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: It s a risk of course it s a risk,
subQuotationList: ['It s a risk of course it s a risk,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But it s the only way if you think friendship worth having,
subQuotationList: ['But it s the only way if you think friendship worth having,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Perhaps under those conditions it might be,
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps under those conditions it might be,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Well, those are the terms of the friendship I wish to offer
you.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'those are the terms of the friendship I wish to offer\nyou.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I should like it, but
subQuotationList: ['I should like it,', 'but']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Would Rodney mind?
subQuotationList: ['Would Rodney mind?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Oh no,
subQuotationList: ['Oh no,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No, no, it isn t that,
subQuotationList: ['No, no, it isn t that,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Now, let s go and have tea.
subQuotationList: ['Now,', 'let s go and have tea.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
My dear, my
whole life s changed from this moment! I must write the man s name down
at once, or I shall forget
subQuotationList: ['My dear,', 'my\nwhole life s changed from this moment! I must write the man s name down\nat once, or I shall forget']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
May I sit and watch you? I
got ready on purpose.
subQuotationList: ['May I sit and watch you?', 'I\ngot ready on purpose.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Oh, you re ready, are you?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, you re ready, are you?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: There are people dining here,
subQuotationList: ['There are people dining here,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Who s coming to dinner?
subQuotationList: ['Who s coming to dinner?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: There s William, and, I believe, Aunt Eleanor and Uncle Aubrey.
subQuotationList: ['There s William, and, I believe, Aunt Eleanor and Uncle Aubrey.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I m so glad William is coming. Did he tell you that he sent me his
manuscript? I think it s wonderful I think he s almost good enough for
you, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['I m so glad William is coming. Did he tell you that he sent me his\nmanuscript? I think it s wonderful I think he s almost good enough for\nyou, Katharine.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: You shall sit next to him and tell him what you think of him.
subQuotationList: ['You shall sit next to him and tell him what you think of him.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I shan t dare do that,
subQuotationList: ['I shan t dare do that,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Why? You re not afraid of him, are you?
subQuotationList: ['Why? You re not afraid of him, are you?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: A little because he s connected with you.
subQuotationList: ['A little because he s connected with you.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
But then, with your well-known fidelity, considering that you re
staying here at least a fortnight, you won t have any illusions left
about me by the time you go. I give you a week, Cassandra. I shall see
my power fading day by day. Now it s at the climax; but to-morrow it ll
have begun to fade. What am I to wear, I wonder? Find me a blue dress,
Cassandra, over there in the long wardrobe.
subQuotationList:
['But then, with your well-known fidelity, considering that you re

Were there
any buds on the trees? Which line did she travel by?
subQuotationList: ['Were there\nany buds on the trees?', 'Which line did she travel by?']

look out of the window; you read _all_ the time.

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'William Rodney', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'William Rodney', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

quoteText:
But I must confess
that I knew that before, so it isn t fair. I ve got your manuscript
with me, I ve got all sorts of things I want to ask you about it.

play?
subQuotationList: ['First of all,', 'I want to know why you chose to write a\nplay?']

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'William Rodney', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

quoteText: Ah! You mean it s not dramatic?
subQuotationList: ['Ah! You mean it s not dramatic?']
speaker: William Rodney
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton', 'Mrs. Hilbery']

quoteText:
I mean that I don t see what it would gain by being acted. But then
does Shakespeare gain? Henry and I are always arguing about
Shakespeare. I m certain he s wrong, but I can t prove it because I ve
only seen Shakespeare acted once in Lincoln. But I m quite positive, that Shakespeare wrote for the stage.
subQuotationList:
['I mean that I don t see what it would gain by being acted. But then
does Shakespeare gain? Henry and I are always arguing about
Shakespeare. I m certain he s wrong, but I can t prove it because I ve
only seen Shakespeare acted once in Lincoln. But I m quite positive,', 'that Shakespeare wrote for the stage.']

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'William Rodney', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

quoteText:
You re perfectly right, I was hoping you were on
that side. Henry s wrong entirely wrong. Of course, I ve failed, as all
the moderns fail. Dear, dear, I wish I d consulted you before.
subQuotationList: ['You re perfectly right,', 'I was hoping you were on\nthat side. Henry s wrong entirely wrong. Of course, I ve failed, as all\nthe moderns fail. Dear, dear, I wish I d consulted you before.']

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

addressees: ['William Rodney', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton', 'Mrs. Hilbery']

quoteText:
Ah, but poetry s different, Trevor, Different altogether.
And I ve never thought, for my part, that Hamlet was as mad as they
make out. What is your opinion, Mr. Peyton?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, but poetry s different, Trevor,', 'Different altogether.\nAnd I ve never thought, for my part, that Hamlet was as mad as they\nmake out. What is your opinion, Mr. Peyton?']

quoteText:
Lovely, lovely Ophelia! What a wonderful power it
is poetry! I wake up in the morning all bedraggled; there s a yellow
fog outside; little Emily turns on the electric light when she brings
me my tea, and says, And then I open a little green
book, and the birds are singing, the stars shining, the flowers
twinkling
subQuotationList:

subQuotationList: ['Has the cook cut her finger badly?']
speaker: Aunt Eleanor
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'William Rodney', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Mr. Peyton', 'Mrs. Hilbery']

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

But if she had cut her arm off, Katharine would have sewn it
on again,

addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

quoteText:
But what horrid, horrid
thoughts, Come, let us find something more cheerful to talk about
upstairs.
subQuotationList: ['But what horrid, horrid\nthoughts,', 'Come, let us find something more cheerful to talk about\nupstairs.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressees: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Uncle Aubrey', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway', 'Aunt Eleanor', 'Mr. Peyton']

quoteText: What are you laughing at?
subQuotationList: ['What are you laughing at?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
It was nothing ridiculous in the worst of taste, but still, if you
half shut your eyes and looked
subQuotationList: ['It was nothing ridiculous in the worst of taste, but still, if you\nhalf shut your eyes and looked']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: I utterly refuse to tell you!
subQuotationList: ['I utterly refuse to tell you!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
Ah, but you re cruel to make me feel the barbarity of my sex, We ve been discussing all sorts
of dull things, and now I shall never know what I want to know more
than anything in the world.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, but you re cruel to make me feel the barbarity of my sex,', 'We ve been discussing all sorts\nof dull things, and now I shall never know what I want to know more\nthan anything in the world.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
You don t deceive us for a minute! Not for a second. We
both know that you ve been enjoying yourself immensely. Hasn t he,
Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['You don t deceive us for a minute!', 'Not for a second. We\nboth know that you ve been enjoying yourself immensely. Hasn t he,\nKatharine?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
No, I think he s speaking the truth. He doesn t care
much for politics.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I think he s speaking the truth. He doesn t care\nmuch for politics.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I detest politics.
subQuotationList: ['I detest politics.']
speaker: William Rodney
referringExpression: William at once lost his look of animation and said

quoteText: I don t think any man has the right to say that,
subQuotationList: ['I don t think any man has the right to say that,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: I agree. I mean that I detest politicians,
subQuotationList: ['I agree. I mean that I detest politicians,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
You see, I believe Cassandra is what they call a Feminist, Or rather, she was a Feminist six months ago, but it s no
good supposing that she is now what she was then. That is one of her
greatest charms in my eyes. One never can tell.
subQuotationList: ['You see, I believe Cassandra is what they call a Feminist,', 'Or rather, she was a Feminist six months ago, but it s no\ngood supposing that she is now what she was then. That is one of her\ngreatest charms in my eyes. One never can tell.']

quoteText: Katharine, you make one feel so horribly small!
subQuotationList: ['Katharine, you make one feel so horribly small!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
No, no, that s not what she means, I quite agree
that women have an immense advantage over us there. One misses a lot by
attempting to know things thoroughly.
subQuotationList: ['No, no, that s not what she means,', 'I quite agree\nthat women have an immense advantage over us there. One misses a lot by\nattempting to know things thoroughly.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
He knows Greek thoroughly, But then he also knows a
good deal about painting, and a certain amount about music. He s very
cultivated perhaps the most cultivated person I know.
subQuotationList: ['He knows Greek thoroughly,', 'But then he also knows a\ngood deal about painting, and a certain amount about music. He s very\ncultivated perhaps the most cultivated person I know.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And poetry,
subQuotationList: ['And poetry,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Yes, I was forgetting his play,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I was forgetting his play,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Henry, would say that a stage ought to be no
bigger than this drawing-room. He wants there to be singing and dancing
as well as acting only all the opposite of Wagner you understand?
subQuotationList: ['Henry,', 'would say that a stage ought to be no\nbigger than this drawing-room. He wants there to be singing and dancing\nas well as acting only all the opposite of Wagner you understand?']

quoteText: Ah, there she is,

Trelawny s Recollections of Shelley.  The third shelf on the right of

quoteText: Stop, Katharine, Let me go.

quoteText:

the most beautiful woman,
subQuotationList: ['Of course, we disagree about every subject under the sun,', 'but I think he s the cleverest man I ve ever met and you re\nthe most beautiful woman,']

quoteText: As late as that! Well ?

quoteText:
At twelve my horses turn into rats and off I go. The illusion fades.
But I accept my fate. I make hay while the sun shines.
subQuotationList: ['At twelve my horses turn into rats and off I go. The illusion fades.\nBut I accept my fate. I make hay while the sun shines.']

quoteText:

quoteText:
In starting a society such as we wish to start (we can t say any more
at present), there
are two things to remember the Press and the public. Other societies,
which shall be nameless, have gone under because they ve appealed only
to cranks. If you don t want a mutual admiration society, which dies as
soon as you ve all discovered each other s faults, you must nobble the
Press. You must appeal to the public.
subQuotationList:
['In starting a society such as we wish to start (we can t say any more

subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon. I thought you were one of my own girls. Dorothy,', 'we shall want some more methylated spirits unless the lamp\nitself is out of order. If one of you could invent a good spirit-lamp']

tea, but it didn t do.

speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You ve won again,
subQuotationList: ['You ve won again,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I ve won?
subQuotationList: ['I ve won?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I wish to God I hadn t asked you here,
subQuotationList: ['I wish to God I hadn t asked you here,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
When you re here, it s different I m happy. You ve only to walk to the
window you ve only to talk about liberty. When I saw you down there
among them all
subQuotationList: ['When you re here, it s different I m happy. You ve only to walk to the\nwindow you ve only to talk about liberty. When I saw you down there\namong them all']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You thought how ordinary I was.
subQuotationList: ['You thought how ordinary I was.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I tried to think so. But I thought you more wonderful than ever.
subQuotationList: ['I tried to think so. But I thought you more wonderful than ever.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I thought you disliked me,
subQuotationList: ['I thought you disliked me,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
God knows I tried, I ve done my best to see you as you
are, without any of this damned romantic nonsense. That was why I asked
you here, and it s increased my folly. When you re gone I shall look
out of that window and think of you. I shall waste the whole evening
thinking of you. I shall waste my whole life, I believe.
subQuotationList:
['God knows I tried,', 'I ve done my best to see you as you
are, without any of this damned romantic nonsense. That was why I asked
you here, and it s increased my folly. When you re gone I shall look
out of that window and think of you. I shall waste the whole evening
thinking of you. I shall waste my whole life, I believe.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
This is what I foretold. We shall gain nothing but unhappiness. Look
at me, Ralph.
subQuotationList: ['This is what I foretold. We shall gain nothing but unhappiness. Look\nat me, Ralph.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I assure you that I m far more
ordinary than I appear. Beauty means nothing whatever. In fact, the
most beautiful women are generally the most stupid. I m not that, but
I m a matter-of-fact, prosaic, rather ordinary character; I order the
dinner, I pay the bills, I do the accounts, I wind up the clock, and I
never look at a book.
subQuotationList:
['I assure you that I m far more
ordinary than I appear. Beauty means nothing whatever. In fact, the
most beautiful women are generally the most stupid. I m not that, but
I m a matter-of-fact, prosaic, rather ordinary character; I order the
dinner, I pay the bills, I do the accounts, I wind up the clock, and I
never look at a book.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You forget
subQuotationList: ['You forget']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You come and see me among flowers and pictures, and think me
mysterious, romantic, and all the rest of it. Being yourself very
inexperienced and very emotional, you go home and invent a story about
me, and now you can t separate me from the person you ve imagined me to
be. You call that, I suppose, being in love; as a matter of fact it s
being in delusion. All romantic people are the same, My
mother spends her life in making stories about the people she s fond
of. But I won t have you do it about me, if I can help it.
subQuotationList:
['You come and see me among flowers and pictures, and think me
mysterious, romantic, and all the rest of it. Being yourself very
inexperienced and very emotional, you go home and invent a story about
me, and now you can t separate me from the person you ve imagined me to
be. You call that, I suppose, being in love; as a matter of fact it s
being in delusion. All romantic people are the same,', 'My
mother spends her life in making stories about the people she s fond
of. But I won t have you do it about me, if I can help it.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText: You can t help it,
subQuotationList: ['You can t help it,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I warn you it s the source of all evil.
subQuotationList: ['I warn you it s the source of all evil.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And of all good,
subQuotationList: ['And of all good,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: You ll find out that I m not what you think me.
subQuotationList: ['You ll find out that I m not what you think me.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Perhaps. But I shall gain more than I lose.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps. But I shall gain more than I lose.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: If such gain s worth having.
subQuotationList: ['If such gain s worth having.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
That may be what we have to face, There may be nothing
else. Nothing but what we imagine.
subQuotationList: ['That may be what we have to face,', 'There may be nothing\nelse. Nothing but what we imagine.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: The reason of our loneliness,
subQuotationList: ['The reason of our loneliness,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: When are you to be married?
subQuotationList: ['When are you to be married?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Not till September, I think. It s been put off.
subQuotationList: ['Not till September, I think. It s been put off.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You won t be lonely then, According to what people say,
marriage is a very queer business. They say it s different from
anything else. It may be true. I ve known one or two cases where it
seems to be true.
subQuotationList:
['You won t be lonely then,', 'According to what people say,
marriage is a very queer business. They say it s different from
anything else. It may be true. I ve known one or two cases where it
seems to be true.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
It may be put off even longer than that, Some one in the office is ill, and William has to take
his place. We may put it off for some time in fact.
subQuotationList: ['It may be put off even longer than that,', 'Some one in the office is ill, and William has to take\nhis place. We may put it off for some time in fact.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: That s rather hard on him, isn t it?
subQuotationList: ['That s rather hard on him, isn t it?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
He has his work, He has lots of things that interest
him.... I know I ve been to that place, But I can t remember where it is oh, of course it s
Oxford. Now, what about your cottage?
subQuotationList: ['He has his work,', 'He has lots of things that interest\nhim.... I know I ve been to that place,', 'But I can t remember where it is oh, of course it s\nOxford. Now, what about your cottage?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I m not going to take it.
subQuotationList: ['I m not going to take it.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: How you change your mind!
subQuotationList: ['How you change your mind!']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
It s not that, It s that I want to be where I
can see you.
subQuotationList: ['It s not that,', 'It s that I want to be where I\ncan see you.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Our compact is going to hold in spite of all I ve said?
subQuotationList: ['Our compact is going to hold in spite of all I ve said?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: For ever, so far as I m concerned,
subQuotationList: ['For ever, so far as I m concerned,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You re going to go on dreaming and imagining and making up stories
about me as you walk along the street, and pretending that we re riding
in a forest, or landing on an island
subQuotationList: ['You re going to go on dreaming and imagining and making up stories\nabout me as you walk along the street, and pretending that we re riding\nin a forest, or landing on an island']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
No. I shall think of you ordering dinner, paying bills, doing the
accounts, showing old ladies the relics
subQuotationList: ['No. I shall think of you ordering dinner, paying bills, doing the\naccounts, showing old ladies the relics']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
That s better, You can think of me to-morrow morning
looking up dates in the  Dictionary of National Biography.
subQuotationList: ['That s better,', 'You can think of me to-morrow morning\nlooking up dates in the  Dictionary of National Biography.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: And forgetting your purse,
subQuotationList: ['And forgetting your purse,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I love her.
subQuotationList: ['I love her.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But I m in love with you!
subQuotationList: ['But I m in love with you!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Do you know each other?
subQuotationList: ['Do you know each other?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
We were just going through some papers, Mr. Basnett has
to help me, because I don t know much about my work yet. It s the new
society, I m the secretary. I m no longer at Russell
Square.
subQuotationList:
['We were just going through some papers,', 'Mr. Basnett has
to help me, because I don t know much about my work yet. It s the new
society,', 'I m the secretary. I m no longer at Russell
Square.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: What are your aims? I see,
subQuotationList: ['What are your aims?', 'I see,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: D you know, Mary, I believe I m in for a cold. Have you any quinine?
subQuotationList: ['D you know, Mary,', 'I believe I m in for a cold. Have you any quinine?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Of course, I agree with you, But there s more that might be done. Have you
seen Judson, for instance? You should make a point of getting him.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, I agree with you,', 'But there s more that might be done. Have you\nseen Judson, for instance? You should make a point of getting him.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
referringExpression: Ralph say in this strange voice to Mr Basnett

quoteText: Judson s address?
subQuotationList: ['Judson s address?']
speaker: Mr. Basnett

quoteText: Mary,
subQuotationList: ['Mary,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Mary,
subQuotationList: ['Mary,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: What is it, Ralph?
subQuotationList: ['What is it, Ralph?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: You ll stay and dine?
subQuotationList: ['You ll stay and dine?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: No,
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: That s a clever young man,
subQuotationList: ['That s a clever young man,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
I m glad you thought so. It s tremendously interesting work, and
considering everything, I think we ve done very well. But I m inclined
to agree with you; we ought to try to be more conciliatory. We re
absurdly strict. It s difficult to see that there may be sense in what
one s opponents say, though they are one s opponents. Horace Basnett is
certainly too uncompromising. I mustn t forget to see that he writes
that letter to Judson. You re too busy, I suppose, to come on to our
committee?
subQuotationList:
['I m glad you thought so. It s tremendously interesting work, and
considering everything, I think we ve done very well. But I m inclined
to agree with you; we ought to try to be more conciliatory. We re
absurdly strict. It s difficult to see that there may be sense in what
