speaker: Mary Datchet
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Basnett'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Basnett'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Basnett'], ['Mr. Basnett'], ['Mr. Basnett'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Basnett']]]

quoteText: I may be out of town,
subQuotationList: ['I may be out of town,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Our executive meets every week, of course, But some of
our members don t come more than once a month. Members of Parliament
are the worst; it was a mistake, I think, to ask them.
subQuotationList: ['Our executive meets every week, of course,', 'But some of\nour members don t come more than once a month. Members of Parliament\nare the worst; it was a mistake, I think, to ask them.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: You ve not taken your quinine,
subQuotationList: ['You ve not taken your quinine,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: I don t want it,
subQuotationList: ['I don t want it,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Well, you know best,
subQuotationList: ['Well, you know best,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
Mary, I m a brute! Here I come and waste your time,
and do nothing but make myself disagreeable.
subQuotationList: ['Mary, I m a brute!', 'Here I come and waste your time,\nand do nothing but make myself disagreeable.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: A cold coming on does make one feel wretched,
subQuotationList: ['A cold coming on does make one feel wretched,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I ve not got a cold. That was a lie. There s nothing the matter with
me. I m mad, I suppose. I ought to have had the decency to keep away.
But I wanted to see you I wanted to tell you I m in love, Mary.
subQuotationList: ['I ve not got a cold. That was a lie. There s nothing the matter with\nme. I m mad, I suppose. I ought to have had the decency to keep away.\nBut I wanted to see you I wanted to tell you I m in love, Mary.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: In love, are you? I m glad, Ralph.
subQuotationList: ['In love, are you?', 'I m glad, Ralph.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
I suppose I m in love. Anyhow, I m out of my mind. I can t think, I
can t work, I don t care a hang for anything in the world. Good
Heavens, Mary! I m in torment! One moment I m happy; next I m
miserable. I hate her for half an hour; then I d give my whole life to
be with her for ten minutes; all the time I don t know what I feel, or
why I feel it; it s insanity, and yet it s perfectly reasonable. Can
you make any sense of it? Can you see what s happened? I m raving, I
know; don t listen, Mary; go on with your work.
subQuotationList:
['I suppose I m in love. Anyhow, I m out of my mind. I can t think, I
can t work, I don t care a hang for anything in the world. Good
Heavens, Mary! I m in torment! One moment I m happy; next I m
miserable. I hate her for half an hour; then I d give my whole life to
be with her for ten minutes; all the time I don t know what I feel, or
why I feel it; it s insanity, and yet it s perfectly reasonable. Can
you make any sense of it? Can you see what s happened? I m raving, I
know; don t listen, Mary; go on with your work.']
speaker: Ralph Denham
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Datchet'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet']]]

quoteText: Do sit down, You make me so
subQuotationList: ['Do sit down,', 'You make me so']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: You haven t told me her name you d rather not, I suppose?
subQuotationList: ['You haven t told me her name you d rather not, I suppose?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Her name? Katharine Hilbery.
subQuotationList: ['Her name? Katharine Hilbery.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: But she s engaged
subQuotationList: ['But she s engaged']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: To Rodney. They re to be married in September.
subQuotationList: ['To Rodney. They re to be married in September.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I see,
subQuotationList: ['I see,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Is there anything that I could do for you?
subQuotationList: ['Is there anything that I could do for you?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
You could see her no, that s not what I want; you mustn t bother about
me, Mary.
subQuotationList: ['You could see her no, that s not what I want; you mustn t bother about\nme, Mary.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: I m afraid no third person can do anything to help,
subQuotationList: ['I m afraid no third person can do anything to help,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: No,
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Katharine was saying to-day how lonely we
are.
subQuotationList: ['Katharine was saying to-day how lonely we\nare.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: There s always work,
subQuotationList: ['There s always work,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Do you want to be working now?
subQuotationList: ['Do you want to be working now?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
No, no. It s Sunday, I was thinking of Katharine. She
doesn t understand about work. She s never had to. She doesn t know
what work is. I ve only found out myself quite lately. But it s the
thing that saves one I m sure of that.
subQuotationList:
['No, no. It s Sunday,', 'I was thinking of Katharine. She
doesn t understand about work. She s never had to. She doesn t know
what work is. I ve only found out myself quite lately. But it s the
thing that saves one I m sure of that.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: There are other things, aren t there?
subQuotationList: ['There are other things, aren t there?']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Nothing that one can count upon,
subQuotationList: ['Nothing that one can count upon,']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText:
After all, other
people Where should I be
now if I hadn t got to go to my office every day? Thousands of people
would tell you the same thing thousands of women. I tell you, work is
the only thing that saved me, Ralph.
subQuotationList:
['After all, other
people', 'Where should I be
now if I hadn t got to go to my office every day? Thousands of people
would tell you the same thing thousands of women. I tell you, work is
the only thing that saved me, Ralph.']
speaker: Mary Datchet
referringExpression: she stopped but forced herself to go on

quoteText:
It s all turned out splendidly for me, It will for you,
too. I m sure of that. Because, after all, Katharine is worth it.
subQuotationList: ['It s all turned out splendidly for me,', 'It will for you,\ntoo. I m sure of that. Because, after all, Katharine is worth it.']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Mary !
subQuotationList: ['Mary !']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Mary, you re splendid,
subQuotationList: ['Mary, you re splendid,']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Goodness, Denham, what are you doing here?
subQuotationList: ['Goodness, Denham, what are you doing here?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Did you stay long after we d left?
subQuotationList: ['Did you stay long after we d left?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: No. We went back to my house.
subQuotationList: ['No. We went back to my house.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: Women are incomprehensible creatures, Denham!
subQuotationList: ['Women are incomprehensible creatures, Denham!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Um,
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
You say something and they fly into a passion. Or for no reason at
all, they laugh. I take it that no amount of education will
subQuotationList: ['You say something and they fly into a passion. Or for no reason at\nall, they laugh. I take it that no amount of education will']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I ve suffered tortures, Denham, tortures!
subQuotationList: ['I ve suffered tortures, Denham, tortures!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Yes, yes, I know that.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, I know that.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: She s laughed at me.
subQuotationList: ['She s laughed at me.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Never to me.
subQuotationList: ['Never to me.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: How I ve loved her!
subQuotationList: ['How I ve loved her!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I am in love with Katharine myself. That is why I am here to-night.
subQuotationList: ['I am in love with Katharine myself. That is why I am here to-night.']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText:
Ah, I ve always known it, I ve known it from the first.
You ll marry her!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, I ve always known it,', 'I ve known it from the first.\nYou ll marry her!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: My God, Denham, what fools we both are!
subQuotationList: ['My God, Denham, what fools we both are!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Are you awake, Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['Are you awake, Katharine?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Yes, I m awake. What is it?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I m awake. What is it?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I couldn t sleep, and I thought I d come and speak to you only for a
moment, though. I m going home to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['I couldn t sleep, and I thought I d come and speak to you only for a\nmoment, though. I m going home to-morrow.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Home? Why, what has happened?
subQuotationList: ['Home? Why, what has happened?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Something happened to-day which makes it impossible for me to stay
here.
subQuotationList: ['Something happened to-day which makes it impossible for me to stay\nhere.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
I have decided to tell you the whole truth, Katharine. William allowed
himself to behave in a way which made me extremely uncomfortable
to-day.
subQuotationList: ['I have decided to tell you the whole truth, Katharine. William allowed\nhimself to behave in a way which made me extremely uncomfortable\nto-day.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: At the Zoo?
subQuotationList: ['At the Zoo?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No, on the way home. When we had tea.
subQuotationList: ['No, on the way home. When we had tea.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
There s a train at eleven, I shall tell Aunt Maggie that I
have to go suddenly.... I shall make Violet s visit an excuse. But,
after thinking it over, I don t see how I can go without telling you
the truth.
subQuotationList:
['There s a train at eleven,', 'I shall tell Aunt Maggie that I
have to go suddenly.... I shall make Violet s visit an excuse. But,
after thinking it over, I don t see how I can go without telling you
the truth.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: But I don t see the least reason why you should go,
subQuotationList: ['But I don t see the least reason why you should go,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Because I can t allow any man to behave to me in that way, particularly when I know that he is engaged to
some one else.
subQuotationList: ['Because I can t allow any man to behave to me in that way,', 'particularly when I know that he is engaged to\nsome one else.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: But you like him, don t you?
subQuotationList: ['But you like him, don t you?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
That s got nothing to do with it, I
consider his conduct, under the circumstances, most disgraceful.
subQuotationList: ['That s got nothing to do with it,', 'I\nconsider his conduct, under the circumstances, most disgraceful.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: I should say it had everything to do with it,
subQuotationList: ['I should say it had everything to do with it,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t understand you in the least, Katharine. How can you behave as
you behave? Ever since I came here I ve been amazed by you!
subQuotationList: ['I don t understand you in the least, Katharine. How can you behave as\nyou behave? Ever since I came here I ve been amazed by you!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: You ve enjoyed yourself, haven t you?
subQuotationList: ['You ve enjoyed yourself, haven t you?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Yes, I have,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I have,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Anyhow, my behavior hasn t spoiled your visit.
subQuotationList: ['Anyhow, my behavior hasn t spoiled your visit.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: No,
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Do you think I ve been very foolish about it?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think I ve been very foolish about it?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: But do you care for William?
subQuotationList: ['But do you care for William?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Do you mean, am I in love with him?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean, am I in love with him?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Yes, in love with him,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, in love with him,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: How can I love the man you re engaged to marry?
subQuotationList: ['How can I love the man you re engaged to marry?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: He may be in love with you.
subQuotationList: ['He may be in love with you.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I don t think you ve any right to say such things, Katharine, Why do you say them? Don t you mind in the least
how William behaves to other women? If I were engaged, I couldn t bear
it!
subQuotationList: ['I don t think you ve any right to say such things, Katharine,', 'Why do you say them? Don t you mind in the least\nhow William behaves to other women? If I were engaged, I couldn t bear\nit!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: We re not engaged,
subQuotationList: ['We re not engaged,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Katharine!
subQuotationList: ['Katharine!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
No, we re not engaged, But no one knows it but
ourselves.
subQuotationList: ['No, we re not engaged,', 'But no one knows it but\nourselves.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But why I don t understand you re not engaged! Oh, that explains it! You re not in love with him! You don t want to
marry him!
subQuotationList: ['But why I don t understand you re not engaged!', 'Oh, that explains it! You re not in love with him! You don t want to\nmarry him!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: We aren t in love with each other any longer,
subQuotationList: ['We aren t in love with each other any longer,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: How queer, how strange, how unlike other people you are, Katharine,
subQuotationList: ['How queer, how strange, how unlike other people you are, Katharine,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: You re not in love with him?
subQuotationList: ['You re not in love with him?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: But I love him,
subQuotationList: ['But I love him,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: D you know what time it is?
subQuotationList: ['D you know what time it is?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
There s no reason why I should go home, then? Unless you want me to go, Katharine? What _do_ you want me to
do?
subQuotationList: ['There s no reason why I should go home, then?', 'Unless you want me to go, Katharine? What _do_ you want me to\ndo?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: You wanted us to fall in love,
subQuotationList: ['You wanted us to fall in love,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Please, miss, Mrs. Milvain is in the kitchen.
subQuotationList: ['Please, miss,', 'Mrs. Milvain is in the kitchen.']
speaker: The Maid

quoteText: You know what that means.
subQuotationList: ['You know what that means.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
referringExpression: She rose walked to the window and the maid being gone said

quoteText: Aunt Celia is in the kitchen,
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Celia is in the kitchen,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Why in the kitchen?
subQuotationList: ['Why in the kitchen?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Probably because she s discovered something,
subQuotationList: ['Probably because she s discovered something,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: About us?
subQuotationList: ['About us?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
Heaven knows, I shan t let her stay in the
kitchen, though. I shall bring her up here.
subQuotationList: ['Heaven knows,', 'I shan t let her stay in the\nkitchen, though. I shall bring her up here.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
For goodness  sake, Katharine, don t be rash. Don t let her
suspect. Remember, nothing s certain
subQuotationList: ['For goodness  sake, Katharine,', 'don t be rash. Don t let her\nsuspect. Remember, nothing s certain']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: I ve something that I want to say to you in _private_,
subQuotationList: ['I ve something that I want to say to you in _private_,']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: The drawing-room is empty
subQuotationList: ['The drawing-room is empty']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But we might meet your mother upon the stairs. We might disturb your
father,
subQuotationList: ['But we might meet your mother upon the stairs. We might disturb your\nfather,']
speaker: Aunt Celia
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Aunt Celia', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery']]]

quoteText: Nobody will overhear us?
subQuotationList: ['Nobody will overhear us?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
I see that I have interrupted
you,
subQuotationList: ['I see that I have interrupted\nyou,']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: Was some one sitting with you?
subQuotationList: ['Was some one sitting with you?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: Cassandra was helping me to put the flowers in water,
subQuotationList: ['Cassandra was helping me to put the flowers in water,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Ah, Cassandra is still with you, And did William send
you those lovely flowers?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, Cassandra is still with you,', 'And did William send\nyou those lovely flowers?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: They re from Stogdon House,
subQuotationList: ['They re from Stogdon House,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
People are talking about you, Katharine. That is why I have come this
morning. You forgive me for saying what I d much rather not say? What I
say is only for your own sake, my child.
subQuotationList: ['People are talking about you, Katharine. That is why I have come this\nmorning. You forgive me for saying what I d much rather not say? What I\nsay is only for your own sake, my child.']
speaker: Aunt Celia
referringExpression: Mrs Milvain who was possessed of rash but heroic courage plunged

quoteText: There s nothing to forgive yet, Aunt Celia,
subQuotationList: ['There s nothing to forgive yet, Aunt Celia,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
People are saying that William goes everywhere with you and Cassandra,
and that he is always paying her attentions. At the Markhams  dance he
sat out five dances with her. At the Zoo they were seen alone together.
They left together. They never came back here till seven in the
evening. But that is not all. They say his manner is very marked he is
quite different when she is there.
subQuotationList:
['People are saying that William goes everywhere with you and Cassandra,
and that he is always paying her attentions. At the Markhams  dance he
sat out five dances with her. At the Zoo they were seen alone together.
They left together. They never came back here till seven in the
evening. But that is not all. They say his manner is very marked he is
quite different when she is there.']
speaker: Aunt Celia
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway', 'William Rodney'], ['William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway']]]

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
We all know how good you are how unselfish how you sacrifice yourself
to others. But you ve been too unselfish, Katharine. You have made
Cassandra happy, and she has taken advantage of your goodness.
subQuotationList: ['We all know how good you are how unselfish how you sacrifice yourself\nto others. But you ve been too unselfish, Katharine. You have made\nCassandra happy, and she has taken advantage of your goodness.']
speaker: Aunt Celia
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
I don t understand, Aunt Celia, What has Cassandra
done?
subQuotationList: ['I don t understand, Aunt Celia,', 'What has Cassandra\ndone?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Cassandra has behaved in a way that I could not have thought
possible, She has been utterly
selfish utterly heartless. I must speak to her before I go.
subQuotationList: ['Cassandra has behaved in a way that I could not have thought\npossible,', 'She has been utterly\nselfish utterly heartless. I must speak to her before I go.']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: I don t understand,
subQuotationList: ['I don t understand,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Cassandra has stolen William s love.
subQuotationList: ['Cassandra has stolen William s love.']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: Do you mean, that he has fallen in love with her?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean,', 'that he has fallen in love with her?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: There are ways of _making_ men fall in love with one, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['There are ways of _making_ men fall in love with one, Katharine.']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
Nothing would have made me say these things but your own good. I have
not wished to interfere; I have not wished to give you pain. I am a
useless old woman. I have no children of my own. I only want to see you
happy, Katharine.
subQuotationList:
['Nothing would have made me say these things but your own good. I have
not wished to interfere; I have not wished to give you pain. I am a
useless old woman. I have no children of my own. I only want to see you
happy, Katharine.']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: You are not going to say these things to Cassandra, You ve said them to me; that s enough.
subQuotationList: ['You are not going to say these things to Cassandra,', 'You ve said them to me; that s enough.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I ve made you angry! I knew I should!
subQuotationList: ['I ve made you angry! I knew I should!']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
Yes, I m so angry that I don t want to
say anything more. I think you d better go, Aunt Celia. We don t
understand each other.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I m so angry that I don t want to\nsay anything more. I think you d better go, Aunt Celia. We don t\nunderstand each other.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Married love, is
the most sacred of all loves. The love of husband and wife is the most
holy we know. That is the lesson Mamma s children learnt from her; that
is what they can never forget. I have tried to speak as she would have
wished her daughter to speak. You are her grandchild.
subQuotationList:
['Married love,', 'is
the most sacred of all loves. The love of husband and wife is the most
holy we know. That is the lesson Mamma s children learnt from her; that
is what they can never forget. I have tried to speak as she would have
wished her daughter to speak. You are her grandchild.']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: I don t see that there is any excuse for your behavior,
subQuotationList: ['I don t see that there is any excuse for your behavior,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: These are for you, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['These are for you, Katharine.']
speaker: William Rodney
referringExpression: he advanced straight to Katharine and presented the flowers with the words

quoteText: I must go,
subQuotationList: ['I must go,']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
I ve come to be forgiven, Our quarrel was perfectly hateful
to me. I ve not slept all night. You re not angry with me, are you,
Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['I ve come to be forgiven,', 'Our quarrel was perfectly hateful\nto me. I ve not slept all night. You re not angry with me, are you,\nKatharine?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
She s been spying upon us, following us about London,
overhearing what people are saying
subQuotationList: ['She s been spying upon us,', 'following us about London,\noverhearing what people are saying']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Mrs. Milvain? What has she told you?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Milvain?', 'What has she told you?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Oh, people are saying that you re in love with Cassandra, and that you
don t care for me.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, people are saying that you re in love with Cassandra, and that you\ndon t care for me.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: They have seen us?
subQuotationList: ['They have seen us?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Everything we ve done for a fortnight has been seen.
subQuotationList: ['Everything we ve done for a fortnight has been seen.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: I told you that would happen!
subQuotationList: ['I told you that would happen!']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
It s all been a mistake, I blame myself for it. I should
have known better. I let you persuade me in a moment of madness. I beg
you to forget my insanity, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['It s all been a mistake,', 'I blame myself for it. I should\nhave known better. I let you persuade me in a moment of madness. I beg\nyou to forget my insanity, Katharine.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
She wished even to persecute Cassandra! She threatened to speak to her. She s capable of
it she s capable of anything!
subQuotationList: ['She wished even to persecute Cassandra!', 'She threatened to speak to her. She s capable of\nit she s capable of anything!']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Aunt Celia'], ['Cassandra Otway']], [['Aunt Celia'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Milvain is not tactful, I know, but you exaggerate, Katharine.
People are talking about us. She was right to tell us. It only confirms
my own feeling the position is monstrous.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Milvain is not tactful, I know, but you exaggerate, Katharine.\nPeople are talking about us. She was right to tell us. It only confirms\nmy own feeling the position is monstrous.']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Aunt Celia'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney']]]

quoteText: You don t mean that this influences you, William?
subQuotationList: ['You don t mean that this influences you, William?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
It does, It s intensely disagreeable to me. I
can t endure that people should gossip about us. And then there s your
cousin Cassandra
subQuotationList: ['It does,', 'It s intensely disagreeable to me. I\ncan t endure that people should gossip about us. And then there s your\ncousin Cassandra']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I came here this morning, Katharine, to ask you to forget my folly, my bad temper, my inconceivable
behavior. I came, Katharine, to ask whether we can t return to the
position we were in before this this season of lunacy. Will you take me
back, Katharine, once more and for ever?
subQuotationList:
['I came here this morning, Katharine,', 'to ask you to forget my folly, my bad temper, my inconceivable
behavior. I came, Katharine, to ask whether we can t return to the
position we were in before this this season of lunacy. Will you take me
back, Katharine, once more and for ever?']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText:
I was as much to blame as you were yesterday, I confess, William, the sight of you and
Cassandra together made me jealous, and I couldn t control myself. I
laughed at you, I know.
subQuotationList: ['I was as much to blame as you were yesterday,', 'I confess, William, the sight of you and\nCassandra together made me jealous, and I couldn t control myself. I\nlaughed at you, I know.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
You jealous! I assure you, Katharine, you ve not
the slightest reason to be jealous. Cassandra dislikes me, so far as
she feels about me at all. I was foolish enough to try to explain the
nature of our relationship. I couldn t resist telling her what I
supposed myself to feel for her. She refused to listen, very rightly.
But she left me in no doubt of her scorn.
subQuotationList:
['You jealous!', 'I assure you, Katharine, you ve not
the slightest reason to be jealous. Cassandra dislikes me, so far as
she feels about me at all. I was foolish enough to try to explain the
nature of our relationship. I couldn t resist telling her what I
supposed myself to feel for her. She refused to listen, very rightly.
But she left me in no doubt of her scorn.']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway']]]

quoteText:
She charmed me, I thought I loved her. But that s
a thing of the past. It s all over, Katharine. It was a dream an
hallucination. We were both equally to blame, but no harm s done if you
believe how truly I care for you. Say you believe me!
subQuotationList:
['She charmed me,', 'I thought I loved her. But that s
a thing of the past. It s all over, Katharine. It was a dream an
hallucination. We were both equally to blame, but no harm s done if you
believe how truly I care for you. Say you believe me!']
speaker: William Rodney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cassandra Otway']], [['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: Yes, yes, yes, you accept me, Katharine. You love me.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, yes,', 'you accept me, Katharine. You love me.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Cassandra loves you more than I do.
subQuotationList: ['Cassandra loves you more than I do.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Cassandra?
subQuotationList: ['Cassandra?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: She loves you,
subQuotationList: ['She loves you,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: She loves you.
subQuotationList: ['She loves you.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Yes, yes, it s true.
I know what she feels for you.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes,', 'it s true.\nI know what she feels for you.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: She loves me?
subQuotationList: ['She loves me?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Ah, but who knows what I feel? How can I be sure of my feeling myself?
Ten minutes ago I asked you to marry me. I still wish it I don t know
what I wish
subQuotationList: ['Ah, but who knows what I feel? How can I be sure of my feeling myself?\nTen minutes ago I asked you to marry me. I still wish it I don t know\nwhat I wish']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Tell me what you feel for Denham.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me what you feel for Denham.']
speaker: William Rodney
referringExpression: He suddenly faced her and demanded

quoteText: For Ralph Denham?
subQuotationList: ['For Ralph Denham?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Yes! You re
jealous of me, William; but you re not in love with me. I m jealous of
you. Therefore, for both our sakes, I say, speak to Cassandra at once.
subQuotationList: ['Yes!', 'You re\njealous of me, William; but you re not in love with me. I m jealous of\nyou. Therefore, for both our sakes, I say, speak to Cassandra at once.']

mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway']]]

quoteText:
You re right, I love
Cassandra.
subQuotationList: ['You re right,', 'I love\nCassandra.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: I have overheard every word!
subQuotationList: ['I have overheard every word!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Then you know what I wish to ask you. Give me your answer
subQuotationList: ['Then you know what I wish to ask you. Give me your answer']
speaker: William Rodney
referringExpression: Rodney made a step forward and said

quoteText: What Katharine said,
subQuotationList: ['What Katharine said,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
But, how frightfully difficult it all is! Our feelings, I mean yours and
mine and Katharine s. Katharine, tell me, are we doing right?
subQuotationList: ['But,', 'how frightfully difficult it all is! Our feelings, I mean yours and\nmine and Katharine s. Katharine, tell me, are we doing right?']
speaker: Cassandra Otway
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway']]]

quoteText:
Right of course we re doing right, if, after
what you ve heard, you can marry a man of such incomprehensible
confusion, such deplorable
subQuotationList: ['Right of course we re doing right,', 'if, after\nwhat you ve heard, you can marry a man of such incomprehensible\nconfusion, such deplorable']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Don t, William, Cassandra has heard us; she
can judge what we are; she knows better than we could tell her.
subQuotationList: ['Don t, William,', 'Cassandra has heard us; she\ncan judge what we are; she knows better than we could tell her.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Rodney']], [['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney'], ['Cassandra Otway']]]

quoteText:
I must be first with him, Katharine! I can t share
him even with you.
subQuotationList: ['I must be first with him, Katharine!', 'I can t share\nhim even with you.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: I shall never ask that,
subQuotationList: ['I shall never ask that,']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: But you ve shared with me,
subQuotationList: ['But you ve shared with me,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
Why can t I share with
you? Why am I so mean? I know why it is, We understand
each other, William and I. You ve never understood each other. You re
too different.
subQuotationList:
['Why can t I share with
you? Why am I so mean? I know why it is,', 'We understand
each other, William and I. You ve never understood each other. You re
too different.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['William Rodney', 'Cassandra Otway'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: I ve never admired anybody more,
subQuotationList: ['I ve never admired anybody more,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: It s not that it s understanding.
subQuotationList: ['It s not that', 'it s understanding.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: Have I never understood you, Katharine? Have I been very selfish?
subQuotationList: ['Have I never understood you, Katharine? Have I been very selfish?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Yes, You ve asked her for sympathy, and she s
not sympathetic; you ve wanted her to be practical, and she s not
practical. You ve been selfish; you ve been exacting and so has
Katharine but it wasn t anybody s fault.
subQuotationList:
['Yes,', 'You ve asked her for sympathy, and she s
not sympathetic; you ve wanted her to be practical, and she s not
practical. You ve been selfish; you ve been exacting and so has
Katharine but it wasn t anybody s fault.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

quoteText: It s quite true, It was nobody s fault.
subQuotationList: ['It s quite true,', 'It was nobody s fault.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
There are many things that he ll always come to you for, I accept that,
Katharine. I shall never dispute it. I want to be generous as you ve
been generous. But being in love makes it more difficult for me.
subQuotationList: ['There are many things that he ll always come to you for,', 'I accept that,\nKatharine. I shall never dispute it. I want to be generous as you ve\nbeen generous. But being in love makes it more difficult for me.']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
One thing I beg of you both, We will never discuss
these matters again. It s not that I m timid and conventional, as you
think, Katharine. It s that it spoils things to discuss them; it
unsettles people s minds; and now we re all so happy
subQuotationList:
['One thing I beg of you both,', 'We will never discuss
these matters again. It s not that I m timid and conventional, as you
think, Katharine. It s that it spoils things to discuss them; it
unsettles people s minds; and now we re all so happy']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
Yes, I m happy, And I agree. We will never talk
about it again.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I m happy,', 'And I agree. We will never talk\nabout it again.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: Oh, Katharine, Katharine!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Katharine, Katharine!']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText: What is it?
subQuotationList: ['What is it?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: There he is again, Look, there under the lamp-post.
subQuotationList: ['There he is again,', 'Look, there under the lamp-post.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Denham,
subQuotationList: ['Denham,']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: He was there last night too.
subQuotationList: ['He was there last night too.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: If he chooses to come
subQuotationList: ['If he chooses to come']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You can t let him wait out there. I shall tell him to come in.
subQuotationList: ['You can t let him wait out there. I shall tell him to come in.']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Wait! I don t allow you.
subQuotationList: ['Wait!', 'I don t allow you.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You can t wait, You ve gone too far.

speaker: William Rodney

quoteText: Why don t you admit, Katharine, that you love him? Are you going to treat him as you treated me?
subQuotationList: ['Why don t you admit, Katharine,', 'that you love him? Are you going to treat him as you treated me?']
speaker: William Rodney

quoteText:
I ve no right to interfere, I ll leave you. Or, if you
like, we ll go back to the drawing-room.

quoteText: You love him, Katharine,

I was thinking about a mountain in the North of

Byron ah, Byron. I ve known people who knew Lord

The windows of the

people yourselves, I ll do it for you. I know William has feelings

would make him ill for weeks.

quoteText:
But he has left the office, The only question is will
he have reached home yet? He went to see me at Chelsea; I tried to meet
him and missed him. He will have found no message to explain. So I must
find him as soon as possible.

quoteText: Mary.

Possibly he may come here, It would be worth your while to wait if

No, Except that when one s desperate one has a sort
of right. I am desperate. How do I know what s happening to him now? He
may do anything. He may wander about the streets all night. Anything
may happen to him.

You forget that I loved him too. I thought I knew him. I _did_ know

subQuotationList: ['But where are you going to?']
speaker: Mary Datchet

quoteText: Oh, I m going home no, to Highgate perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I m going home no, to Highgate perhaps.']

quoteText:
Very well, We may as well go there as

subQuotationList: ['Very well,', 'We may as well go there as\nanywhere else.']

quoteText: I m sure we shall find him,
subQuotationList: ['I m sure we shall find him,']

quoteText: It may be too late,

quoteText:
Nonsense, If we don t find

subQuotationList: ['Nonsense,', 'If we don t find\nhim there we shall find him somewhere else.']

quoteText: But suppose he s walking about the streets for hours and hours?

quoteText:
He may refuse ever to speak to me again, Don t be frightened, I m not going to

subQuotationList: ['He may refuse ever to speak to me again,', 'Don t be frightened,', 'I m not going to\njump out of the cab. It wouldn t do much good after all.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I ought to have apologized, for
bringing you into all this business; I haven t told you half, either.
I m no longer engaged to William Rodney. He is to marry Cassandra
Otway. It s all arranged all perfectly right.... And after he d waited
in the streets for hours and hours, William made me bring him in. He
was standing under the lamp-post watching our windows. He was perfectly
white when he came into the room. William left us alone, and we sat and
talked. It seems ages and ages ago, now. Was it last night? Have I been
out long? What s the time?
subQuotationList:
['I ought to have apologized,', 'for
bringing you into all this business; I haven t told you half, either.

Otway. It s all arranged all perfectly right.... And after he d waited
in the streets for hours and hours, William made me bring him in. He
was standing under the lamp-post watching our windows. He was perfectly
white when he came into the room. William left us alone, and we sat and
talked. It seems ages and ages ago, now. Was it last night? Have I been
out long? What s the time?']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Mr. Denham called again, miss. He has been waiting for you for some

quoteText:
That doesn t matter with me, of course, but suppose it happened with

merely from her expression. She looked she looked like
some one walking in her sleep.

Once throw conventions aside, once do the things that

Katharine and Ralph, eh?
subQuotationList: ['But don t you think it s a little unsociable?', 'Why not\ndo something amusing? go to the play, for instance? Why not ask\nKatharine and Ralph, eh?']

subQuotationList: ['Don t you think they must be ?']

Oh, I know nothing about that. I only thought we might amuse
ourselves, as your uncle s out.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I know nothing about that. I only thought we might amuse\nourselves, as your uncle s out.']

How can Cassandra how could she herself
have been so blind?

quoteText:
She looks as if she
were offering up a sacrifice! Very beautiful,
subQuotationList: ['She looks as if she\nwere offering up a sacrifice! Very beautiful,']
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
The only hope for us, is that William shall die, and
Cassandra shall be given rooms as the widow of a distinguished poet.
subQuotationList: ['The only hope for us,', 'is that William shall die, and\nCassandra shall be given rooms as the widow of a distinguished poet.']

quoteText: Or
speaker: Cassandra Otway

quoteText:
Katharine is out this afternoon, Why not come round
later and discuss it with her with us both, eh?
subQuotationList: ['Katharine is out this afternoon,', 'Why not come round\nlater and discuss it with her with us both, eh?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
My dear Trevor, I have particular reasons for wishing to talk to you
alone.... Where is Katharine?
subQuotationList: ['My dear Trevor, I have particular reasons for wishing to talk to you\nalone.... Where is Katharine?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
She s out with her young man, naturally. Cassandra plays the part of
chaperone very usefully. A charming young woman that a great favorite
of mine.
subQuotationList: ['She s out with her young man, naturally. Cassandra plays the part of\nchaperone very usefully. A charming young woman that a great favorite\nof mine.']

With Cassandra, With
Cassandra.

quoteText:
Yes, with Cassandra, I think they said they were going to Hampton Court, and I
rather believe they were taking a protege of mine, Ralph Denham, a very
clever fellow, too, to amuse Cassandra. I thought the arrangement very
suitable.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, with Cassandra,', 'I think they said they were going to Hampton Court, and I

speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Hampton Court always seems to me an ideal spot for engaged couples.
There s the Maze, there s a nice place for having tea I forget what
they call it and then, if the young man knows his business he contrives
to take his lady upon the river. Full of possibilities full. Cake,
Celia? I respect my dinner too much, but that
can t possibly apply to you. You ve never observed that feast, so far
as I can remember.
subQuotationList:
['Hampton Court always seems to me an ideal spot for engaged couples.
There s the Maze, there s a nice place for having tea I forget what
they call it and then, if the young man knows his business he contrives
to take his lady upon the river. Full of possibilities full. Cake,
Celia?', 'I respect my dinner too much, but that
can t possibly apply to you. You ve never observed that feast, so far

speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Who is this Mr. Denham?
subQuotationList: ['Who is this Mr. Denham?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
Ralph Denham? A very interesting young man. I ve a great belief in him.
He s an authority upon our mediaeval institutions, and if he weren t
forced to earn his living he would write a book that very much wants
writing
subQuotationList:
['Ralph Denham?', 'A very interesting young man. I ve a great belief in him.
He s an authority upon our mediaeval institutions, and if he weren t
forced to earn his living he would write a book that very much wants
writing']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: He is not well off, then?
subQuotationList: ['He is not well off, then?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
Hasn t a penny, I m afraid, and a family more or less dependent on
him.
subQuotationList: ['Hasn t a penny, I m afraid, and a family more or less dependent on\nhim.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: A mother and sisters? His father is dead?
subQuotationList: ['A mother and sisters? His father is dead?']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText: Yes, his father died some years ago,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, his father died some years ago,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
His father has been dead some time, and this young man had to take his
place
subQuotationList: ['His father has been dead some time, and this young man had to take his\nplace']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
A legal family? I fancy I ve seen the name
somewhere.
subQuotationList: ['A legal family?', 'I fancy I ve seen the name\nsomewhere.']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
I should be inclined to doubt whether they
were altogether in that walk of life,
subQuotationList: ['I should be inclined to doubt whether they\nwere altogether in that walk of life,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
I fancy that
Denham once told me that his father was a corn merchant. Perhaps he
said a stockbroker. He came to grief, anyhow, as stockbrokers have a
way of doing. I ve a great respect for Denham,
subQuotationList:
['I fancy that
Denham once told me that his father was a corn merchant. Perhaps he
said a stockbroker. He came to grief, anyhow, as stockbrokers have a
way of doing. I ve a great respect for Denham,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Cassandra s grown into a very charming young
woman, Charming to look at, and charming to talk
to, though her historical knowledge is not altogether profound. Another
cup of tea?
subQuotationList:
['Cassandra s grown into a very charming young
woman,', 'Charming to look at, and charming to talk
to, though her historical knowledge is not altogether profound. Another

speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
It is Cassandra that I have come about, I am very sorry
to say that Cassandra is not at all what you think her, Trevor. She has
imposed upon your and Maggie s goodness. She has behaved in a way that
would have seemed incredible in this house of all houses were it not
for other circumstances that are still more incredible.
subQuotationList:
['It is Cassandra that I have come about,', 'I am very sorry
to say that Cassandra is not at all what you think her, Trevor. She has
imposed upon your and Maggie s goodness. She has behaved in a way that

speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
It all sounds very black, But I own I am completely in the
dark.
subQuotationList: ['It all sounds very black,', 'But I own I am completely in the\ndark.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Who has Cassandra gone out with? William Rodney. Who has Katharine
gone out with? Ralph Denham. Why are they for ever meeting each other
round street corners, and going to music-halls, and taking cabs late at
night? Why will Katharine not tell me the truth when I question her? I
understand the reason now. Katharine has entangled herself with this
unknown lawyer; she has seen fit to condone Cassandra s conduct.
subQuotationList:
['Who has Cassandra gone out with? William Rodney. Who has Katharine
gone out with? Ralph Denham. Why are they for ever meeting each other

night? Why will Katharine not tell me the truth when I question her? I
understand the reason now. Katharine has entangled herself with this
unknown lawyer; she has seen fit to condone Cassandra s conduct.']
speaker: Aunt Celia
referringExpression: Mrs Milvain became rigid and emitted

quoteText:
Ah, well, Katharine will no doubt have some explanation to give me, It s a little too complicated for
me to take in all at once, I confess and, if you won t think me rude,
Celia, I think I ll be getting along towards Knightsbridge.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well, Katharine will no doubt have some explanation to give me,', 'It s a little too complicated for\nme to take in all at once, I confess and, if you won t think me rude,\nCelia, I think I ll be getting along towards Knightsbridge.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
She has condoned Cassandra s conduct and entangled herself with Ralph
Denham,
subQuotationList: ['She has condoned Cassandra s conduct and entangled herself with Ralph\nDenham,']
speaker: Aunt Celia

quoteText:
I m sorry to bother you, my dear. I heard you come in, and thought I d
better make myself disagreeable at once as it seems, unfortunately,
that fathers are expected to make themselves disagreeable. Now, your
Aunt Celia has been to see me; your Aunt Celia has taken it into her
head apparently that you and Cassandra have been let us say a little
foolish. This going about together these pleasant little
parties there s been some kind of misunderstanding. I told her I saw no
harm in it, but I should just like to hear from yourself. Has Cassandra
been left a little too much in the company of Mr. Denham?
subQuotationList:
['I m sorry to bother you, my dear. I heard you come in, and thought I d
better make myself disagreeable at once as it seems, unfortunately,
that fathers are expected to make themselves disagreeable. Now, your
Aunt Celia has been to see me; your Aunt Celia has taken it into her
head apparently that you and Cassandra have been let us say a little
foolish. This going about together these pleasant little
parties there s been some kind of misunderstanding. I told her I saw no
harm in it, but I should just like to hear from yourself. Has Cassandra
been left a little too much in the company of Mr. Denham?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery
referringExpression: He thought instinctively that he had interrupted some happy hour of hers with Rodney and apologized
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText:
I don t see why I should answer Aunt Celia s questions. I ve told her
already that I won t.
subQuotationList: ['I don t see why I should answer Aunt Celia s questions. I ve told her\nalready that I won t.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
Very good. Then you authorize me to tell her that she s been mistaken,
and there was nothing but a little fun in it? You ve no doubt,
Katharine, in your own mind? Cassandra is in our charge, and I don t
intend that people should gossip about her. I suggest that you should
be a little more careful in future. Invite me to your next
entertainment.
subQuotationList:
['Very good. Then you authorize me to tell her that she s been mistaken,
and there was nothing but a little fun in it? You ve no doubt,
Katharine, in your own mind? Cassandra is in our charge, and I don t
intend that people should gossip about her. I suggest that you should

speaker: Mr. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'William Rodney', 'Ralph Denham']]]

quoteText: Have you a guilty conscience?
subQuotationList: ['Have you a guilty conscience?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
Tell me,
Katharine,
subQuotationList: ['Tell me,\nKatharine,']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText:
I ve been meaning to tell you for some time, I m not going
to marry William.
subQuotationList: ['I ve been meaning to tell you for some time,', 'I m not going\nto marry William.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: You re not going ! Why? When? Explain yourself, Katharine.
subQuotationList: ['You re not going !', 'Why? When? Explain yourself, Katharine.']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Oh, some time ago a week, perhaps more.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, some time ago a week, perhaps more.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
But may I ask why have I not been told of this what do you mean by
it?
subQuotationList: ['But may I ask why have I not been told of this what do you mean by\nit?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: We don t wish to be married that s all.
subQuotationList: ['We don t wish to be married that s all.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText: This is William s wish as well as yours?
subQuotationList: ['This is William s wish as well as yours?']
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

quoteText: Oh, yes. We agree perfectly.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes. We agree perfectly.']
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

quoteText:
I confess I find great difficulty in following you. I should like to
hear William s side of the story, I think he ought
to have spoken to me in the first instance.

quoteText:
Look here, we must get to the bottom of this, You ve had some difference of opinion, eh? Take my word for it, most
people go through this sort of thing when they re engaged. I ve seen
more trouble come from long engagements than from any other form of
human folly. Take my advice and put the whole matter out of your
minds both of you. I prescribe a complete abstinence from emotion.
Visit some cheerful seaside resort, Rodney.

quoteText:
But at least, we ve established the fact that my lapses
are still in some odd way connected with you; yours have nothing to do
with me. Katharine, I assure you that we are in love what other people call
love. Remember that night. We had no doubts whatever then. We were
absolutely happy for half an hour. You had no lapse until the day
after; I had no lapse until yesterday morning. We ve been happy at
intervals all day until I went off my head, and you, quite naturally,
were bored.

quoteText:
Then all I can say is that you ve very strange ideas of the proper way
to behave.... People have drawn certain conclusions, nor am I
surprised.... The more I think of it the more inexplicable I find it, Why am I left in ignorance
of what is going on in my own house? Why am I left to hear of these
events for the first time from my sister? Most disagreeable most
upsetting. How I m to explain to your Uncle Francis but I wash my hands
of it. Cassandra goes tomorrow. I forbid Rodney the house. As for the
other young man, the sooner he makes himself scarce the better. After
placing the most implicit trust in you, Katharine

quoteText:
These emotions have been very upsetting, naturally, You ve been placed in a very
difficult position, as I understand from Cassandra. Now let us come to
terms; we will leave these agitating questions in peace for the
present. Meanwhile, let us try to behave like civilized beings. Let us
read Sir Walter Scott. What d you say to  The Antiquary,  eh? Or  The
Bride of Lammermoor ?

sisters and brothers dependent on him.

quoteText:
We were in a little boat going out to a ship at night, The sun had set and the moon was rising over our heads. There were
lovely silver lights upon the waves and three green lights upon the
steamer in the middle of the bay. Your father s head looked so grand
against the mast. It was life, it was death. The great sea was round
us. It was the voyage for ever and ever.

are bound for, or why, or who has sent us, or what we shall find who

knew you were in love; but we re different. It seems, as if
something came to an end suddenly gave out faded an illusion as if when

That s why it s impossible that we should ever marry. Always to be
finding the other an illusion, and going off and forgetting about them,
never to be certain that you cared, or that he wasn t caring for some
one not you at all, the horror of changing from one state to the other,
being happy one moment and miserable the next that s the reason why we
can t possibly marry. At the same time, we can t live
without each other, because

quoteText:
I hope you re not disposing of somebody s fortune in a hurry, or cutting off an
entail at one blow, because I want to ask you to do me a favor. And
Anderson won t keep his horse waiting. (Anderson is a perfect tyrant,
but he drove my dear father to the Abbey the day they buried him.) I
made bold to come to you, Mr. Denham, not exactly in search of legal
assistance (though I don t know who I d rather come to, if I were in
trouble), but in order to ask your help in settling some tiresome
little domestic affairs that have arisen in my absence. I ve been to
Stratford-on-Avon (I must tell you all about that one of these days),
and there I got a letter from my sister-in-law, a dear kind goose who
likes interfering with other people s children because she s got none
of her own. (We re dreadfully afraid that she s going to lose the sight
of one of her eyes, and I always feel that our physical ailments are so
apt to turn into mental ailments. I think Matthew Arnold says something
of the same kind about Lord Byron.) But that s neither here nor there.
subQuotationList:
['I hope you re not disposing of somebody s fortune in a hurry,', 'or cutting off an
entail at one blow, because I want to ask you to do me a favor. And
Anderson won t keep his horse waiting. (Anderson is a perfect tyrant,
but he drove my dear father to the Abbey the day they buried him.) I
made bold to come to you, Mr. Denham, not exactly in search of legal
assistance (though I don t know who I d rather come to, if I were in
trouble), but in order to ask your help in settling some tiresome
little domestic affairs that have arisen in my absence. I ve been to
Stratford-on-Avon (I must tell you all about that one of these days),
and there I got a letter from my sister-in-law, a dear kind goose who
likes interfering with other people s children because she s got none
of her own. (We re dreadfully afraid that she s going to lose the sight
of one of her eyes, and I always feel that our physical ailments are so
apt to turn into mental ailments. I think Matthew Arnold says something
of the same kind about Lord Byron.) But that s neither here nor there.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ralph Denham']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Aunt Celia'], ['Aunt Celia']]]

quoteText:
I didn t come here to talk about Lord Byron, though I know that both you and Katharine, unlike
other young people of your generation, still find him worth reading.
subQuotationList: ['I didn t come here to talk about Lord Byron,', 'though I know that both you and Katharine, unlike\nother young people of your generation, still find him worth reading.']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText:
I m so glad you ve made Katharine read poetry, Mr.
Denham! and feel poetry, and look poetry! She can t
talk it yet, but she will oh, she will!
subQuotationList: ['I m so glad you ve made Katharine read poetry, Mr.\nDenham!', 'and feel poetry, and look poetry! She can t\ntalk it yet, but she will oh, she will!']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

subQuotationList: ['But you care for her?']

quoteText: Good God!
subQuotationList: ['Good God!']
speaker: Ralph Denham

quoteText: It s the Church of England service you both object to?
subQuotationList: ['It s the Church of England service you both object to?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: I don t care a damn what service it is,
subQuotationList: ['I don t care a damn what service it is,']

quoteText:
You would marry her in Westminster Abbey if the worst came to the
worst?
subQuotationList: ['You would marry her in Westminster Abbey if the worst came to the\nworst?']
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

quoteText: I would marry her in St. Paul s Cathedral,
subQuotationList: ['I would marry her in St. Paul s Cathedral,']

quoteText: Thank God!
subQuotationList: ['Thank God!']

quoteText:
Never mind, we ll go to St. Paul s another day, and it may

past Westminster Abbey, which would be even better.

Plenty of room.
We could find space for FOUR of you, William,
subQuotationList: ['Plenty of room.\nWe could find space for FOUR of you, William,']

I believe it will fit you without any

So much earth and so much water and that sublime spirit brooding over

Katharine and Ralph, William and

Until I have your father s consent I have no right to speak

subQuotationList:
